paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LEONATO, Governor of Messina;HERO, his daughter; and BEATRICE his niece, with a MESSENGER$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$HERO$NEWLINE$BEATRICE$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO, Governor of Messina;HERO, his daughter; and BEATRICE, his niece, enter with a MESSENGER$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$HERO$NEWLINE$BEATRICE$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I learn in this letter that Don Pedro of Aragon comes this$NEWLINE$night to Messina.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO$NEWLINE$(holding a letter) According to this letter,
Don Pedro of Aragon and his army are coming to Messina tonight.$NEWLINE$(holding a letter)$NEWLINE$Don$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He is very near by this. He was not three leagues off when$NEWLINE$I left him.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He must be very near by now. When I left him, he was less than nine miles from here.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$How many gentlemen have you lost in this action?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$How many noblemen were killed in the battle you just fought?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$But few of any sort, and none of name.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Not many, and no one important.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$A victory is twice itself when the achiever brings home full$NEWLINE$numbers. I find here that Don Pedro hath bestowed much$NEWLINE$honor on a young Florentine called Claudio.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$A victory in battle is twice as victorious when all the soldiers return home safely. This letter also says that Don Pedro has given honors to a young man from Florence named Claudio.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Much deserved on his part, and equally remembered by$NEWLINE$Don Pedro. He hath borne himself beyond the promise of$NEWLINE$his age, doing in the figure of a lamb the feats of a lion. He$NEWLINE$hath indeed better bettered expectation than you must$NEWLINE$expect of me to tell you how.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Claudio deserves to be honored, and Don Pedro has rewarded him accordingly. Claudio has done more than anyone would expect of a man his age. He looks like a lamb but fights like a lion. He has so greatly exceeded all expectations that I can’t even describe all he’s done.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$He hath an uncle here in Messina will be very much glad of$NEWLINE$it.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$He has an uncle here in Messina who will be glad to hear this news.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I have already delivered him letters, and there appears$NEWLINE$much joy in him—even so much that joy could not show$NEWLINE$itself modest enough without a badge of bitterness.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I have delivered some letters to his uncle, and he seemed very happy. He got so emotional that he actually looked like he was in pain.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Did he break out into tears?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Did he start weeping?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$In great measure.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Yes, heavily.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$A kind overflow of kindness. There are no faces truer than$NEWLINE$those that are so washed. How much better is it to weep at$NEWLINE$joy than to joy at weeping!
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$That’s a very natural display of affection. There’s no face more sincere than one washed in tears. And it’s definitely better to cry because you’re happy than laugh because you’re sad!

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I pray you, is Signor Montanto returned from the wars or$NEWLINE$no?
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Please tell me, has Signior
Montanto returned from battle?$NEWLINE$Montanto$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I know none of that name, lady. There was none such in the$NEWLINE$army of any sort.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I don’t know anyone with that name, ma'am. There was no Signior Montanto in our army.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$What is he that you ask for, niece?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Who are you talking about, niece?

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$My cousin means Signor Benedick of Padua.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Oh, he’s returned, and as pleasant as ever he was.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Oh, yes, Benedick has returned and is as cheerful as ever.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$He set up his bills here in Messina and challenged Cupid at$NEWLINE$the flight, and my uncle’s Fool, reading the challenge,$NEWLINE$subscribed for Cupid and challenged him at the bird-bolt.$NEWLINE$I pray you, how many hath he killed and eaten in these$NEWLINE$wars? But how many hath he killed? For indeed I promised$NEWLINE$to eat all of his killing.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Benedick once put up a public notice in Messina challenging Cupid to an archery match. My uncle’s jester accepted the contest on Cupid’s behalf but used toy arrows at the shooting match. But tell me, how many men did he kill and eat in this battle? I promised him I would eat anyone he killed.$NEWLINE$Benedick$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Faith, niece, you tax Signor Benedick too much, but he’ll be$NEWLINE$meet with you, I doubt it not.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$For God’s sake, Beatrice, you’re criticizing Signior Benedick too heavily. But I’m sure he’ll get even with you.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He hath done good service, lady, in these wars.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Signior Benedick served well in the war, my lady.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$You had musty victual, and he hath holp to eat it. He is a$NEWLINE$very valiant trencherman. He hath an excellent stomach.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$You had rotten food, and he helped you eat it. He’s a very brave eater—he has a strong stomach.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$And a good soldier too, lady.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He’s a good soldier too, lady.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$And a good soldier to a lady, but what is he to a lord?
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$He’s a good soldier to a lady? Well then, what is he to a lord?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$A lord to a lord, a man to a man, stuffed with all honorable$NEWLINE$virtues.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He’s a lord to a lord and a man to a man. He is positively stuffed with honorable virtues.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$It is so indeed. He is no less than a stuffed man. But for the$NEWLINE$stuffing—well, we are all mortal.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Absolutely—he is stuffed, like a dummy. As for what he’s stuffed with—well, nobody’s perfect.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$You must not, sir, mistake my niece. There is a kind of$NEWLINE$merry war betwixt Signor Benedick and her. They never$NEWLINE$meet but there’s a skirmish of wit between them.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Please don’t take my niece the wrong way, sir. Benedick and Beatrice have been waging a war of wits between themselves. Whenever they meet, there’s a little battle.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Alas, he gets nothing by that. In our last conflict four of his$NEWLINE$five wits went halting off, and now is the whole man$NEWLINE$governed with one, so that if he have wit enough to keep$NEWLINE$himself warm, let him bear it for a difference between$NEWLINE$himself and his horse, for it is all the wealth that he hath left$NEWLINE$to be known a reasonable creature. Who is his companion$NEWLINE$now? He hath every month a new sworn brother.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$And I always win. The last time we fought, he was so dazed by the end that he wasn’t much smarter than his horse. So tell me, who is he hanging around with these days? Every month he has a new best friend.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Is ’t possible?
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Is that possible?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Very easily possible. He wears his faith but as the fashion of$NEWLINE$his hat; it ever changes with the next block.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$It’s entirely possible. He’s incredibly fickle—his affection changes faster than the latest fashions.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I see, lady, the gentleman is not in your books.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I can see you don’t like this gentleman.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$No. An he were, I would burn my study. But I pray you,$NEWLINE$who is his companion? Is there no young squarer now that$NEWLINE$will make a voyage with him to the devil?
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$No, absolutely not. But please tell me, who’s his best friend? Isn’t there some new swaggering young ruffian who will happily go to hell with Benedick?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He spends most of his time with the good, noble Claudio.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$O Lord, he will hang upon him like a disease! He is sooner$NEWLINE$caught than the pestilence, and the taker runs presently$NEWLINE$mad. God help the noble Claudio! If he have caught the$NEWLINE$Benedick, it will cost him a thousand pound ere a be cured.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Oh God, Benedick will plague him like a disease! Benedick is an infection that’s easy to catch but hard to get rid of—and he’ll drive you crazy once you’ve been infected. God help Claudio! If he’s caught the Benedick, he’ll lose all his money before he’s cured.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I will hold friends with you, lady.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I’m going to make sure I stay on your good side, lady.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Do, good friend.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Do that, my friend.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$You will never run mad, niece.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$You will never fall victim to Benedick’s charms, my niece.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$No, not till a hot January.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$No, not until we see a hot January.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Don Pedro is approached.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Don Pedro is here.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO, Prince of Aragon, with CLAUDIO, BENEDICK,BALTHASAR, and DON JOHN the bastard$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$DON JOHN
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO, Prince of Aragon, enters with CLAUDIO, BENEDICK,BALTHASAR, and
DON JOHN, the bastard.$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$DON JOHN$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Good Signor Leonato, are you come to meet your trouble?$NEWLINE$The fashion of the world is to avoid cost, and you encounter$NEWLINE$it.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$My dear Signior Leonato, hosting my whole army is such a huge burden, but you accept it—and me—with open arms. Most people choose to avoid trouble, but you run to it.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Never came trouble to my house in the likeness of your$NEWLINE$Grace, for trouble being gone, comfort should remain, but$NEWLINE$when you depart from me, sorrow abides and happiness$NEWLINE$takes his leave.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$You are never trouble to this house, your Grace. It’s comforting when trouble departs. But when you leave, you take happiness with you and leave sorrow in its place.$NEWLINE$you

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$You embrace your charge too willingly. I think this is your$NEWLINE$daughter.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$You take up your duties too cheerfully. (turning to HERO) This must be your daughter.$NEWLINE$(turning to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Her mother hath many times told me so.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$That’s what her mother always tells me.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Were you in doubt, sir, that you asked her?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Did you doubt that she was your daughter, since you had to ask her mother?

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Signor Benedick, no, for then were you a child.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$(teasing) Of course not, Signior Benedick. You were only a child when my daughter was born, and not yet old enough to seduce my wife.$NEWLINE$(teasing)

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$You have it full, Benedick. We may guess by this what you$NEWLINE$are, being a man. Truly, the lady fathers herself.—Be$NEWLINE$happy, lady, for you are like an honorable father.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Ah, he got you back, Benedick! Leonato clearly knows your reputation with women. Seriously, though, the lady resembles Leonato so much that there can be no doubt about who her father is. Congratulations, lady: you resemble a most honorable man.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO and DON PEDRO move to one side, still talking$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO and DON PEDRO move to one side, still talking.$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$If Signor Leonato be her father, she would not have his$NEWLINE$head on her shoulders for all Messina, as like him as she is.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Well, even if he is her father, I’m sure she wouldn’t want to have the head of the old man on her shoulders!

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I wonder that you will still be talking, Signor Benedick.$NEWLINE$Nobody marks you.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I’m amazed you’re still talking, Signior Benedick. No one’s listening to you.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$What, my dear Lady Disdain! Are you yet living?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Look, it’s my dear Lady Disdain! Aren’t you dead yet?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Is it possible disdain should die while she hath such meet$NEWLINE$food to feed it as Signor Benedick? Courtesy itself must$NEWLINE$convert to disdain if you come in her presence.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$How could disdain die when you’re here? When you’re around, even Lady Courtesy becomes Lady Disdain.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Then is courtesy a turncoat. But it is certain I am loved of$NEWLINE$all ladies, only you excepted. And I would I could find in$NEWLINE$my heart that I had not a hard heart, for truly I love none.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$That makes Lady Courtesy a traitor. All ladies love me, except you. It’s too bad I’m so hard-hearted, because I really don’t love anyone.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$A dear happiness to women. They would else have been$NEWLINE$troubled with a pernicious suitor. I thank God and my cold$NEWLINE$blood I am of your humor for that. I had rather hear my dog$NEWLINE$bark at a crow than a man swear he loves me.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Women are lucky, then. You would make a nasty suitor. Thankfully, I feel the same way you do. I have no need for romance. I would rather listen to my dog bark at a crow than hear a man swear that he loves me.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$God keep your Ladyship still in that mind, so some gentle-$NEWLINE$man or other shall ’scape a predestinate scratched face.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Well, I hope you stay in that frame of mind or some poor man will end up with his face all scratched up.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Scratching could not make it worse an ’twere such a face as$NEWLINE$yours were.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$If he has a face like yours, a good scratching couldn’t make him look any worse.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Well, you are a rare parrot-teacher.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Listen to you, instructing me like a parrot would.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$A bird of my tongue is better than a beast of yours.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I’d rather be a squawking bird than an animal like you.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I would my horse had the speed of your tongue and so good$NEWLINE$a continuer. But keep your way, i' God’s name. I have done.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I wish my horse moved as fast as your mouth and was as tireless. That’s it—I’m done.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$You always end with a jade’s trick. I know you of old.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$You always slip out of the argument like this. I know you from before.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO and DON PEDRO come forward$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO and DON PEDRO come forward$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$That is the sum of all, Leonato.—Signior Claudio and$NEWLINE$Signior Benedick, my dear friend Leonato hath invited you$NEWLINE$all. I tell him we shall stay here at the least a month, and he$NEWLINE$heartily prays some occasion may detain us longer. I dare$NEWLINE$swear he is no hypocrite but prays from his heart.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$And that’s everything, Leonato.—Claudio, Benedick—my dear friend Leonato has invited you all to stay here at Messina. I told him we’ll stay for at least a month, and he says that he hopes we’ll stay longer. I think he’s actually serious, and not just being polite.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$If you swear, my lord, you shall not be forsworn. (to DON$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$JOHN) Let me bid you welcome, my lord. Being reconciled$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$to the Prince your brother, I owe you all duty.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I am being serious, my lord. (to DON JOHN) I welcome you here as well. Now that you and your brother have made friends again, I owe you the same allegiance I owe Don Pedro.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I thank you. I am not of many words, but I thank you.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Thank you. I’m not a man who talks a lot, but I thank you.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Please it your Grace lead on?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$If it pleases you, your highness, will you lead us all inside?

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Your hand, Leonato. We will go together.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Give me your hand, Leonato. We will go in together.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt. Manent BENEDICK andCLAUDIO$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except BENEDICK andCLAUDIO.$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Benedick, didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Benedick, did you notice Signior Leonato’s daughter?

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I noted her not, but I looked on her.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I saw her, but I didn’t notice her.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Is she not a modest young lady?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Isn’t she a well-mannered young lady?

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Do you question me as an honest man should do, for my$NEWLINE$simple true judgment? Or would you have me speak after$NEWLINE$my custom, as being a professed tyrant to their sex?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Do you want my true opinion? Or do you want me to criticize her like I do all women?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$No, I pray thee speak in sober judgment.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$No, please, speak seriously.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Why, i' faith, methinks she’s too low for a high praise, too$NEWLINE$brown for a fair praise, and too little for a great praise. Only$NEWLINE$this commendation I can afford her, that were she other$NEWLINE$than she is, she were unhandsome, and being no other but$NEWLINE$as she is, I do not like her.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Well, it seems to me that she is too short to be praised highly, too dark to be praised fairly, and too small to be praised greatly. I can only say this about her: if she looked different than she does, she would be ugly, and since she can’t be anything but herself, I don’t like her.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Thou thinkest I am in sport. I pray thee tell me truly how$NEWLINE$thou lik’st her.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$You think I’m kidding. Please tell me seriously what you think of her.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Would you buy her, that you enquire after her?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Are you thinking of buying her? Is that why you’re asking?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Can the world buy such a jewel?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Would it even be possible to buy a jewel as rare and precious as Hero?

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Yea, and a case to put it into. But speak you this with a sad$NEWLINE$brow? Or do you play the flouting jack, to tell us Cupid is$NEWLINE$a good hare-finder and Vulcan a rare carpenter? Come, in$NEWLINE$what key shall a man take you to go in the song?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Yes, and you could buy a case to put it in, too. But tell me, are you speaking seriously? Or are you just teasing? If I’m going to sing along with you, I need to know what key you’re singing in.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$In mine eye she is the sweetest lady that ever I looked on.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I think she’s the most wonderful woman I’ve ever laid eyes on.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I can see yet without spectacles, and I see no such matter.$NEWLINE$There’s her cousin, an she were not possessed with a fury,$NEWLINE$exceeds her as much in beauty as the first of May doth the$NEWLINE$last of December. But I hope you have no intent to turn$NEWLINE$husband, have you?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I’m still young enough to see without glasses, and I don’t see what you’re talking about. If her cousin Beatrice didn’t have such a nasty temper, she’d be so much more beautiful than Hero that it would be like comparing May to December. But, hey, this doesn’t mean you’re looking to get married, does it?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I would scarce trust myself, though I had sworn the$NEWLINE$contrary, if Hero would be my wife.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Even if I had sworn never to marry, I wouldn’t trust myself to keep that promise if Hero would marry me.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Is ’t come to this? In faith, hath not the world one man but$NEWLINE$he will wear his cap with suspicion? Shall I never see a$NEWLINE$bachelor of three-score again? Go to, i' faith, an thou wilt$NEWLINE$needs thrust thy neck into a yoke, wear the print of it, and$NEWLINE$sigh away Sundays. Look, Don Pedro is returned to seek$NEWLINE$you.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$What’s going on these days? Isn’t there one man left in the world who knows not to take a wife? She’s just going to cheat on him. Will I never see a sixty-year old bachelor again or will all men be swindled into marriage while they’re young? Go ahead, then, if you have to yoke yourself to marriage, like an ox carrying his load, and throw away your free time. Look, Don Pedro has come back for you.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO enters.$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$What secret hath held you here that you followed not to$NEWLINE$Leonato’s?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$What secrets between you have kept you from following us to Leonato’s?

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I would your grace would constrain me to tell.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Your highness will have to force me to tell.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I charge thee on thy allegiance.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Your loyalty to me requires you to tell me what you’ve been talking about.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$You hear, Count Claudio? I can be secret as a dumb man, I$NEWLINE$would have you think so, but on my allegiance—mark you$NEWLINE$this, on my allegiance—(to DON PEDRO) he is in love. With$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$who? Now, that is your Grace’s part. Mark how short his$NEWLINE$answer is: with Hero, Leonato’s short daughter.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Look, Claudio, I can keep secrets like a mute; I want you to know that. But I owe Don Pedro my allegiance—look, I have to tell him—(to DON PEDRO) Claudio is in love. With whom? That’s what you’re supposed to ask me next, your Grace. Look how short the answer is—with Hero, Leonato’s short daughter.$NEWLINE$have$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$If this were so, so were it uttered.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$If you say so.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Like the old tale, my lord: “It is not so nor ’twas not so but,$NEWLINE$indeed, God forbid it should be so.”
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Listen to him deny it, like that man in the old tale “Mr. Fox”: “It isn’t true and wasn’t true and God forbid it should be so.”

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$If my passion change not shortly, God forbid it should be$NEWLINE$otherwise.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Unless my feelings change very soon, I have to admit it’s true.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Amen, if you love her, for the lady is very well worthy.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$It’s good if you love Hero, because she’s worthy of your love.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$You speak this to fetch me in, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$You’re trying to trick me, my lord.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$By my troth, I speak my thought.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I swear, I’m telling you what I honestly think.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And, in faith, my lord, I spoke mine.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And I swear I spoke honestly to Benedick—I am in love with Hero.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$And by my two faiths and troths, my lord, I spoke mine.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$And I swear all up and down I spoke honestly when I said that this was a horrible idea.$NEWLINE$I

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$That I love her, I feel.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I feel that I love her.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$That she is worthy, I know.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I know that she is worthy of that love.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$That I neither feel how she should be loved nor know how$NEWLINE$she should be worthy is the opinion that fire cannot melt$NEWLINE$out$NEWLINE$of me. I will die in it at the stake.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I, on the other hand, don’t feel how she could be loved and don’t know how she could be worthy. Even fire can’t melt that opinion out of me. You could burn me at the stake, and I’d still think this.$NEWLINE$feel$NEWLINE$know

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Thou wast ever an obstinate heretic in the despite of beauty.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$You never did believe in the power of beauty.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And never could maintain his part but in the force of his will.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Or in the power of reason.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$That a woman conceived me, I thank her. That she brought$NEWLINE$me up, I likewise give her most humble thanks. But that I$NEWLINE$will have a recheat winded in my forehead or hang my bugle$NEWLINE$in an invisible baldrick, all women shall pardon me.$NEWLINE$Because I will not do them the wrong to mistrust any, I will$NEWLINE$do myself the right to trust none. And the fine is, for the$NEWLINE$which I may go the finer, I will live a bachelor.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I was conceived by a woman, and I thank her very much for all her effort. And then she brought me up, and I thank her for that, too. But all the other women will have to forgive me for not being willing to be made a fool of—cheated on by a wife. I don’t want to insult any particular woman by doubting and mistrusting her, so I’ll just avoid them all. And the conclusion of this is that I’ll live as a bachelor—and, with the money I save, dress better.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I shall see thee, ere I die, look pale with love.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I swear, before I die I’m going to see you sick with love.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$With anger, with sickness, or with hunger, my lord, not$NEWLINE$with love. Prove that ever I lose more blood with love than$NEWLINE$I will get again with drinking, pick out mine eyes with a$NEWLINE$ballad-maker’s pen and hang me up at the door of a brothel$NEWLINE$house for the sign of blind Cupid.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$With anger, with fever, or with hunger, sure, my friend, but never sick with love. If you can prove that I’ll ever be so in love that I can’t be brought to my senses with a good round of beers, you can pluck out my eyes with a love-poet’s pen and hang me on a brothel’s door where the picture of blind Cupid usually goes.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Well, if ever thou dost fall from this faith, thou wilt prove$NEWLINE$a notable argument.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I’ll be sure to remember this fuss you’ve made, in case you ever do fall in love. That’ll be news.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$If I do, hang me in a bottle like a cat and shoot at me, and he$NEWLINE$that hits me, let him be clapped on the shoulder and called$NEWLINE$Adam.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$If I ever change my mind, you can use me for target practice. And whoever hits the bull’s eye gets to be a hero.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Well, as time shall try.$NEWLINE$In time the savage bull doth bear the yoke.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Well, time will tell. Even the most savage bull is eventually domesticated.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$The savage bull may, but if ever the sensible Benedick bear$NEWLINE$it, pluck off the bull’s horns and set them in my forehead,$NEWLINE$and let me be vilely painted, and in such great letters as they$NEWLINE$write “Here is good horse to hire” let them signify under my$NEWLINE$sign “Here you may see Benedick the married man.”
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Maybe the bull is, but if I am ever domesticated, you can take that bull’s horns and put them right on my forehead, as my wife is sure to cuckold me soon enough. You might as well hang a big sign with enormous lettering around my neck. But instead of it saying “Horse for hire,” it will say “Take a look at Benedick, the married man.”$NEWLINE$I

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$If this should ever happen, thou wouldst be horn-mad.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$If that ever happened, you’d go absolutely mad.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Nay, if Cupid have not spent all his quiver in Venice, thou$NEWLINE$wilt quake for this shortly.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Well, if Cupid hasn’t used up all his arrows in Venice, where the courtesans are famous for making men lovesick, he’ll get you to quiver and shake. Just you wait.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I look for an earthquake too, then.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$That’s about as likely as an earthquake.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Well, you temporize with the hours. In the meantime, good$NEWLINE$Signior Benedick, repair to Leonato’s. Commend me to$NEWLINE$him and tell him I will not fail him at supper, for indeed he$NEWLINE$hath made great preparation.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Oh, you’ll soften as time passes. While you’re waiting for that to happen, though, hurry to Leonato’s. Give him my respects, and tell him I’ll definitely be there for dinner, since I know he has gone to great lengths for this meal.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I have almost matter enough in me for such an embassage,$NEWLINE$and so I commit you—
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I think I can handle this mission. And so I commit you—

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$To the tuition of God. From my house, if I had it—
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$“Into God’s hands. From my house, if I had a house—”

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$The sixth of July. Your loving friend, Benedick.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$“The sixth of July. Sincerely, your loving friend, Benedick.”

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Nay, mock not, mock not. The body of your discourse is$NEWLINE$sometimes guarded with fragments and the guards are but$NEWLINE$slightly basted on neither. Ere you flout old ends any$NEWLINE$further, examine your conscience. And so I leave you.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Oh, stop joking around. You know, sometimes you two dress up your conversation with flimsy little bits of wit that don’t hold together too well. Before you make
fun of everyone else, look at yourselves in the mirror! And with that, I’m leaving.$NEWLINE$fun$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$My liege, your highness now may do me good.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$My lord, you could really help me out now.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$My love is thine to teach. Teach it but how,$NEWLINE$And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn$NEWLINE$Any hard lesson that may do thee good.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I am at your service. Just tell me what you want me to do, and however hard it is, you’ll see that I’m eager to do it.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Hath Leonato any son, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Does Leonato have a son, my lord?

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$No child but Hero; she’s his only heir.$NEWLINE$Dost thou affect her, Claudio?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Hero is his only child, and his only heir. Do you like her, Claudio?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$O, my lord,$NEWLINE$When you went onward on this ended action,$NEWLINE$I looked upon her with a soldier’s eye,$NEWLINE$That liked but had a rougher task in hand$NEWLINE$Than to drive liking to the name of love.$NEWLINE$But now I am returned and that war thoughts$NEWLINE$Have left their places vacant, in their rooms$NEWLINE$Come thronging soft and delicate desires,$NEWLINE$All prompting me how fair young Hero is,$NEWLINE$Saying I liked her ere I went to wars.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Oh, my lord, when we left Messina to fight the war, I looked at Hero with the eyes of a soldier. I liked what I saw, but my mind was so occupied with the rough, violent task ahead of me that there was no chance that like would turn intolove. But now that I’m back, the room in my head that I used to fill with war plans has become crowded with soft and delicate feelings. They all lead me to the same thought—how beautiful young Hero is and how I must have liked her even before I left to fight.$NEWLINE$like$NEWLINE$love

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Thou wilt be like a lover presently$NEWLINE$And tire the hearer with a book of words.$NEWLINE$If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it,$NEWLINE$And I will break with her and with her father,$NEWLINE$And thou shalt have her. Was ’t not to this end$NEWLINE$That thou began’st to twist so fine a story?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$You will become a true lover soon, and exhaust your friends with your endless chatter about your feelings. Look, if you really love the beautiful Hero, enjoy it. I will speak to her and her father about the matter, and I’ll convince Leonato to promise Hero to you. Isn’t that the reason you told me all this?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$How sweetly you do minister to love,$NEWLINE$That know love’s grief by his complexion!$NEWLINE$But lest my liking might too sudden seem,$NEWLINE$I would have salved it with a longer treatise.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$You can see that I’m sick with love, and you’re taking care of me in just the right way! But I didn’t want you to think that I’m hasty in my emotions. I was going to explain my feelings with a longer story.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$What need the bridge much broader than the flood?$NEWLINE$The fairest grant is the necessity.$NEWLINE$Look what will serve is fit. 'Tis once, thou lovest,$NEWLINE$And I will fit thee with the remedy.$NEWLINE$I know we shall have reveling tonight.$NEWLINE$I will assume thy part in some disguise$NEWLINE$And tell fair Hero I am Claudio,$NEWLINE$And in her bosom I’ll unclasp my heart$NEWLINE$And take her hearing prisoner with the force$NEWLINE$And strong encounter of my amorous tale.$NEWLINE$Then after to her father will I break,$NEWLINE$And the conclusion is, she shall be thine.$NEWLINE$In practice let us put it presently.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Why speak longer than you have to? That’s like building a bridge wider than the river it crosses. Whatever gets the job done is best. You love Hero; that’s all I need to know to want to find a remedy. They’re going to have a costume party with dancing tonight. I’ll disguise myself as you and pour out “my” feelings to Hero, taking her prisoner with the force of my love story. Then I’ll talk to her father. And in the end, she’s yours! Let’s get started right away.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LEONATO andANTONIO$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO and ANTONIO enter.$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$How now, brother, where is my cousin, your son? Hath he$NEWLINE$provided this music?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Hey, brother. Tell me, where is my nephew, your son? Has he taken care of the music?

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$He is very busy about it. But, brother, I can tell you strange$NEWLINE$news that you yet dreamt not of.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$He is taking care of it as we speak. But brother, I have some strange news for you.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Are they good?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Is it good news?

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$As the events stamps them, but they have a good cover;$NEWLINE$they show well outward. The Prince and Count Claudio,$NEWLINE$walking in a thick-pleached alley in mine orchard, were$NEWLINE$thus much overheard by a man of mine: the Prince$NEWLINE$discovered to Claudio that he loved my niece your daughter$NEWLINE$and meant to acknowledge it this night in a dance, and if he$NEWLINE$found her accordant, he meant to take the present time by$NEWLINE$the top and instantly break with you of it.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Well, it seems like good news. A servant of mine overheard the Prince and Claudio talking as they walked through my orchard. The Prince said that he is in love with Hero, your daughter, and that he is going to tell her so at the dance tonight. If he she wants to marry him, too, he’s going to find you and ask for her hand immediately.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Hath the fellow any wit that told you this?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Is this servant of yours a smart man?

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$A good sharp fellow. I will send for him, and question him$NEWLINE$yourself.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$He’s very bright. I’ll get him to come here, and you can ask him yourself.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$No, no, we will hold it as a dream till it appear itself. But I$NEWLINE$will acquaint my daughter withal, that she may be the$NEWLINE$better prepared for an answer if peradventure this be true.$NEWLINE$Go you and tell her of it.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$No, no, until it comes true we’ll pretend it was just a dream we had. But my daughter should know about this, so she can be prepared with an answer just in case. Go to her and tell her for me.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONIO ’s son, with a musician and attendants$NEWLINE$ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO ’s son enters with a musician and attendants.$NEWLINE$ANTONIO

paragraphs.original: Cousins, you know what you have to do.—O, I cry you$NEWLINE$mercy, friend. Go you with me and I will use your skill.—$NEWLINE$Good cousin, have a care this busy time.
paragraphs.translated: Cousins, you all have work to do.—Oh, I beg your pardon. Come with me now, and help me out. —Dear cousin, please be careful during this busy time.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter DON JOHN andCONRAD$NEWLINE$DON JOHN$NEWLINE$CONRAD
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN and CONRAD enter.$NEWLINE$DON JOHN$NEWLINE$CONRAD

paragraphs.original: CONRAD$NEWLINE$What the goodyear, my lord, why are you thus out of$NEWLINE$measure sad?
paragraphs.translated: CONRAD$NEWLINE$Really, my lord, why are you so excessively sad?

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$There is no measure in the occasion that breeds. Therefore$NEWLINE$the sadness is without limit.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$The things that cause my sadness are without limit. Therefore my sadness is without limit.

paragraphs.original: CONRAD$NEWLINE$You should hear reason.
paragraphs.translated: CONRAD$NEWLINE$You should listen to reason. Then you’d stop being so gloomy.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$And when I have heard it, what blessing brings it?
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$And after I have sat and listened to reason, what’s my prize?

paragraphs.original: CONRAD$NEWLINE$If not a present remedy, at least a patient sufferance.
paragraphs.translated: CONRAD$NEWLINE$If not an end to your suffering, then at least you’ll have the means to endure it patiently.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I wonder that thou, being, as thou sayst thou art, born$NEWLINE$under Saturn, goest about to apply a moral medicine to a$NEWLINE$mortifying mischief. I cannot hide what I am. I must be sad$NEWLINE$when I have cause and smile at no man’s jests, eat when I$NEWLINE$have stomach and wait for no man’s leisure, sleep when I am$NEWLINE$drowsy and tend on no man’s business, laugh when I am$NEWLINE$merry and claw no man in his humor.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I’m amazed that you—being such a moody man yourself—are moralizing about my deadly condition. I can’t hide what I am. I’ll be sad when I have reason to be sad and won’t smile at anybody’s jokes. I’ll eat when I’m hungry and won’t wait until it’s convenient. I’ll sleep when I’m tired and won’t rouse myself for anything. I’ll laugh when I’m happy and won’t flatter and fawn over anyone.

paragraphs.original: CONRAD$NEWLINE$Yea, but you must not make the full show of this till you$NEWLINE$may do it without controlment. You have of late stood out$NEWLINE$against your brother, and he hath ta'en you newly into his$NEWLINE$grace, where it is impossible you should take true root but$NEWLINE$by the fair weather that you make yourself. It is needful that$NEWLINE$you frame the season for your own harvest.
paragraphs.translated: CONRAD$NEWLINE$Sure, but don’t do it at full volume until there’s no danger in it. Not long ago you challenged and opposed your brother, and it is only very recently that he has forgiven you. You need to act carefully if you’re going to stay in his good graces. You have to wait for the appropriate time to let loose.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I had rather be a canker in a hedge than a rose in his grace,$NEWLINE$and it better fits my blood to be disdained of all than to$NEWLINE$fashion a carriage to rob love from any. In this, though I$NEWLINE$cannot be said to be a flattering honest man, it must not be$NEWLINE$denied but I am a plain-dealing villain. I am trusted with a$NEWLINE$muzzle and enfranchised with a clog; therefore I have$NEWLINE$decreed not to sing in my cage. If I had my mouth, I would$NEWLINE$bite; if I had my liberty, I would do my liking. In the$NEWLINE$meantime, let me be that I am, and seek not to alter me.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I’d rather be a weed in a hedge than a rose in my brother’s garden. It suits me more to be hated by everyone than to put on a fancy show and trick people into loving me. Though I am not a flattering, righteous man, at least you can say that I am honest about being a villain. My brother trusts me now? Yeah—as much as a master trusts the dog he muzzles or the peasant he “frees” by chaining a big block around the man’s foot. If my mouth were unrestrained, I’d bite. If I were free, I’d do what I pleased. Until that happens, let me be who I am and don’t try to change me.

paragraphs.original: CONRAD$NEWLINE$Can you make no use of your discontent?
paragraphs.translated: CONRAD$NEWLINE$Can’t you somehow use your dissatisfaction to your own advantage?

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I make all use of it, for I use it only. Who comes here?
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I use it all the time, since it’s all that I have. Who’s that?

paragraphs.original: Enter BORACHIO$NEWLINE$BORACHIO
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO enters.$NEWLINE$BORACHIO

paragraphs.original: What news, Borachio?
paragraphs.translated: What’s going on, Borachio?

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$I came yonder from a great supper. The Prince your$NEWLINE$brother$NEWLINE$is royally entertained by Leonato, and I can give you$NEWLINE$intelligence of an intended marriage.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$I just came from a great feast where Leonato is entertaining the Prince, your brother. I can give you information about an intended marriage.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Will it serve for any model to build mischief on? What is he$NEWLINE$for a fool that betroths himself to unquietness?
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Will this give me an opportunity to make some mischief? Who is this fool who wants all the fuss of marriage?

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Marry, it is your brother’s right hand.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Your brother’s right-hand man.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Who? The most exquisite Claudio?
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Who? That pretty boy, Claudio?

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Even he.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$That’s the one.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$A proper squire. And who, and who? Which way looks he?
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$He’s a very fancy gentleman. And who’s the girl who has caught his eye?

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Marry, on Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$A very forward March-chick! How came you to this?
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$A lively young one! How did you learn about this?

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Being entertained for a perfumer, as I was smoking a musty$NEWLINE$room, comes me the Prince and Claudio, hand in hand, in$NEWLINE$sad conference. I whipped me behind the arras, and there$NEWLINE$heard it agreed upon that the Prince should woo Hero for$NEWLINE$himself, and having obtained her, give her to Count$NEWLINE$Claudio.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$I was hired to perfume all the rooms in Leonato’s house. As I was working on one musty room, the Prince and Claudio entered. They were in the middle of a serious conversation. I quickly hid behind a tapestry and heard them agree that the Prince would court Hero tonight at the dance and, once he won her consent to marry, would give her to Claudio.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Come, come, let us thither. This may prove food to my$NEWLINE$displeasure. That young start-up hath all the glory of my$NEWLINE$overthrow. If I can cross him any way, I bless myself every$NEWLINE$way. You are both sure, and will assist me?
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Come, let’s go to the dance. This just may cheer me up. Claudio, the young upstart, was responsible for keeping me from gaining power over my brother. If there’s any way I can spoil his life, I’ll be overjoyed. You’ll both help me, right?

paragraphs.original: CONRAD$NEWLINE$To the death, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: CONRAD$NEWLINE$Until the day we die, my lord.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Let us to the great supper. Their cheer is the greater that I$NEWLINE$am subdued. Would the cook were o' my mind! Shall we go$NEWLINE$prove what’s to be done?
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Let’s go to this great feast. They’ll be even happier now that my mood has lightened. It’s too bad the cook doesn’t think like me; she would have poisoned them all if she did. Should we go check out the scene?

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$We’ll wait upon your lordship.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Lead the way, sir.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LEONATO,ANTONIO, HERO,BEATRICE, URSULA andMARGARET$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$HERO$NEWLINE$BEATRICE$NEWLINE$URSULA$NEWLINE$MARGARET
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO, ANTONIO HERO BEATRICE URSULA, and MARGARET enter.$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$HERO$NEWLINE$BEATRICE$NEWLINE$URSULA$NEWLINE$MARGARET

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Was not Count John here at supper?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Wasn’t Don John at dinner tonight?

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I saw him not.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I didn’t see him.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$How tartly that gentleman looks! I never can see him but I$NEWLINE$am heartburned an hour after.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$That man always looks so sour! Just looking at him gives me heartburn.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$He is of a very melancholy disposition.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$He has a very gloomy attitude.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$He were an excellent man that were made just in the$NEWLINE$midway between him and Benedick. The one is too like an$NEWLINE$image and says nothing, and the other too like my lady’s$NEWLINE$eldest son, evermore tattling.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$It would be excellent if they could make a man halfway between Don John and Benedick. One of them is too much like a painting of a man—he never speaks—and the other is too much like a spoiled little boy, always chattering.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Then half Signor Benedick’s tongue in Count John’s$NEWLINE$mouth, and half Count John’s melancholy in Signor$NEWLINE$Benedick’s face—
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$So, the man would talk half as much as Benedick and be half as serious as Don John—

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$With a good leg and a good foot, uncle, and money enough$NEWLINE$in his purse, such a man would win any woman in the$NEWLINE$world, if he could get her goodwill.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$And if he were handsome, agile, and rich, too, he could have any woman in the world—all he’d need was her good will.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$By my troth, niece, thou wilt never get thee a husband if$NEWLINE$thou be so shrewd of thy tongue.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Really, niece, you’ll never get a husband if you keep saying such harsh things about people.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$In faith, she’s too curst.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Honestly, she is too ill-tempered.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Too curst is more than curst. I shall lessen God’s sending$NEWLINE$that way, for it is said, “God sends a curst cow short horns,”$NEWLINE$but to a cow too curst, he sends none.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Being “too ill-tempered” is different from being simply “ill-tempered,” right? So I suppose that means I can escape God’s punishment, for in the old proverb, it is said that “God gives an ill-tempered cow short horns” so that she can’t inflict damage on anyone. But it doesn’t say anything about a cow that is too ill-tempered.$NEWLINE$too

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$So, by being too curst, God will send you no horns.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$So then, for being too argumentative, God won’t send you any horns?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Just, if he send me no husband, for the which blessing I am$NEWLINE$at him upon my knees every morning and evening. Lord, I$NEWLINE$could not endure a husband with a beard on his face! I had$NEWLINE$rather lie in the woolen.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Exactly. I pray every morning and night that the Lord won’t send me a husband. Really, I couldn’t stand a husband with a beard. I’d rather be wrapped in scratchy blankets all night.$NEWLINE$Exactly$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$You may light on a husband that hath no beard.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Maybe you will find a husband without a beard.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$What should I do with him? Dress him in my apparel and$NEWLINE$make him my waiting gentlewoman? He that hath a beard$NEWLINE$is more than a youth, and he that hath no beard is less than$NEWLINE$a man; and he that is more than a youth is not for me, and$NEWLINE$he that is less than a man, I am not for him. Therefore I will$NEWLINE$even take sixpence in earnest of the bearherd, and lead his$NEWLINE$apes into hell.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$And then what would I do with him? Dress him up in my clothes and pretend he’s my lady servant? If he has a beard, he’s more than a boy; if he doesn’t have a beard, he’s less than a man. If he’s more than a boy, he’s not the one for me, and if he’s less than a man, I’m not the one for him. They say that women who die unmarried are destined to lead the apes to hell, and I suppose that’ll be my fate as well.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Well then, go you into hell?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$So you’ll go to hell?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$No, but to the gate, and there will the devil meet me like an$NEWLINE$old cuckold with horns on his head, and say, “Get you to$NEWLINE$heaven, Beatrice, get you to heaven; here’s no place for you$NEWLINE$maids.” So deliver I up my apes and away to Saint Peter. For$NEWLINE$the heavens, he shows me where the bachelors sit, and there$NEWLINE$live we as merry as the day is long.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$No, just to the gates of hell, where the devil will meet me, with the horns on his head like a cuckold, and say, “Go up to heaven, Beatrice. Hell is no place for you virgins.” So I’ll fly up to heaven (leaving the apes behind) where I’ll be met by Saint Peter guarding heaven’s gates. He will show me the part of heaven where the bachelors sit, and I’ll have fun there forever.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$(to HERO)Well, niece, I trust you will be ruled by your$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$father.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$(to HERO) Well, niece, I trust that you will defer to your father on these important decisions.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Yes, faith, it is my cousin’s duty to make curtsy and say,$NEWLINE$“Father, as it please you.” But yet for all that, cousin, let$NEWLINE$him be a handsome fellow, or else make another curtsy and$NEWLINE$say, “Father, as it please me.”
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Surely, my cousin has a duty to please her father. But if the husband her father chooses isn’t handsome, she should sweetly tell her father that she will please herself—with another one.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Well, niece, I hope to see you one day fitted with a husband.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Well, niece, I hope that I will see you married one day.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Not till God make men of some other metal than earth.$NEWLINE$Would it not grieve a woman to be overmastered with a$NEWLINE$piece of valiant dust? To make an account of her life to a clod$NEWLINE$of wayward marl? No, uncle, I’ll none. Adam’s sons are my$NEWLINE$brethren, and truly I hold it a sin to match in my kindred.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE$NEWLINE$No, I won’t take a husband until they make men out of something other than dirt. What woman wouldn’t be distressed, being lorded over by a handful of dust? Can you imagine being hitched to a lump of clay? No, uncle, I won’t be married. And anyhow, if
Adam is the father of all mankind, then his sons are my brothers, and really I believe that incest is a sin.$NEWLINE$Adam$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$(to HERO) Daughter, remember what I told you. If the$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Prince do solicit you in that kind, you know your answer.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$(to HERO) Daughter, remember what I told you. If the Prince asks for your hand in marriage, you know what to tell him.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$The fault will be in the music, cousin, if you be not wooed$NEWLINE$in good time. If the Prince be too important, tell him there$NEWLINE$is measure in everything, and so dance out the answer. For$NEWLINE$hear me, Hero, wooing, wedding, and repenting is as a$NEWLINE$Scotch jig, a measure, and a cinquepace. The first suit is hot$NEWLINE$and hasty like a Scotch jig, and full as fantastical; the$NEWLINE$wedding, mannerly modest as a measure, full of state and$NEWLINE$ancientry; and then comes repentance, and with his bad$NEWLINE$legs falls into the cinquepace faster and faster till he sink$NEWLINE$into his grave.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE$NEWLINE$But cousin, make sure he woos you properly and appropriately. If he is too insistent, tell him that romance is like a dance: it has its own rhythm and timing. Look, the three stages of romance are like three different dances. The wooing is like a Scottish jig: hot and fast and full of whimsy and illusion. The wedding is a like a dance you would do before the King: proper and decorous. Finally, you get to the part where you regret having gotten married in the first place. It is like the lively
cinquepace: it goes faster and faster until you eventually topple over and die.$NEWLINE$cinquepace$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Cousin, you apprehend passing shrewdly.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Niece, you are exceptionally perceptive.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I have a good eye, uncle. I can see a church by daylight.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I have a good eye, uncle. I can see what’s in broad daylight.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$The revelers are entering, brother. Make good room.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$The partygoers have arrived. Let’s give them room.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO,CLAUDIO, BENEDICK,BALTHASAR, DON JOHN,BORACHIO, MARGARET,URSULA and others, masked$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$DON JOHN$NEWLINE$BORACHIO$NEWLINE$MARGARET$NEWLINE$URSULA
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO,BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO,MARGARET, URSULA enter along with other partygoers. They’re all wearing masks.$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$DON JOHN$NEWLINE$BORACHIO$NEWLINE$MARGARET$NEWLINE$URSULA

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Lady, will you walk a bout with your friend?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$My lady, will you have a dance with me?

paragraphs.original: They begin to dance
paragraphs.translated: They begin to dance.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$So you walk softly, and look sweetly, and say nothing, I am$NEWLINE$yours for the walk, and especially when I walk away.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$As long as you move gracefully, look handsome, and say nothing, I’m yours for the dance. And I’ll even linger after I’ve gone.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$With me in your company?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Will I be with you then?

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$I may say so when I please.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$Perhaps, if I decide to let you.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$And when please you to say so?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$And when will that be?

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$When I like your favor, for God defend the lute should be$NEWLINE$like the case!
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$When I like the way you look, for God forbid your face be as ugly as your mask!

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$My visor is Philemon’s roof; within the house is Jove.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$My mask is like the roof of the poor
Philemon’s humble cottage; underneath the mask, I am as magnificent as the glorious god Jove.$NEWLINE$Philemon’s$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$Why, then, your visor should be thatched.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$Well, then, since Philemon’s roof was thatched with straw, your mask should have a beard.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Speak low if you speak love.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$If you wish to speak of love, speak more softly.

paragraphs.original: They move aside. BALTHASAR andMARGARET move forward$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$MARGARET
paragraphs.translated: They move aside. BALTHASAR andMARGARET move forward.$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$MARGARET

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Well, I would you did like me.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Well, I wish you liked me.

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$So would not I for your own sake, for I have many ill qualities.
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$I’m glad I don’t, for your sake. I have many awful qualities.

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Which is one?
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Tell me one.

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$I say my prayers aloud.
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$I say my prayers out loud.

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$I love you the better; the hearers may cry “Amen.”
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$That makes me love you even more. Everyone who hears you can shout, “Amen.”

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$God match me with a good dancer!
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$God give me a good dance partner!

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Amen.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Amen. That would be me.

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$And God keep him out of my sight when the dance is done!$NEWLINE$Answer, clerk.
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$And God take him away from me when we’re finished dancing! Go ahead—say “Amen.”

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$No more words. The clerk is answered.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$No more talking. I’ve got my answer.

paragraphs.original: They move aside. URSULA andANTONIO move forward.$NEWLINE$URSULA$NEWLINE$ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: They move aside. URSULA andANTONIO move forward.$NEWLINE$URSULA$NEWLINE$ANTONIO

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$I know you well enough. You are Signor Antonio.
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$I know who you are; you are Signior Antonio.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$At a word, I am not.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$No, really, I’m not.

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$I know you by the waggling of your head.
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$I can tell by the way you waggle your head.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$To tell you true, I counterfeit him.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Really, I’m only pretending to be him.

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$You could never do him so ill-well unless you were the very$NEWLINE$man. Here’s his dry hand up and down. You are he, you are$NEWLINE$he.
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$You could only imitate his imperfections so well if you were the man himself. Look, you’ve got his wrinkled hands. You are Antonio, you are he.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$At a word, I am not.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$In short, I’m not.

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$Come, come, do you think I do not know you by your$NEWLINE$excellent wit? Can virtue hide itself? Go to, mum, you are$NEWLINE$he. Graces will appear, and there’s an end.
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$Come on, do you think I can’t recognize you by your excellent wit? Can a good thing hide itself? Be quiet, you are Antonio. A man’s virtues will always show themselves, and that’s the end of that.

paragraphs.original: They move aside. BENEDICK andBEATRICE move forward.$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated: They move aside. BENEDICK andBEATRICE move forward.$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$BEATRICE

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Will you not tell me who told you so?
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Won’t you tell me who told you that?

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$No, you shall pardon me.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$No, you’ll have to excuse me.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Nor will you not tell me who you are?
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$And you won’t tell me who you are?

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Not now.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Not now.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$That I was disdainful and that I had my good wit out of The$NEWLINE$Hundred Merry Tales! Well this was Signor Benedick that$NEWLINE$said so.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Who said that I was disdainful, and that I got all my best lines out of a bad joke book?! Well, it must have been Signior Benedick.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$What’s he?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Who’s that?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I am sure you know him well enough.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I’m sure you know him.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Not I, believe me.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$No I don’t, believe me.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Did he never make you laugh?
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$What, he never made you laugh?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I pray you, what is he?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Please tell me, who is this man?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Why, he is the Prince’s jester, a very dull fool, only his gift$NEWLINE$is in devising impossible slanders. None but libertines$NEWLINE$delight in him, and the commendation is not in his wit but$NEWLINE$in his villainy, for he both pleases men and angers them,$NEWLINE$and then they laugh at him and beat him. I am sure he is in$NEWLINE$the fleet. I would he had boarded me.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Why, he’s the Prince’s fool, and a very dull fool at that. His only talent is his capacity to come up with unbelievable slanders. Only the most immoral people enjoy his company, and they like him not for his wit but his outrageousness. He manages to both please and anger people; they laugh at him and then beat him up. I’m sure he’s out there dancing. I could have sworn he trampled on me.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$When I know the gentleman, I’ll tell him what you say.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$When I meet this gentleman, I’ll tell him what you’ve said.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Do, do. He’ll but break a comparison or two on me, which,$NEWLINE$peradventure not marked or not laughed at, strikes him into$NEWLINE$melancholy, and then there’s a partridge wing saved, for the$NEWLINE$fool will eat no supper that night.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Oh, please do. He’ll say a few nasty things about me, and if nobody listens to him or laughs, he’ll be thrown into a funk. And that will save a partridge wing from being eaten, because he’ll be too miserable for dinner.

paragraphs.original: Music for the dance
paragraphs.translated: Music for the dance begins.

paragraphs.original: We must follow the leaders.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, we have to follow the leaders of the dance.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$In every good thing.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$In every good thing they do.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will leave them at the next$NEWLINE$turning.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$No, if they try to lead us to harm, I will leave the dance floor at the next song.

paragraphs.original: Dance, then exeunt all except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, and CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$DON JOHN$NEWLINE$BORACHIO$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO
paragraphs.translated: There is a dance. Everyone exits except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, andCLAUDIO.$NEWLINE$DON JOHN$NEWLINE$BORACHIO$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$(to BORACHIO) Sure my brother is amorous on Hero, and$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$hath withdrawn her father to break with him about it. The$NEWLINE$ladies follow her, and but one visor remains.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$(to BORACHIO) My brother just wooed Hero and now has taken her father inside to tell him his feelings. The ladies have followed Hero, but one masked man remains.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$And that is Claudio. I know him by his bearing.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$That’s Claudio. I can tell by the way he carries himself.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$(to CLAUDIO) Are not you Signor Benedick?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$(to CLAUDIO) Aren’t you Signior Benedick?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$You know me well. I am he.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$You know me too well. I am Benedick.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Signor, you are very near my brother in his love. He is$NEWLINE$enamored on Hero. I pray you, dissuade him from her. She$NEWLINE$is no equal for his birth. You may do the part of an honest$NEWLINE$man in it.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Sir, my brother is very fond of you. He is in love with Hero. Please make him change his mind. She doesn’t have the proper rank to marry the Prince. You would be doing a good service.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$How know you he loves her?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$How do you know he loves her?

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I heard him swear his affection.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I heard him swear he did.

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$So did I too, and he swore he would marry her tonight.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$I did too, and he also swore he would marry her tonight.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Come, let us to the banquet.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Come on, let’s get to the banquet.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt DON JOHN andBORACHIO$NEWLINE$DON JOHN$NEWLINE$BORACHIO
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN andBORACHIO exit.$NEWLINE$DON JOHN$NEWLINE$BORACHIO

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(unmasking)$NEWLINE$(unmasking)$NEWLINE$Thus answer I in the name of Benedick,$NEWLINE$But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio.$NEWLINE$'Tis certain so, the Prince woos for himself.$NEWLINE$Friendship is constant in all other things$NEWLINE$Save in the office and affairs of love.$NEWLINE$Therefore all hearts in love use their own tongues.$NEWLINE$Let every eye nogetiate for itself$NEWLINE$And trust no agent, for beauty is a witch$NEWLINE$Against whose charms faith melteth into blood.$NEWLINE$This is an accident of hourly proof,$NEWLINE$Which I mistrusted not. Farewell, therefore, Hero.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(taking off his mask)$NEWLINE$(taking off his mask)$NEWLINE$Though I said my name was Benedick, I heard this news with Claudio’s ears. Of course the Prince wants Hero for himself. Friendship is enduring except when love is involved. Therefore, all lovers should speak for themselves. They should look for themselves, without asking someone else to get involved in their affairs. Beauty is a witch whose spells can turn loyalty into passion. This happens a lot, but it didn’t occur to me that it would happen to me. Goodbye then, Hero.

paragraphs.original: Enter BENEDICK$NEWLINE$BENEDICK
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK enters.$NEWLINE$BENEDICK

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Count Claudio?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Claudio?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Yea, the same.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Yes, that’s me.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Come, will you go with me?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Will you come with me?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Whither?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Where?

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Even to the next willow, about your own business, county.$NEWLINE$What fashion will you wear the garland of? About your$NEWLINE$neck like an usurer’s chain? Or under your arm like a$NEWLINE$lieutenant’s scarf? You must wear it one way, for the Prince$NEWLINE$hath gat your Hero.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Right over to that
willow tree to see about your business. How do you want to wear your garland of willow leaves? Around your neck, like a moneylender’s gold chain, or under your arm, like a lieutenant’s sash? You have to wear it somehow, because the Prince has gotten your Hero.$NEWLINE$willow tree$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I wish him joy of her.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I hope he enjoys her.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Why, that’s spoken like an honest drover; so they sell$NEWLINE$bullocks. But did you think the Prince would have served$NEWLINE$you thus?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$You sound like a cattle dealer: that’s the way they sell bulls. But do you really think the Prince would treat you that way?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I pray you, leave me.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Please, leave me alone.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Ho, now you strike like the blind man. 'Twas the boy that$NEWLINE$stole your meat, and you’ll beat the post.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Look at you, thrashing about like a blind man. A boy robbed you, but you’ll beat up the post instead.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$If it will not be, I’ll leave you.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$If you won’t leave, then I’ll leave.$NEWLINE$I’ll

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Alas, poor hurt fowl, now will he creep into sedges. But that$NEWLINE$my Lady Beatrice should know me, and not know me! The$NEWLINE$Prince’s fool! Ha, it may be I go under that title because I am$NEWLINE$merry. Yea, but so I am apt to do myself wrong. I am not so$NEWLINE$reputed! It is the base, though bitter, disposition of Beatrice$NEWLINE$that puts the world into her person and so gives me out.$NEWLINE$Well, I’ll be revenged as I may.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Oh, the poor bird. Now he’ll hide himself in the bushes. But how strange that Beatrice should seem to know who I was and yet not know at the same time. “The Prince’s fool”! Maybe they call me that because I am cheerful. Yes, but I am insulting myself by thinking this way. I don’t have that kind of reputation! Beatrice’s mean, sarcastic nature makes her believe that the entire world shares her opinions; that’s why she describes me this way. Well, I’ll get my revenge.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO enters.$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Now, Signior, where’s the Count? Did you see him?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Now, sir, where is Claudio? Did you see him?

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Troth, my lord, I have played the part of Lady Fame. I$NEWLINE$found him here as melancholy as a lodge in a warren. I told$NEWLINE$him, and I think I told him true, that your Grace had got the$NEWLINE$goodwill of this young lady, and I offered him my company$NEWLINE$to a willow tree, either to make him a garland, as being$NEWLINE$forsaken, or to bind him up a rod, as being worthy to be$NEWLINE$whipped.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord, I played the part of a gossip and brought him the news. I found him here,
as sad as a rabbit in a burrow. I told him—and I think I was telling the truth—that you had won the lady’s heart. I offered to accompany him to the willow tree, where he could either make a garland—fit to be worn by an abandoned lover—or gather sticks into a bundle, ready for his beating.$NEWLINE$as sad as a rabbit in a burrow$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$To be whipped? What’s his fault?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Beating? Why, what did he do?
