paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$The flat transgression of a schoolboy who, being overjoyed$NEWLINE$with finding a birds' nest, shows it his companion, and he$NEWLINE$steals it.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$He was like a schoolboy who finds a bird’s nest and happily shows it to his friend, who then steals it from him.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Wilt thou make a trust a transgression? The transgression$NEWLINE$is in the stealer.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$What, is trusting a friend such a crime? The criminal is the one who stole the nest.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Yet it had not been amiss the rod had been made, and the$NEWLINE$garland too, for the garland he might have worn himself$NEWLINE$and the rod he might have bestowed on you, who, as I take$NEWLINE$it, have stolen his birds' nest.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$It might have been appropriate to make both the rod and the garland. He could have worn the garland himself and beaten you with the rod, since you—as I understand it—have stolen his bird’s nest.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I will but teach them to sing and restore them to the owner.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I only want to teach the baby birds to sing; then I will return the nest to its rightful owner.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$If their singing answer your saying, by my faith, you say$NEWLINE$honestly.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$We’ll wait and see; if the chicks follow your lead—if Hero is ready to love Claudio—then we’ll know you’re telling the truth.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you. The gentleman$NEWLINE$that danced with her told her she is much wronged by you.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Lady Beatrice is angry with you. The gentleman she danced with told her you insulted her.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$O, she misused me past the endurance of a block! An oak$NEWLINE$but with one green leaf on it would have answered her. My$NEWLINE$very visor began to assume life and scold with her. She told$NEWLINE$me, not thinking I had been myself, that I was the Prince’s$NEWLINE$jester, that I was duller than a great thaw, huddling jest$NEWLINE$upon jest with such impossible conveyance upon me that I$NEWLINE$stood like a man at a mark with a whole army shooting at$NEWLINE$me. She speaks poniards, and every word stabs. If her$NEWLINE$breath were as terrible as her terminations, there were no$NEWLINE$living near her; she would infect to the north star. I would$NEWLINE$not marry her, though she were endowed with all that$NEWLINE$Adam had left him before he transgressed. She would have$NEWLINE$made Hercules have turned spit, yea, and have cleft his club$NEWLINE$to make the fire, too. Come, talk not of her. You shall find$NEWLINE$her the infernal Ate in good apparel. I would to God some$NEWLINE$scholar would conjure her, for certainly, while she is here,$NEWLINE$a man may live as quiet in hell as in a sanctuary, and people$NEWLINE$sin upon purpose because they would go thither. So indeed$NEWLINE$all disquiet, horror and perturbation follows her.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Not even a block of wood could handle her abuses! An oak tree barely clinging to life would have revived itself to fight her. Even my mask seemed to come to life in order to argue with her. She told me—not realizing it was me—that I was the Prince’s jester and as dull as mud. She hurled mocking insults at me with such incredible speed that all I could do was stand there, paralyzed. She speaks daggers, and every word stabs. If her breath were as terrible as her words, she would kill every living thing from here to the furthest star. I wouldn’t marry her, even if she were as blessed as paradise. If she were married to the great hero Hercules, she would have humiliated him with chores around the house and ordered him to chop up his famous club for firewood. Please, don’t mention her. She’s as wicked as
Ate, just disguised in pretty clothes. I wish to God that some wise man would conjure her away, because as long as she lives on earth, our lives are filled with turmoil. It’s quieter in hell, where people, sinning on purpose, are eager to be sent just to get away from her. So chaos, horror, and sorrow follow her wherever she goes.$NEWLINE$Ate$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CLAUDIO,BEATRICE, HERO, andLEONATO$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$BEATRICE$NEWLINE$HERO$NEWLINE$LEONATO
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO, BEATRICE,HERO, and LEONATO enter.$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$BEATRICE$NEWLINE$HERO$NEWLINE$LEONATO

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Look, here she comes.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Look, here she comes.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Will your grace command me any service to the world’s$NEWLINE$end? I will go on the slightest errand now to the Antipodes$NEWLINE$that you can devise to send me on. I will fetch you a$NEWLINE$toothpicker now from the furthest inch of Asia, bring you$NEWLINE$the length of Prester John’s foot, fetch you a hair off the$NEWLINE$great Cham’s beard, do you any embassage to the Pygmies,$NEWLINE$rather than hold three words' conference with this harpy.$NEWLINE$You have no employment for me?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Your highness, could you send me on a mission to the ends of the earth? I’ll go to the Antipodes for any little errand you can think of. I’ll fetch you a toothpick from the
farthest reaches of Asia, or find out Prester John’s shoe size, or snatch a hair from Kublai Khan’s beard, or deliver any message you wish to relay to the Pygmies—anything rather than exchange three words with this awful, screeching woman. Isn’t there something you want from me?$NEWLINE$farthest reaches of Asia$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$None but to desire your good company.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Nothing but your good company.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$O God, sir, here’s a dish I love not. I cannot endure my$NEWLINE$Lady Tongue!
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Oh, God, sir, here comes a dish I hate. I can’t stand tongue.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$(to BEATRICE) Come, lady, come, you have lost the heart of$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Signior Benedick.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$(to BEATRICE) Lady, you have lost Signior Benedick’s heart.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Indeed, my lord, he lent it me awhile, and I gave him use for$NEWLINE$it, a double heart for his single one. Marry, once before he$NEWLINE$won it of me with false dice. Therefore your Grace may well$NEWLINE$say I have lost it.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$It’s true, my lord. He lent it to me once, and I paid him back with interest: a double heart for his single one. Really, he won it from me once before in a dishonest game of dice. So I suppose your grace can truly say that I have lost it.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$You have put him down, lady, you have put him down.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$You’ve humiliated him, lady: you’ve put him down.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$So I would not he should do me, my lord, lest I should prove$NEWLINE$the mother of fools. I have brought Count Claudio, whom$NEWLINE$you sent me to seek.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE$NEWLINE$And I hope that he won’t
put me down or I’m sure to have fools for children.I’ve brought Claudio, who you sent me to find.$NEWLINE$put me down$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Why, how now, Count, wherefore are you sad?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Why, what’s wrong, count? Why are you so sad?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Not sad, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I’m not sad, my lord.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$How then, sick?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$What then, sick?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Neither, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I’m neither, my lord.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$The Count is neither sad, nor sick, nor merry, nor well, but$NEWLINE$civil count, civil as an orange, and something of that jealous$NEWLINE$complexion.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$The count is neither sad nor sick nor cheerful nor well—he’s just civil, as Seville as an orange, with the same jealous-yellow complexion.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I' faith, lady, I think your blazon to be true, though, I’ll be$NEWLINE$sworn, if he be so, his conceit is false.—Here, Claudio, I$NEWLINE$have wooed in thy name, and fair Hero is won. I have broke$NEWLINE$with her father and his goodwill obtained. Name the day of$NEWLINE$marriage, and God give thee joy.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Truly, lady, I think your description is correct, though I swear he has no reason to look like that. Here, Claudio, I’ve wooed Hero for you, and she’s agreed to marry you. I’ve told her father, and he’s given his permission. Tell us when you wish to get married, and may God give you joy.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Count, take of me my daughter, and with her my fortunes.$NEWLINE$His grace hath made the match, and all grace say “Amen”$NEWLINE$to it.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Claudio, take my daughter, and, with her, take my fortunes. The Prince has made the match, and may God bless it.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Speak, Count, ’tis your cue.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Speak, Claudio, that’s your cue.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Silence is the perfectest herald of joy. I were but little happy$NEWLINE$if I could say how much.—Lady, as you are mine, I am$NEWLINE$yours. I give away myself for you and dote upon the$NEWLINE$exchange.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Complete joy makes one speechless; if I were only a little happy, then I could say exactly how much. Lady, you are mine and I am yours. For you, I give myself away and I’m ecstatic about the exchange.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Speak, cousin, or if you cannot, stop his mouth with a kiss$NEWLINE$and let not him speak neither.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Say something, cousin. Or, if you can’t say anything, stop his mouth with a kiss and don’t let him speak, either.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$In faith, lady, you have a merry heart.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Truly, lady, you have a merry heart.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Yea, my lord. I thank it, poor fool, it keeps on the windy side$NEWLINE$of care. My cousin tells him in his ear that he is in her heart.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord. I thank my heart—the poor fool—for it keeps away from seriousness. Look, my cousin is whispering to Claudio that she loves him.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And so she doth, cousin.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Why, you’re absolutely right, cousin.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Good Lord for alliance! Thus goes everyone to the world$NEWLINE$but I, and I am sunburnt. I may sit in a corner and cry,$NEWLINE$“Heigh-ho for a husband!”
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Thank the lord for alliances! So everyone goes off into the world except me, who stays in because I’m sunburned. I should sit in the corner and sing that song, “Heigh-Ho for a Husband!”

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Lady Beatrice, I’ll get you a husband.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I would rather have one of your father’s getting. Hath your$NEWLINE$grace ne'er a brother like you? Your father got excellent$NEWLINE$husbands, if a maid could come by them.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I’d rather get a husband from your father. Don’t you have any brothers like you? Your father’s sons would make excellent husbands, if only a girl could catch one for herself.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Will you have me, lady?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Will you take me, my lady?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$No, my lord, unless I might have another for working days.$NEWLINE$Your Grace is too costly to wear every day. But I beseech$NEWLINE$your Grace pardon me. I was born to speak all mirth and no$NEWLINE$matter.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$No, my lord, unless I could have another husband for the work week. You are too expensive to wear every day. But please, forgive me, your highness. I was born to speak cleverly, not seriously.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Your silence most offends me, and to be merry best$NEWLINE$becomes you, for out o' question you were born in a merry$NEWLINE$hour.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I’d be more offended if you were silent, for being lively and cheerful suits you best. Surely, you must have been born at a happy time.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$No, sure, my lord, my mother cried, but then there was a$NEWLINE$star danced, and under that was I born.—Cousins, God$NEWLINE$give you joy!
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Actually, my lord, my mother cried when she was giving birth to me. But then a star danced in the sky, and that’s the moment I was born.—Kinsmen, I’m off.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Niece, will you look to those things I told you of?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Niece, will you take care of those things I mentioned?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I cry you mercy, uncle.—By your Grace’s pardon.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Oh, yes, I’m sorry, uncle.—If you’ll excuse me, your grace.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$By my troth, a pleasant-spirited lady.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I swear, she’s a very good-natured lady.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$There’s little of the melancholy element in her, my lord. She$NEWLINE$is never sad but when she sleeps, and not ever sad then, for$NEWLINE$I have heard my daughter say she hath often dreamed of$NEWLINE$unhappiness and waked herself with laughing.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$There’s very little about her that’s gloomy, my lord. She’s only sad when she sleeps—and not even then. Hero told me that Beatrice has often had dreams about being unhappy, and managed to wake herself from them by laughing.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$She cannot endure to hear tell of a husband.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$She can’t stand to hear about getting a husband.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Oh, by no means. She mocks all her wooers out of suit.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$No, not at all. She mocks all her suitors so severely that they drop the suit.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$She were an excellent wife for Benedict.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$She would make a good wife for Benedick.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$O Lord, my lord, if they were but a week married, they$NEWLINE$would talk themselves mad.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Oh, Lord, if they were married, they’d drive themselves crazy within a week.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$County Claudio, when mean you to go to church?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Count Claudio, when do you plan to go to church and be married?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Tomorrow, my lord. Time goes on crutches till love have all$NEWLINE$his rites.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Tomorrow, my lord. Time will move as slowly as an old man until our love receives its proper ceremony.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Not till Monday, my dear son, which is hence a just$NEWLINE$sevennight, and a time too brief, too, to have all things$NEWLINE$answer my mind.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Wait till Monday, my dear son, which is only a week away. Even that is too short a time to plan things the way I would like.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$(to CLAUDIO) Come, you shake the head at so long a$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$breathing, but I warrant thee, Claudio, the time shall not go$NEWLINE$dully by us. I will in the interim undertake one of Hercules'$NEWLINE$labors, which is to bring Signor Benedick and the Lady$NEWLINE$Beatrice into a mountain of affection, th' one with th' other.$NEWLINE$I would fain have it a match, and I doubt not but to fashion$NEWLINE$it, if you three will but minister such assistance as I shall$NEWLINE$give you direction.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$(to CLAUDIO) Oh, don’t look so frustrated at having to wait so long. I promise you, Claudio, the time will go by quickly. While we’re waiting for the wedding, I’m going to take on an impossible task: to make Signior Benedick and the Lady Beatrice fall in love with each other. I aim to see them matched, and with all of your help, I’m sure we can make it happen.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$My lord, I am for you, though it cost me ten nights'$NEWLINE$watchings.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$My lord, I will help you, even if it means I have to stay awake for ten nights straight.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And I, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Me too, my lord.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$And you too, gentle Hero?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$And you, sweet Hero?

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$I will do any modest office, my lord, to help my cousin to a$NEWLINE$good husband.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$I’ll do any decent thing, my lord, to help my cousin get a good husband.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$And Benedick is not the unhopefulest husband that I know.$NEWLINE$Thus far can I praise him: he is of a noble strain, of approved$NEWLINE$valor, and confirmed honesty. I will teach you how to humor$NEWLINE$your cousin that she shall fall in love with Benedick.—And$NEWLINE$I, with your two helps, will so practice on Benedick$NEWLINE$that, in despite of his quick wit and his queasy stomach, he$NEWLINE$shall fall in love with Beatrice. If we can do this, Cupid is no$NEWLINE$longer an archer; his glory shall be ours, for we are the only$NEWLINE$love gods. Go in with me, and I will tell you my drift.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$And Benedick is not the worst husband I can think of. This much I can say about him: he is well-born, has proven his bravery in battle, and has established his good character. Hero, I’ll show you how to influence your cousin so she falls in love with Benedick. We men will trick Benedick so that, despite his quick wit and his queasiness about marriage, he will fall in love with her. If we can do this, then we will steal Cupid’s glory. We will be the supreme love gods! Come inside with me, and I will tell you my plan.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter DON JOHN andBORACHIO$NEWLINE$DON JOHN$NEWLINE$BORACHIO
paragraphs.translated: Enter DON JOHN andBORACHIO$NEWLINE$DON JOHN$NEWLINE$BORACHIO

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$It is so. The Count Claudio shall marry the daughter of$NEWLINE$Leonato.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$It’s arranged. The Count Claudio will marry Leonato’s daughter.

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Yea, my lord, but I can cross it.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord, but I can spoil it.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Any bar, any cross, any impediment will be med'cinable to$NEWLINE$me. I am sick in displeasure to him, and whatsoever comes$NEWLINE$athwart his affection ranges evenly with mine. How canst$NEWLINE$thou cross this marriage?
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Any obstacle or barrier to Claudio’s happiness will be like medicine to me. I hate him so much it makes me sick, and whoever can ruin his happiness will make me happy. How will you wreck this marriage?

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Not honestly, my lord, but so covertly that no dishonesty$NEWLINE$shall appear in me.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$I can only do it by lying, my lord, but I can do it so secretly that no one will suspect me.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Show me briefly how.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Quickly, tell me how.

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$I think I told your lordship a year since how much I am in$NEWLINE$the favor of Margaret, the waiting gentlewoman to Hero.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$I think it was a year ago that I told you how much Margaret, Hero’s servant woman, likes me.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I remember.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I remember.

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$I can, at any unseasonable instant of the night, appoint her$NEWLINE$to look out at her lady’s chamber window.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$I can arrange it so that at some indecent hour of the night, she looks out Hero’s bedroom window.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$What life is in that to be the death of this marriage?
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$How will that kill this marriage?

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$The poison of that lies in you to temper. Go you to the$NEWLINE$Prince your brother. Spare not to tell him that he hath$NEWLINE$wronged his honor in marrying the renowned Claudio,$NEWLINE$whose estimation do you mightily hold up, to a$NEWLINE$contaminated stale, such a one as Hero.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$That part is up to you. Go to the Prince, your brother, and tell him that he has done a terrible thing by matching the renowned Claudio—whom you greatly admire—with such a tainted whore as Hero.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$What proof shall I make of that?
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$What will be my evidence?

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Proof enough to misuse the Prince, to vex Claudio, to undo$NEWLINE$Hero, and kill Leonato. Look you for any other issue?
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Evidence enough to deceive the Prince, anger Claudio, ruin Hero, and kill Leonato. Is there anything else you wish?

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Only to despite them, I will endeavor anything.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$That’s all I want, and I’ll do anything to accomplish it.

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Go then, find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and the$NEWLINE$Count Claudio alone. Tell them that you know that Hero$NEWLINE$loves me. Intend a kind of zeal both to the Prince and$NEWLINE$Claudio, as in love of your brother’s honor, who hath made$NEWLINE$this match, and his friend’s reputation, who is thus like to$NEWLINE$be cozened with the semblance of a maid, that you have$NEWLINE$discovered thus. They will scarcely believe this without$NEWLINE$trial. Offer them instances, which shall bear no less$NEWLINE$likelihood than to see me at her chamber window, hear me$NEWLINE$call Margaret “Hero,” hear Margaret term me “Claudio,”$NEWLINE$and bring them to see this the very night before the$NEWLINE$intended wedding, for in the meantime I will so fashion the$NEWLINE$matter that Hero shall be absent, and there shall appear$NEWLINE$such seeming truth of Hero’s disloyalty that jealousy shall$NEWLINE$be called assurance and all the preparation overthrown.
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Find a time to speak with Don Pedro and Claudio alone. Tell them you know that Hero loves me. Pretend to be very concerned about both the Prince, who has compromised his honor by making the match, and Claudio, whose reputation will be ruined by this woman who’s pretending to be a virgin. Of course, they won’t believe you without proof. Tell them you’ve seen the two of us at Hero’s bedroom window, and then bring them to see for themselves on the night before the wedding. I’ll arrange it so that Hero is away for the night, so what they’ll actually see is Margaret and me at the window, calling each other “Hero” and
“Claudio.” It’ll be such blatant evidence of Hero’s disloyalty that Claudio’s jealousy will quickly turn to certainty, and the wedding will be instantly called off.$NEWLINE$“Claudio.”$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Grow this to what adverse issue it can, I will put it in$NEWLINE$practice. Be cunning in the working this, and thy fee is a$NEWLINE$thousand ducats.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Make the arrangements, and I’ll do it. Do this carefully, and I will reward you with a thousand gold coins.

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Be you constant in the accusation, and my cunning shall not$NEWLINE$shame me.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$If you make the accusation convincingly, then my cunning won’t fail me.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I will presently go learn their day of marriage.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I’ll go now to find out the date of the wedding.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter BENEDICK$NEWLINE$BENEDICK
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK enters.$NEWLINE$BENEDICK

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Boy!
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Boy!

paragraphs.original: Enter BOY$NEWLINE$BOY
paragraphs.translated: A BOY enters.$NEWLINE$BOY

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$Signior?
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$Yes Signior?

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$In my chamber window lies a book. Bring it hither to me in$NEWLINE$the orchard.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$In my bedroom window there is a book. Go get it and bring it to me here in the orchard.

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$I am here already, sir.
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$I’m already here, sir.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I know that, but I would have thee hence and here again.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I see that you are here, but I’d like you to go there and then come back again.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exit BOY$NEWLINE$BOY
paragraphs.translated: The BOY exits.$NEWLINE$BOY

paragraphs.original: I do much wonder that one man, seeing how much another$NEWLINE$man is a fool when he dedicates his behaviors to love, will,$NEWLINE$after he hath laughed at such shallow follies in others,$NEWLINE$become the argument of his own scorn by falling in love—$NEWLINE$and such a man is Claudio. I have known when there was no$NEWLINE$music with him but the drum and the fife, and now had he$NEWLINE$rather hear the tabor and the pipe. I have known when he$NEWLINE$would have walked ten mile afoot to see a good armor, and$NEWLINE$now will he lie ten nights awake carving the fashion of a new$NEWLINE$doublet. He was wont to speak plain and to the purpose,$NEWLINE$like an honest man and a soldier, and now is he turned$NEWLINE$orthography; his words are a very fantastical banquet, just$NEWLINE$so many strange dishes. May I be so converted and see with$NEWLINE$these eyes? I cannot tell; I think not.
paragraphs.translated: I’m amazed that a man, after watching romance turn another man into a fool and laughing at that man, can turn right around and become the thing he’s scorned. That’s the kind of man Claudio is. I knew him when he listened to nothing but the military drum and fife; now he would rather hear the sweet and refined music of the tabor and pipe. I knew him when he would’ve walked ten miles to see a well-crafted suit of armor; now he spends ten nights awake in his room designing himself a fancy new jacket. He used to speak plainly and to the point, like an honorable man and soldier; now his speech is elaborate and flowery. His words are like a miraculous banquet, full of strange new dishes. Will I be changed like that, and see the world through a lover’s eyes? I’m not sure, but I don’t think so.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: I will not be sworn but love may transform me to an oyster,$NEWLINE$but I’ll take my oath on it, till he have made an oyster of me,$NEWLINE$he shall never make me such a fool. One woman is fair, yet$NEWLINE$I am well; another is wise, yet I am well; another virtuous,$NEWLINE$yet I am well; but till all graces be in one woman, one$NEWLINE$woman shall not come in my grace. Rich she shall be, that’s$NEWLINE$certain; wise, or I’ll none; virtuous, or I’ll never cheapen$NEWLINE$her; fair, or I’ll ever look on her; mild, or come not near$NEWLINE$me; noble, or not I for an angel; of good discourse, an$NEWLINE$excellent musician, and her hair shall be of what color it$NEWLINE$please God. Ha! The Prince and Monsieur Love! I will hide$NEWLINE$me in the arbor.
paragraphs.translated: I can’t promise that love won’t transform me, but I can promise you this: until I truly fall in love, a woman will never make me act like such a fool. A beautiful woman comes along, but I’m unmoved. A wise woman turns up, but I’m unmoved. A virtuous woman appears, but I’m unmoved. I refuse to fall in love until all three qualities unite in a single woman. She must be rich, certainly, and smart, or I’ll have nothing to do with her. She has to be virtuous, or I’ll never bid on her; beautiful, or I won’t bother to look at her. Mild-mannered, or else she should stay away from me. Noble, or I won’t have her even if she’s an angel. She must be well spoken, an excellent musician, and her hair should be—well, I suppose the color doesn’t matter. Ha! Look, it’s the Prince and Mr. Love. I’ll hide in the arbor.

paragraphs.original: He hides
paragraphs.translated: He hides.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO,CLAUDIO, and LEONATO, andBALTHASAR with music$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and LEONATO enter. BALTHASAR enters with music.$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Come, shall we hear this music?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Well, should we hear some music?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Yea, my good lord. How still the evening is,$NEWLINE$As hushed on purpose to grace harmony!
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord. Listen to how quiet the evening is, as if it’s purposefully setting the stage for a song.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$(aside to CLAUDIO)$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$See you where Benedick hath hid himself?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only CLAUDIOcan hear) Do you see where Benedick is hiding?$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(aside to DON PEDRO)$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$O, very well, my lord. The music ended,$NEWLINE$We’ll fit the kid-fox with a pennyworth.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only DON PEDROcan hear) Yes, very well, my lord. Once the music has ended, we’ll give him more than he bargained for.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Come, Balthasar, we’ll hear that song again.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Come on, Balthasar, let’s hear that song again.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$O, good my lord, tax not so bad a voice$NEWLINE$To slander music anymore than once.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Oh, my good lord, don’t make me insult music again with my awful singing.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$It is the witness still of excellency$NEWLINE$To put a strange face on his own perfection.$NEWLINE$I pray thee, sing, and let me woo no more.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$You can tell an artist is excellent when he denies his own perfection. Please, sing for us; don’t make me woo you anymore!

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Because you talk of wooing, I will sing,$NEWLINE$Since many a wooer doth commence his suit$NEWLINE$To her he thinks not worthy, yet he woos,$NEWLINE$Yet will he swear he loves.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Since you put it that way, I’ll sing. You’re like a suitor who courts a woman insincerely, swearing that he loves her even though he really doesn’t find her worthy.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Nay, pray thee, come,$NEWLINE$Or, if thou wilt hold longer argument,$NEWLINE$Do it in notes.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Come on, please sing. If you’d like to continue this discussion, at least do so with music.

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Note this before my notes:$NEWLINE$There’s not a note of mine that’s worth the noting.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$Just know this before I begin: I can’t play a single note that’s worthy of note.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Why, these are very crotchets that he speaks!$NEWLINE$Note notes, forsooth, and nothing.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Listen to him speaking in quarter notes! Get on with your note-playing now.

paragraphs.original: Music plays
paragraphs.translated: Music plays.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$(aside) Now, divine air! Now is his soul ravished. Is it not$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$strange that sheeps' guts should hale souls out of men’s$NEWLINE$bodies? Well, a horn for my money, when all’s done.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$(to himself) That music must be divine, because their souls have been captivated. Isn’t it strange that strings made of sheep’s guts are capable of drawing men’s souls out of their bodies? Well, I’d rather listen to a plain old hunting horn than this music, when all is said and done.$NEWLINE$(to himself)$NEWLINE$I’d

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more,$NEWLINE$Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more$NEWLINE$Men were deceivers ever,$NEWLINE$Men were deceivers ever$NEWLINE$One foot in sea and one on shore,$NEWLINE$One foot in sea and one on shore$NEWLINE$To one thing constant never.$NEWLINE$To one thing constant never$NEWLINE$Then sigh not so, but let them go,$NEWLINE$Then sigh not so, but let them go$NEWLINE$And be you blithe and bonny,$NEWLINE$And be you blithe and bonny$NEWLINE$Converting all your sounds of woe$NEWLINE$Converting all your sounds of woe$NEWLINE$Into Hey, nonny nonny.$NEWLINE$Into Hey, nonny nonny$NEWLINE$Sing no more ditties, sing no mo$NEWLINE$Sing no more ditties, sing no mo$NEWLINE$Of dumps so dull and heavy.$NEWLINE$Of dumps so dull and heavy$NEWLINE$The fraud of men was ever so,$NEWLINE$The fraud of men was ever so$NEWLINE$Since summer first was leavy.$NEWLINE$Since summer first was leavy$NEWLINE$Then sigh not so, but let them go$NEWLINE$Then sigh not so, but let them go$NEWLINE$And be you blithe and bonny,$NEWLINE$And be you blithe and bonny$NEWLINE$Converting all your sounds of woe$NEWLINE$Converting all your sounds of woe$NEWLINE$Into Hey, nonny nonny.$NEWLINE$Into Hey, nonny nonny
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$Don’t cry anymore, ladies, don’t cry anymore$NEWLINE$Don’t cry anymore, ladies, don’t cry anymore$NEWLINE$Men have always been deceivers,$NEWLINE$Men have always been deceivers$NEWLINE$One foot on a ship and one on the shore,$NEWLINE$One foot on a ship and one on the shore$NEWLINE$Never devoted to anything.$NEWLINE$Never devoted to anything$NEWLINE$So don’t cry like that, just let them go$NEWLINE$So don’t cry like that, just let them go$NEWLINE$And be happy and carefree forever,$NEWLINE$And be happy and carefree forever$NEWLINE$Turning all your sad sounds around$NEWLINE$Turning all your sad sounds around$NEWLINE$When you sing “Hey, nonny nonny” instead.$NEWLINE$When you sing “Hey, nonny nonny” instead$NEWLINE$Don’t sing more sad songs$NEWLINE$Don’t sing more sad songs$NEWLINE$About being down in the dumps$NEWLINE$About being down in the dumps$NEWLINE$For men have been committing this kind of fraud$NEWLINE$For men have been committing this kind of fraud$NEWLINE$Ever since the first summer trees had leaves.$NEWLINE$Ever since the first summer trees had leaves$NEWLINE$So don’t cry like that, just let them go$NEWLINE$So don’t cry like that, just let them go$NEWLINE$And be happy and carefree forever,$NEWLINE$And be happy and carefree forever$NEWLINE$Turning all your sad sounds around$NEWLINE$Turning all your sad sounds around$NEWLINE$When you sing “Hey, nonny nonny” instead.$NEWLINE$When you sing “Hey, nonny nonny” instead

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$By my troth, a good song.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$That’s a good song.

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$And an ill singer, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$And a bad singer, my lord.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Ha, no, no, faith, thou sing’st well enough for a shift.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Ha! No, no, really, your voice is good enough in a pinch.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$(aside) An he had been a dog that should have howled thus,$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$they would have hanged him. And I pray God his bad voice$NEWLINE$bode no mischief. I had as lief have heard the night raven,$NEWLINE$come what plague could have come after it.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$(to himself) If a dog had howled like that, I would have hung it. I hope his horrible singing doesn’t have any ill effects. I would’ve rather listened to the night raven screech, even if the bird’s noise does give me the plague, as they say it will.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Yea, marry, dost thou hear, Balthasar? I pray thee, get us$NEWLINE$some excellent music, for tomorrow night we would have it$NEWLINE$at the Lady Hero’s chamber window
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Yes, do you hear me, Balthasar? Please, get some excellent music, because tomorrow we want to serenade Lady Hero at her bedroom window.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$The best I can, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$I’ll do the best I can, my lord.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Do so. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Please do. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Exit BALTHASAR$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR
paragraphs.translated: BALTHASAR exits.$NEWLINE$BALTHASAR

paragraphs.original: Come hither, Leonato. What was it you told me of today,$NEWLINE$that your niece Beatrice was in love with Signor Benedick?
paragraphs.translated: Come here, Leonato. What was it that you told me today—that your niece Beatrice was in love with Signior Benedick?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Oh, ay. (aside to DON PEDRO) Stalk on, stalk on; the fowl$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$sits.—I did never think that lady would have loved any$NEWLINE$man.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Oh yes. (speaking so that only DON PEDRO can hear) Go on, keep walking: our prey is in sight.—I never thought that woman would love any man.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$No, nor I neither, but most wonderful that she should so$NEWLINE$dote on Signor Benedick, whom she hath in all outward$NEWLINE$behaviors seemed ever to abhor.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I didn’t, either. But how wonderful that she should be so fond of Signior Benedick, whom she has always appeared to hate.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$(aside) Is ’t possible? Sits the wind in that corner?$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$(to himself) Is it possible? Is that the way the wind is blowing?$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$By my troth, my lord, I cannot tell what to think of it, but$NEWLINE$that she loves him with an enraged affection, it is past the$NEWLINE$infinite of thought.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Really, my lord, I don’t know what to make of it, but she loves him with such a passion that it’s past all understanding.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$May be she doth but counterfeit.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Maybe she’s just pretending.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Faith, like enough.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Yes, that’s quite likely.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$O God! Counterfeit? There was never counterfeit of$NEWLINE$passion came so near the life of passion as she discovers it.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Oh God! Pretending? No one has ever faked passion as skillfully as this, then.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Why, what effects of passion shows she?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Why, what symptoms of love does she exhibit?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(aside to LEONATO) Bait the hook well; this fish will bite.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only LEONATOcan hear) Bait the hook well; this fish is going to bite.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$What effects, my lord? She will sit you—you heard my$NEWLINE$daughter tell you how.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$What symptoms, my lord? She will have a seat—you heard my daughter tell you how.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$She did indeed.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Yes, she did tell us.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$How, how I pray you? You amaze me. I would have thought$NEWLINE$her spirit had been invincible against all assaults of affection.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Please, please tell me! This is amazing. I would have thought she was invincible against any assault of love.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I would have sworn it had, my lord, especially against$NEWLINE$Benedick.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I would have sworn that, too, my lord, especially against Benedick.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$(aside) I should think this a gull but that the white-bearded$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$fellow speaks it. Knavery cannot, sure, hide himself in such$NEWLINE$reverence.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$(to himself) I would take this as a joke if the old man weren’t saying it. Mischief surely can’t be hiding in such a respectable man.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(aside to DON PEDRO) He hath ta'en th' infection. Hold it up.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only DON PEDROcan hear) We’ve infected him! Keep it up.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Hath she made her affection known to Benedick?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Has she told Benedick how she feels?

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$No, and swears she never will. That’s her torment.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$No, and she swears she never will. That’s what’s driving her crazy.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$'Tis true indeed, so your daughter says. “Shall I,” says she,$NEWLINE$“that have so oft encountered him with scorn, write to him$NEWLINE$that I love him?”
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$It’s true, Hero says so. Beatrice asks, “Does it make any sense to write and tell him I love him when I have always treated him with scorn?”

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$This says she now when she is beginning to write to him, for$NEWLINE$she’ll be up twenty times a night, and there will she sit in her$NEWLINE$smock till she have writ a sheet of paper. My daughter tells$NEWLINE$us all.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$She says this as she begins to write the letter. She’ll be getting up twenty times in a night, sitting there in her slip until she’s written a page. My daughter told me everything.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a pretty jest$NEWLINE$your daughter told.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Now that you speak of paper, I remember a funny story of Hero’s.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Oh, when she had writ it and was reading it over, she found$NEWLINE$“Benedick” and “Beatrice” between the sheet?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Oh, you mean when Beatrice writes a letter and Hero sees that it has “Benedick” and “Beatrice” written all over it?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$That.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Yes, that’s the one.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$O, she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence, railed at$NEWLINE$herself that she should be so immodest to write to one that$NEWLINE$she knew would flout her. “I measure him,” says she, “by$NEWLINE$my own spirit, for I should flout him if he writ to me, yea,$NEWLINE$though I love him, I should.”
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Oh, she tears that letter into a thousand small pieces and berates herself for being so forward as to write a letter to a man she knows would mock her. “I compare him,” she says, “to myself, and I know that I would mock him if he wrote me such a letter. Yes, even though I love him, I would mock him.”

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Then down upon her knees she falls, weeps, sobs, beats her$NEWLINE$heart, tears her hair, prays, curses: “O sweet Benedick! God$NEWLINE$give me patience!”
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Then she falls down to her knees, weeps, sobs, beats her breast, tears her hair, prays, and curses: “Oh sweet Benedick! God give me patience!”

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$She doth indeed, my daughter says so, and the ecstasy hath$NEWLINE$so much overborne her that my daughter is sometime$NEWLINE$afeared$NEWLINE$she will do a desperate outrage to herself. It is very true.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$She did indeed, my daughter says so. She worries that Beatrice is so overwrought that she might do herself harm someday. It’s true.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$It were good that Benedick knew of it by some other, if she$NEWLINE$will not discover it.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$If she won’t tell Benedick, someone else should.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$To what end? He would make but a sport of it and torment$NEWLINE$the poor lady worse.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And what would that accomplish? He’ll just turn it into a joke and torment the poor woman even more.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$An he should, it were an alms to hang him. She’s an$NEWLINE$excellent sweet lady, and, out of all suspicion, she is$NEWLINE$virtuous.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$If he did that, it would be a charitable deed to hang him. She’s an excellent, sweet woman, and there’s no doubt that she is virtuous.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And she is exceeding wise.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And she is very smart.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$In every thing but in loving Benedick.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Except for the fact that she loves Benedick.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Oh, my lord, wisdom and blood combating in so tender a$NEWLINE$body, we have ten proofs to one that blood hath the victory.$NEWLINE$I am sorry for her, as I have just cause, being her uncle and$NEWLINE$her guardian.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Oh, my lord, when wisdom and passion are in one body, it’s ten to one that the passion will win. I am sorry for her, as I should be, since I am both her uncle and her guardian.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I would she had bestowed this dotage on me. I would have$NEWLINE$daffed all other respects and made her half myself. I pray$NEWLINE$you tell Benedick of it and hear what he will say.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I wish she were in love with me instead. I would have thrown away all other considerations and made her my wife. Please, tell Benedick about her feelings and see what he has to say.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Were it good, think you?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Is that a good idea, do you think?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Hero thinks surely she will die, for she says she will die if he$NEWLINE$love her not, and she will die ere she make her love known,$NEWLINE$and she will die if he woo her rather than she will bate one$NEWLINE$breath of her accustomed crossness.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Hero thinks Beatrice will surely die, for she says she’ll die if he doesn’t love her, and that she’ll die before she tells him, and she’ll die if he woos her and she’s made to hold back even one of her usual insults.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$She doth well. If she should make tender of her love, ’tis$NEWLINE$very possible he’ll scorn it, for the man, as you know all,$NEWLINE$hath a contemptible spirit.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$She’s probably right. If she offers him her love, it’s very possible that he’ll scorn it, since, as we all know, he tends to be contemptuous.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$He is a very proper man.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$He’s a very proper man.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$He hath indeed a good outward happiness.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Indeed, he is good-looking and carries himself well.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Before God, and in my mind, very wise.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And I swear to God he’s very smart.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$He doth indeed show some sparks that are like wit.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$He does indeed show sparks of something like wit.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And I take him to be valiant.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And I believe him to be brave.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$As Hector, I assure you, and in the managing of quarrels$NEWLINE$you may say he is wise, for either he avoids them with great$NEWLINE$discretion or undertakes them with a most Christian-like$NEWLINE$fear.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$As brave as
Hector, surely. And you could say that he is wise in managing fights, for he either avoids them discreetly or enters into them timidly.$NEWLINE$Hector$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$If he do fear God, he must necessarily keep peace. If he$NEWLINE$break the peace, he ought to enter into a quarrel with fear$NEWLINE$and trembling.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$If he fears God, he must necessarily keep the peace. If he breaks the peace, he ought to enter into a quarrel with fear and trembling.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$And so will he do, for the man doth fear God, howsoever it$NEWLINE$seems not in him by some large jests he will make. Well, I$NEWLINE$am sorry for your niece. Shall we go seek Benedick and tell$NEWLINE$him of her love?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$And he’ll do that, because he’s a God-fearing man, even though his joking makes it seem otherwise. Well, I’m sorry for your niece. Should we go find Benedick and tell him about Beatrice’s love?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Never tell him, my lord, let her wear it out with good$NEWLINE$counsel.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$No, don’t ever tell him, my lord. Let her get over it, with the help of good advice.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Nay, that’s impossible. She may wear her heart out first.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$No, that’s impossible. Her heart will break first.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Well, we will hear further of it by your daughter. Let it cool$NEWLINE$the while. I love Benedick well, and I could wish he would$NEWLINE$modestly examine himself to see how much he is unworthy$NEWLINE$so good a lady.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Well, we’ll hear more about it from your daughter. Let it sit for a while. I am very fond of Benedick, and I just wish he would take a look at himself and realize how unfairly he’s treating this good woman.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$My lord, will you walk? Dinner is ready.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$My lord, will you come with me? Dinner is ready.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(aside to DON PEDRO and LEONATO) If he do not dote on her$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$upon this, I will never trust my expectation.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only DON PEDROand LEONATO can hear) If he doesn’t fall in love with her now, I’ll never trust my intuition again.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$(aside to LEONATO) Let there be the same net spread for her,$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$and that must your daughter and her gentlewomen carry.$NEWLINE$The sport will be when they hold one an opinion of$NEWLINE$another’s dotage, and no such matter. That’s the scene that$NEWLINE$I would see, which will be merely a dumb show. Let us send$NEWLINE$her to call him in to dinner.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only LEONATOcan hear) The same trap must be set for her; that’s your daughter’s and servants' job. The real fun will be when they both believe the other to be in love, without any of it being true. I can’t wait to watch that drama—it’ll be a pantomime, since both of them will be totally speechless! Let’s send Beatrice to call Benedick in to dinner$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt DON PEDRO,CLAUDIO, and LEONATO$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$LEONATO
paragraphs.translated: Everyone except BENEDICK exits.$NEWLINE$BENEDICK

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$(coming forward) This can be no trick. The conference was$NEWLINE$(coming forward)$NEWLINE$sadly borne; they have the truth of this from Hero; they$NEWLINE$seem to pity the lady. It seems her affections have their full$NEWLINE$bent. Love me? Why, it must be requited! I hear how I am$NEWLINE$censured. They sy I will bear myself proudly if I perceive$NEWLINE$the love come from her. They say, too, that she will rather$NEWLINE$die than give any sign of affection. I did never think to$NEWLINE$marry. I must not seem proud. Happy are they that hear$NEWLINE$their detractions and can put them to mending. They say$NEWLINE$the lady is fair; ’tis a truth, I can bear them witness. And$NEWLINE$virtuous; ’tis so, I cannot reprove it. And wise, but for$NEWLINE$loving me; by my troth, it is no addition to her wit, nor no$NEWLINE$great argument of her folly, for I will be horribly in love$NEWLINE$with her! I may chance have some odd quirks and remnants$NEWLINE$of wit broken on me because I have railed so long against$NEWLINE$marriage, but doth not the appetite alter? A man loves the$NEWLINE$meat in his youth that he cannot endure in his age. Shall$NEWLINE$quips and sentences and these paper bullets of the$NEWLINE$brain awe a man from the career of his humor?$NEWLINE$No! The world must be peopled. When I said I would die a$NEWLINE$bachelor, I did not think I should live till I were married.$NEWLINE$Here comes Beatrice. By this day, she’s a fair lady. I do spy$NEWLINE$some marks of love in her.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$(coming forward) This can’t be a trick. They spoke with great seriousness, and they have Hero’s testimony. They seem to pity the lady. It seems her love is stretched to the limit. She loves me? Well, that love must be returned! I hear how I’m criticized. They say I’ll be smug if I find out she loves me. They also say she’d rather die than give any sign of her feelings. I never thought I’d marry. I can’t appear to be proud. People who discover their faults and can then change them are lucky indeed. They say the lady is beautiful; it’s true, I’ve seen it myself. And virtuous; that’s true, I can’t disprove that. And smart, except that she loves me. That may not be any proof of her intelligence, but I swear it won’t be evidence of her stupidity—for I’m going to be horribly in love with her! People might tease me here and there, since I attacked marriage for so long. But don’t tastes change? A man can love a dish when he is young that he hates when he turns old. Will quips and clever remarks and scathing written words keep a man from getting what his heart desires? No! The world needs to be populated. When I said that I’d die as a bachelor, I just meant that I didn’t think I’d live until I got married. Here comes Beatrice. By God! She’s a beautiful lady. I think I sense some signs of love in her.$NEWLINE$(coming forward)

paragraphs.original: Enter BEATRICE$NEWLINE$BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE enters.$NEWLINE$BEATRICE

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Against my will, I am sent to bid you come in to dinner.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Against my will, I’ve been told to bring you in to dinner.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Lovely Beatrice, I thank you for taking the pains to tell me that.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I took no more pains for those thanks than you take pains to$NEWLINE$thank me. If it had been painful, I would not have come.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I didn’t take any more pains bringing this message than you took pains in thanking me. If the job had been painful, I would not have come.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$You take pleasure then in the message?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$So you took pleasure in bringing me this message?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Yea, just so much as you may take upon a knife’s point and$NEWLINE$choke a daw withal. You have no stomach, Signior. Fare you$NEWLINE$well.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Yes, as much pleasure as one might take in choking a bird at knifepoint. You don’t want to eat, sir? Goodbye, then.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Ha! “Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to$NEWLINE$dinner.” There’s a double meaning in that. “I took no more$NEWLINE$pains for those thanks than you took pains to thank me.”$NEWLINE$That’s as much as to say, “Any pains that I take for you is as$NEWLINE$easy as thanks.” If I do not take pity of her, I am a villain.$NEWLINE$If I do not love her, I am a Jew. I will go get her picture.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Ha! “Against my will, I’ve been told to bring you in to dinner.” There’s a double meaning in that. “I didn’t take any more pains bringing this message than you took pains in thanking me.” That’s like saying, “Any thing I do for you is as easy as saying ‘thank you.’” If this doesn’t move me to take pity on her, I’m a horrible person. If I don’t love her, I’m completely
hard-hearted. I will go get her picture.$NEWLINE$hard-hearted$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter HERO,MARGARET, and URSULA$NEWLINE$HERO$NEWLINE$MARGARET$NEWLINE$URSULA
paragraphs.translated: HERO, MARGARET, andURSULA enter.$NEWLINE$HERO$NEWLINE$MARGARET$NEWLINE$URSULA

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$Good Margaret, run thee to the parlor.$NEWLINE$There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice$NEWLINE$Proposing with the Prince and Claudio.$NEWLINE$Whisper her ear and tell her I and Ursula$NEWLINE$Walk in the orchard, and our whole discourse$NEWLINE$Is all of her. Say that thou overheardst us,$NEWLINE$And bid her steal into the pleachèd bower$NEWLINE$Where honeysuckles ripened by the sun$NEWLINE$Forbid the sun to enter, like favorites$NEWLINE$Made proud by princes, that advance their pride$NEWLINE$Against that power that bred it. There will she hide her$NEWLINE$To listen our propose. This is thy office.$NEWLINE$Bear thee well in it and leave us alone.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$Margaret, run into the sitting room. You’ll find Beatrice there, talking to Claudio and the Prince. Whisper to her that Ursula and I are walking in the orchard and that we’re talking all about her. Tell her you heard us, and that she should sneak into the arbor where the crisscrossing branches overhead keep the honeysuckles out of the sun. (The same honeysuckles that were once ripened in the sun; they’re like courtiers who rise because the king favors them, then plot to overthrow his Majesty.) She can hide there and eavesdrop on our conversation. This is your job. Do it well, and then leave us.

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$I’ll make her come, I warrant you, presently.
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$I’ll make her come right away, I promise you.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come,$NEWLINE$As we do trace this alley up and down,$NEWLINE$Our talk must only be of Benedick.$NEWLINE$When I do name him, let it be thy part$NEWLINE$To praise him more than ever man did merit.$NEWLINE$My talk to thee must be how Benedick$NEWLINE$Is sick in love with Beatrice. Of this matter$NEWLINE$Is little Cupid’s crafty arrow made,$NEWLINE$That only wounds by hearsay.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$All right Ursula, as Beatrice arrives, we’ll be walking up and down this alley and speaking about nothing but Benedick. Whenever I mention him, praise him more than any man deserves. It’ll be my job to talk about how Benedick is sick with love for Beatrice. We’ll make our arrows the same way Cupid does: with gossip and rumor.

paragraphs.original: Enter BEATRICE, behind$NEWLINE$BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE enters, behind.$NEWLINE$BEATRICE

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Now begin,$NEWLINE$For look where Beatrice like a lapwing runs$NEWLINE$Close by the ground, to hear our conference.
paragraphs.translated: Let’s start. See, Beatrice has run over like a little bird, keeping close to the ground and trying to overhear us.

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$(aside to HERO)$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$The pleasant’st angling is to see the fish$NEWLINE$Cut with her golden oars the silver stream$NEWLINE$And greedily devour the treacherous bait.$NEWLINE$So angle we for Beatrice, who even now$NEWLINE$Is couchèd in the woodbine coverture.$NEWLINE$Fear you not my part of the dialogue.
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only HERO can hear) The best part of fishing is watching the fish cut through the water and greedily take the bait. Now we’re fishing for Beatrice, who’s hiding right now in the honeysuckle arbor. Don’t worry, I’ll do my part.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$(aside to URSULA)$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Then go we near her, that her ear lose nothing$NEWLINE$Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it.—$NEWLINE$(approaching the bower)$NEWLINE$(approaching the bower)$NEWLINE$No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful.$NEWLINE$I know her spirits are as coy and wild$NEWLINE$As haggards of the rock.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only URSULAcan hear) Then let’s get closer, so she can hear all the false, sweet bait we’re setting for her.— (approaching the bower) No, truly, Ursula, she’s too scornful. She’s as devious and fierce as the wild hawks on the rocks.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)$NEWLINE$(approaching the bower)

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$But are you sure$NEWLINE$That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$But are you sure that Benedick loves Beatrice that much?

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$So says the Prince and my new-trothèd lord.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$That’s what the Prince and my fiancé say.

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$And did they ask you to tell Beatrice about this, madam?

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$They did entreat me to acquaint her of it,$NEWLINE$But I persuaded them, if they loved Benedick,$NEWLINE$To wish him wrestle with affection$NEWLINE$And never to let Beatrice know of it.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$They did want me to tell her, but I persuaded them that, if they truly loved Benedick, they would try to get him to battle his emotions and keep Beatrice in the dark.

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman$NEWLINE$Deserve as full as fortunate a bed$NEWLINE$As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$Why did you do that? Doesn’t Benedick deserve as much luck with a mate as he would have with Beatrice?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$O god of love! I know he doth deserve$NEWLINE$As much as may be yielded to a man,$NEWLINE$But Nature never framed a woman’s heart$NEWLINE$Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice.$NEWLINE$Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes,$NEWLINE$Misprizing what they look on, and her wit$NEWLINE$Values itself so highly that to her$NEWLINE$All matter else seems weak. She cannot love$NEWLINE$Nor take no shape nor project of affection$NEWLINE$She is so self-endeared.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$By the god of love, I know that he deserves all that a man might possess. But Nature never made a woman’s heart as proud and tough as Beatrice’s. There is scorn and disdain in her eyes, and those sparkling eyes despise everything they look upon. She values her wit more highly than anything else, which looks weak by comparison. She’s so in love with herself, she’s incapable of loving anyone else. She can’t even imagine what “love” is.

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$Sure, I think so,$NEWLINE$And therefore certainly it were not good$NEWLINE$She knew his love, lest she make sport at it.
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$Yes, you’re right. It would be bad if she knew about Benedick’s love and teased him about it.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$Why, you speak truth. I never yet saw man,$NEWLINE$How wise, how noble, young, how rarely featured$NEWLINE$But she would spell him backward. If fair-faced,$NEWLINE$She would swear the gentleman should be her sister;$NEWLINE$If black, why, Nature, drawing of an antic,$NEWLINE$Made a foul blot; if tall, a lance ill-headed;$NEWLINE$If low, an agate very vilely cut;$NEWLINE$If speaking, why, a vane blown with all winds;$NEWLINE$If silent, why, a block moved with none.$NEWLINE$So turns she every man the wrong side out$NEWLINE$And never gives to truth and virtue that$NEWLINE$Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$It’s true. Whenever she meets a man—no matter how wise, noble, young, handsome—she rearranges all his good qualities so they end up looking bad. If he has a fair complexion, she’ll say the pretty man should be her sister, not her husband. If he’s dark-skinned, Nature must have spilled some ink while drawing his foolish face. If he’s tall, she’ll say he’s a spear topped by an odd head; if he’s short, she says he looks like a badly carved miniature. If he’s talkative, he’s a weathervane, moving in all directions at once; if he’s silent, he’s a block that can’t be moved at all. And so she turns men inside out and never acknowledges the integrity and merit that a man has.

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$It’s true, her nitpicking is hardly admirable.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$No, not to be so odd and from all fashions$NEWLINE$As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable.$NEWLINE$But who dare tell her so? If I should speak,$NEWLINE$She would mock me into air. O, she would laugh me$NEWLINE$Out of myself, press me to death with wit.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$No, it certainly is not admirable to be so perverse and eccentric. But who would dare tell her? If I said something, she’d mock me so mercilessly that I’d probably disintegrate into air. She’d laugh me right out of my body and kill me with her wit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Therefore let Benedick, like covered fire,$NEWLINE$Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly.$NEWLINE$It were a better death than die with mocks,$NEWLINE$Which is as bad as die with tickling.
paragraphs.translated: So Benedick should conceal his emotions. Like a fire that gets covered up, Benedick should smother his love and waste away. It would be better to die that way than to die from being mocked, which is as bad as being killed by tickling.

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$Yet tell her of it. Hear what she will say.
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$But you should tell her about this, and hear what she has to say.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$No, rather I will go to Benedick$NEWLINE$And counsel him to fight against his passion;$NEWLINE$And truly I’ll devise some honest slanders$NEWLINE$To stain my cousin with. One doth not know$NEWLINE$How much an ill word may empoison liking.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$No, instead I’ll go to Benedick and advise him to fight his emotions. I’ll make up some awful things about my cousin and ruin her reputation. You don’t know how quickly affection can be killed with a single nasty word.

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$O, do not do your cousin such a wrong!$NEWLINE$She cannot be so much without true judgment,$NEWLINE$Having so swift and excellent a wit$NEWLINE$As she is prized to have, as to refuse$NEWLINE$So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$Oh, don’t injure your cousin like that! With the quick, intelligent wit she’s rumored to have, she can’t really be such a bad judge of character that she’d refuse a man as exceptional as Signior Benedick.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$He is the only man of Italy,$NEWLINE$Always excepted my dear Claudio.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$He’s the only worthy man in Italy, aside from my dear Claudio.

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$I pray you, be not angry with me, madam,$NEWLINE$Speaking my fancy. Signor Benedick,$NEWLINE$For shape, for bearing, argument and valor,$NEWLINE$Goes foremost in report through Italy.
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$Don’t be angry with me for speaking my mind, but throughout Italy, Benedick is considered the best man in looks, bearing, intelligence, and bravery.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$Indeed, he hath an excellent good name.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$True, he has an excellent reputation.

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$His excellence did earn it, ere he had it.$NEWLINE$When are you married, madam?
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$And he deserves it, having been excellent before he had a reputation for it. When are you getting married, madam?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$Why, every day, tomorrow. Come, go in.$NEWLINE$I’ll show thee some attires, and have thy counsel$NEWLINE$Which is the best to furnish me tomorrow.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$Tomorrow, and then every day after that. Come on, let’s go inside. I want to show you some clothing, so you can tell me what I should wear tomorrow.

paragraphs.original: They move aside from the bower
paragraphs.translated: They move away from the bower.

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$(aside to HERO)$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$She’s limed, I warrant you. We have caught her, madam.
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only HERO can hear) We caught her in our trap, madam, I’m sure of it.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$(aside to URSULA)$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$If it proves so, then loving goes by haps;$NEWLINE$Some Cupid kills with arrows, some with traps.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only URSULAcan hear) If so, then you never know where love will come from. Cupid gets some lovers with arrows, but some he lays traps for!$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt HERO andURSULA$NEWLINE$HERO$NEWLINE$URSULA
paragraphs.translated: Everyone but BEATRICE exits.$NEWLINE$BEATRICE

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$(coming forward)$NEWLINE$(coming forward)$NEWLINE$What fire is in mine ears? Can this be true?$NEWLINE$Stand I condemned for pride and scorn so much?$NEWLINE$Contempt, farewell, and maiden pride, adieu!$NEWLINE$No glory lives behind the back of such.$NEWLINE$And Benedick, love on; I will requite thee,$NEWLINE$Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand.$NEWLINE$If thou dost love, my kindness shall incite thee$NEWLINE$To bind our loves up in a holy band.$NEWLINE$For others say thou dost deserve, and I$NEWLINE$Believe it better than reportingly.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$(coming forward) I’m burning up with shame! Can this be true? Do people criticize me this much for being proud and scornful? Then I’ll say goodbye to my contempt and my pride in being unmarried! No good is spoken of such a person as me behind her back. Benedick, keep on loving me and I will return your love, like a wild hawk being tamed by her handler. I’ll be kind to you from now on, and if you really do love me, that kindness will encourage you to seal our love with a wedding band. People say that you deserve my love, and I believe it—not just because they’ve said so.$NEWLINE$(coming forward)

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO BENEDICK, and LEONATO$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$LEONATO
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO,BENEDICK, and LEONATO enter.$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$LEONATO

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and then go$NEWLINE$I toward Aragon.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I’ll stay in Messina until you’re married, and then I’ll go to Aragon.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I’ll bring you thither, my lord, if you’ll vouchsafe me.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I’ll go with you, my lord, if you’ll allow me.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss of your$NEWLINE$marriage as to show a child his new coat and forbid him to$NEWLINE$wear it. I will only be bold with Benedick for his company,$NEWLINE$for from the crown of his head to the sole of his foot he is all$NEWLINE$mirth. He hath twice or thrice cut Cupid’s bow-string, and$NEWLINE$the little hangman dare not shoot at him. He hath a heart as$NEWLINE$sound as a bell, and his tongue is the clapper, for what his$NEWLINE$heart thinks, his tongue speaks.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$No, taking you away from your new marriage would be like showing a child a new coat and then not letting him wear it. I’ll ask only Benedick to come with me, for from the top of his head to the soles of his feet he’s a joker. He’s evaded love once or twice, and since then Cupid doesn’t dare to shoot at him. Benedick’s heart is like a bell, with his tongue as the clapper: everything his heart thinks, his tongue speaks.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Gallants, I am not as I have been.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Gentleman, I am not the same man I was before.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$So say I. Methinks you are sadder.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I agree. I think you seem more serious.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I hope he be in love.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I hope he’s in love.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Hang him, truant! There’s no true drop of blood in him to$NEWLINE$be truly touched with love. If he be sad, he wants money.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Come off it, man! There isn’t a single drop of sincerity in him that could be touched with love. If he looks serious, he must need money.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I have the toothache.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I have a
toothache.$NEWLINE$toothache$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Draw it.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Draw it.$NEWLINE$Draw it.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Hang it!
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Hang it!$NEWLINE$Hang it!$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$You must hang it first, and draw it afterwards.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$You have to hang it first. Then you can
draw it.$NEWLINE$draw$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$What, sigh for the toothache?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$What, are you moaning on about your toothache?

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Where is but a humor or a worm.
paragraphs.translated:
LEONATO$NEWLINE$It could only have been caused by some humor or
worm.$NEWLINE$worm$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Well, everyone can master a grief but he that has it.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Well, everyone knows how to overcome an injury except the one who actually has one.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Yet say I, he is in love.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I repeat, he’s in love.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$There is no appearance of fancy in him, unless it be a fancy$NEWLINE$that he hath to strange disguises, as to be a Dutchman$NEWLINE$today, a Frenchman tomorrow, or in the shape of two$NEWLINE$countries at once, as a German from the waist downward,$NEWLINE$all slops, and a Spaniard from the hip upward, no doublet.$NEWLINE$Unless he have a fancy to this foolery, as it appears he hath,$NEWLINE$he is no fool for fancy, as you would have it appear he is.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$No, there’s no love in him, unless you mean his love for strange costumes.
