He’s a Dutchman today, a Frenchman tomorrow, and sometimes wears the clothing of two countries at once: a German from the waist down, with his baggy pants, and a Spaniard from the hips up, with a cloak and no jacket. Unless you’re talking about his love for this kind of foolishness—which, judging from his appearance, he has—he is no fool for love, as you pretend.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$If he be not in love with some woman, there is no believing$NEWLINE$old signs. He brushes his hat o' mornings. What should$NEWLINE$that bode?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$If he’s not in love with a woman, then you can’t trust the usual symptoms. He brushes his hat in the mornings. What do you think that means?

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Hath any man seen him at the barber’s?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Has any man seen him at the barber’s?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$No, but the barber’s man hath been seen with him, and the$NEWLINE$old ornament of his cheek hath already stuffed tennis balls.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$No, but the barber’s assistant has been seen with him. The beard that used to decorate Benedick’s cheeks has been shaved off and is now stuffing
tennis balls.$NEWLINE$tennis balls$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Indeed, he looks younger than he did, by the loss of a beard.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Getting rid of the beard definitely makes him look younger.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Nay, he rubs himself with civet. Can you smell him out by$NEWLINE$that?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$And he’s rubbed himself with perfume. Can you smell out his secret now?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$That’s as much as to say, the sweet youth’s in love.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$That’s as good as proof that the sweet young man’s in love.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$The greatest note of it is his melancholy.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$The biggest clue is his seriousness.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And when was he wont to wash his face?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And when has he ever been known to wash his face?

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Yea, or to paint himself? For the which I hear what they say$NEWLINE$of him.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Yes, or to wear cosmetics? I hear what they say about him for doing that.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Nay, but his jesting spirit, which is now crept into a lute$NEWLINE$string and now governed by stops—
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Indeed, his mocking spirit has now crawled into a
lute, and he can be played like an instrument—$NEWLINE$lute$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Indeed, that tells a heavy tale for him. Conclude, conclude,$NEWLINE$he is in love.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Truly, it all adds up to a serious story for Benedick. A conclusion, a conclusion: he is in love.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Nay, but I know who loves him.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Oh, and I know who loves him.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$That would I know too. I warrant, one that knows him not.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I bet I know, too: someone who clearly doesn’t know him at all.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Yes, and his ill conditions, and, in despite of all, dies for$NEWLINE$him.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$No, she does know him, and she also knows all his bad qualities—and in spite of all this, she still dies for him.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$She shall be buried with her face upwards.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$She’ll be buried with her face upwards, then.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Yet is this no charm for the toothache.—Old Signior, walk$NEWLINE$aside with me. I have studied eight or nine wise words to$NEWLINE$speak to you, which these hobbyhorses must not hear.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$This chatter is no cure for my toothache. (to LEONATO) Old sir, please walk with me a bit. I have eight or nine well-considered words to say to you, and I don’t want these fools to hear.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt BENEDICK andLEONATO$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$LEONATO
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK and LEONATO exit.$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$LEONATO

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$For my life, to break with him about Beatrice!
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I bet my life he’s gone to speak with Leonato about Beatrice!

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$'Tis even so. Hero and Margaret have by this played their$NEWLINE$parts with Beatrice, and then the two bears will not bite one$NEWLINE$another when they meet.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$It must be. By now, Hero and Margaret have done their part with Beatrice. The two bears won’t bite each other the next time they meet.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON JOHN$NEWLINE$DON JOHN
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN enters.$NEWLINE$DON JOHN

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$My lord and brother, God save you.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$My lord and brother, God save you.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Good e'en, brother.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Good evening, brother.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$If your leisure served, I would speak with you.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$If you don’t mind, I’d like to speak with you.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$In private?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$In private?

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$If it please you. Yet Count Claudio may hear, for what I$NEWLINE$would speak of concerns him.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$If you wish. But Count Claudio can stay, for what I’m about to say concerns him.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$What’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$What’s the matter?

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$(to CLAUDIO) Means your lordship to be married tomorrow?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$(to CLAUDIO) Do you plan on getting married tomorrow?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$You know he does.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$You know that he does.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I know not that, when he knows what I know.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I don’t know that, once he knows what I know.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$If there’s any reason we shouldn’t get married, I urge you to tell me.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$You may think I love you not. Let that appear hereafter, and$NEWLINE$aim better at me by that I now will manifest. For my$NEWLINE$brother, I think he holds you well, and in dearness of heart$NEWLINE$hath holp to effect your ensuing marriage—surely suit ill$NEWLINE$spent and labor ill bestowed.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$You may think that I don’t love you. I hope that, after I tell you my news, you will think better of me. My brother thinks highly of you, and because of his affection, has helped arrange your marriage—but that was definitely a waste of his time and energy.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Why, what’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Why, what’s the matter?

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I came hither to tell you; and, circumstances shortened, for$NEWLINE$she has been too long a-talking of, the lady is disloyal.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I came here to tell you—I’ll make this short, since she’s already been talked about for too long—the lady is unfaithful.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Who, Hero?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Who, Hero?

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Even she: Leonato’s Hero, your Hero, every man’s Hero.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$That’s the one: Leonato’s Hero, your Hero, every man’s Hero.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Disloyal?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Unfaithful?

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$The word is too good to paint out her wickedness. I could$NEWLINE$say she were worse. Think you of a worse title, and I will fit$NEWLINE$her to it. Wonder not till further warrant. Go but with me$NEWLINE$tonight, you shall see her chamber window entered, even$NEWLINE$the night before her wedding day. If you love her then,$NEWLINE$tomorrow wed her. But it would better fit your honor to$NEWLINE$change your mind.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$The word is too good to represent her wickedness. She is worse than wicked. If you can think of a more awful title, I’ll call her that. But don’t keep wondering without more proof. Come with me tonight, and you’ll see a man enter her bedroom chamber—even tonight, the night before her wedding. If you still love her after that, then marry her tomorrow. But you would be more honorable if you changed your mind.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(to DON PEDRO) May this be so?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(to DON PEDRO) Is this possible?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I will not think it.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I won’t consider it.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$If you dare not trust that you see, confess not that you know.$NEWLINE$If you will follow me, I will show you enough, and when$NEWLINE$you have seen more and heard more, proceed accordingly.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$If you won’t risk coming to see her tonight, then don’t claim to know what she’s like. If you follow me, I’ll give you all the proof you need. Once you have seen more and heard more, then you can decide what to do.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$If I see anything tonight why I should not marry her,$NEWLINE$tomorrow in the congregation, where I should wed, there$NEWLINE$will I shame her.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$If I see anything tonight that convinces me not to marry her, I’ll shame her tomorrow in the very congregation where I would have married her.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$And as I wooed for thee to obtain her, I will join with thee$NEWLINE$to disgrace her.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$And since I wooed her in your name, I’ll join you in disgracing her.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I will disparage her no farther till you are my witnesses.$NEWLINE$Bear it coldly but till midnight and let the issue show itself.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$I won’t say anything else about her until you two see things for yourselves. Remain calm until midnight, and then you’ll see what the trouble is.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$O day untowardly turned!
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Oh, this day has turned into a disaster!

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$O mischief strangely thwarting!
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Oh, mischief has ruined our plans!

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$O plague right well prevented! So will you say when you$NEWLINE$have seen the sequel.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Oh, a plague has been prevented, thank God! That’s what you’ll say once you’ve seen part two.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter DOGBERRY andVERGES with the Watch$NEWLINE$DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$VERGES
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY and VERGES with several of the Prince’s
WATCHMEN enter.$NEWLINE$DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$VERGES$NEWLINE$WATCHMEN$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Are you good men and true?
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Are you all good and honest men?

paragraphs.original: VERGES$NEWLINE$Yea, or else it were pity but they should suffer salvation,$NEWLINE$body and soul.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES$NEWLINE$Yes they are, otherwise it would be proper for them to suffer
salvation, body and soul.$NEWLINE$salvation$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Nay, that were a punishment too good for them, if they$NEWLINE$should have any allegiance in them, being chosen for the$NEWLINE$Prince’s watch.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$If they had any
allegiance when they were chosen for the Prince’s watch, a punishment like that would be too good for them.$NEWLINE$allegiance$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: VERGES$NEWLINE$Well, give them their charge, neighbor Dogberry.
paragraphs.translated: VERGES$NEWLINE$Well, give them their assignment, Sir Dogberry.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$First, who think you the most desartless man to be constable?
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$First, which man do you think is most
desertless to be leader of the watch?$NEWLINE$desertless$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FIRST WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Hugh Otecake, sir, or George Seacole, for they can write$NEWLINE$and read.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Either Hugh Otecake, sir, or else George Seacole, because both of them can read and write.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Come hither, neighbor Seacole. God hath blessed you with$NEWLINE$a good name. To be a well-favored man is the gift of fortune,$NEWLINE$but to write and read comes by nature.
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Come here, Sir Seacole. God has blessed you with a good name. To be good-looking is a matter of luck, but to read and write is a natural gift.

paragraphs.original: SEACOLE$NEWLINE$Both which, Master Constable—
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Both of which, master constable—

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$You have. I knew it would be your answer. Well, for your$NEWLINE$favor, sir, why, give God thanks, and make no boast of it,$NEWLINE$and for your writing and reading, let that appear when there$NEWLINE$is no need of such vanity. You are thought here to be the$NEWLINE$most senseless and fit man for the constable of the watch;$NEWLINE$therefore bear you the lantern. This is your charge:
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$You have. I knew that would be your answer. Well, for your good looks, sir, thank God and don’t boast about it. As for your reading and writing, use those skills when you can’t use your looks. You’re thought to be the most
senseless and fit man here, so you will carry the lantern and be constable. This is your assignment:$NEWLINE$senseless$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: you shall comprehend all vagrom men; you are to bid any$NEWLINE$man stand, in the Prince’s name.
paragraphs.translated:
you will
comprehend any vagrant men you see. You are to order all men to stop, in the Prince’s name.$NEWLINE$comprehend$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SECOND WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$How if he will not stand?
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$And what if he won’t stop?

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Why, then, take no note of him, but let him go and$NEWLINE$presently call the rest of the watch together and thank God$NEWLINE$you are rid of a knave.
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Well then, don’t bother with him and let him go. Then immediately call the rest of the watch together and thank God that you’ve gotten rid of such a criminal.

paragraphs.original: VERGES$NEWLINE$If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none of the$NEWLINE$Prince’s subjects.
paragraphs.translated: VERGES$NEWLINE$If he won’t stop when he’s told to, then he isn’t one of the Prince’s subjects.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$True, and they are to meddle with none but the Prince’s$NEWLINE$subjects.—You shall also make no noise in the streets; for,$NEWLINE$for the watch to babble and to talk is most tolerable and not$NEWLINE$to be endured.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$True, and you aren’t supposed to meddle with anyone but the Prince’s subjects. You will also stay quiet in the streets, for a babbling watch is most
tolerable and will not be endured.$NEWLINE$tolerable$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$We will rather sleep than talk. We know what belongs to a$NEWLINE$watch.
paragraphs.translated: WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$We’ll sleep instead of talk. We know what’s appropriate for a watch.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Why, you speak like an ancient and most quiet watchman,$NEWLINE$for I cannot see how sleeping should offend. Only have a$NEWLINE$care that your bills be not stolen. Well, you are to call at all$NEWLINE$the alehouses and bid those that are drunk get them to bed.
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Why, you speak like an experienced and quiet watchman. Sleeping on the watch shouldn’t be a problem; just make sure that your weapons don’t get stolen. Also, you’re supposed to visit all the bars and tell anyone who’s drunk to go home and go to bed.

paragraphs.original: WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$How if they will not?
paragraphs.translated: WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$And what if they won’t go?

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Why, then, let them alone till they are sober. If they make$NEWLINE$you not then the better answer, you may say they are not the$NEWLINE$men you took them for.
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Well then, leave them alone until they’re sober. If even then they don’t answer to your satisfaction, you can say that they’re not the men you thought they were.

paragraphs.original: WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Well, sir.
paragraphs.translated: WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Very good, sir.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$If you meet a thief, you may suspect him, by virtue of your$NEWLINE$office, to be no true man, and for such kind of men, the less$NEWLINE$you meddle or make with them, why the more is for your$NEWLINE$honesty.
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$If you meet a thief, you can expect him to be dishonest. The less you have to do with that kind of man, the more honest you will be.

paragraphs.original: WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$If we know him to be a thief, shall we not lay hands on him?
paragraphs.translated: WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$So if we know that a man is a thief, should we try to arrest him?

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Truly, by your office you may, but I think they that touch$NEWLINE$pitch will be defiled. The most peaceable way for you, if$NEWLINE$you$NEWLINE$do take a thief, is to let him show himself what he is and steal$NEWLINE$out of your company.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Your position permits you to, but I think that those who stick their hands in
pitch get their hands dirty. If you encounter a thief, I think the most peaceable thing to do is to let him be himself—and steal away.$NEWLINE$pitch$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: VERGES$NEWLINE$You have been always called a merciful man, partner.
paragraphs.translated: VERGES$NEWLINE$You have always been known as a merciful man, partner.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Truly, I would not hang a dog by my will, much more a man$NEWLINE$who hath any honesty in him.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Truly, I wouldn’t even hang a dog, much
more a man who has any honesty in him.$NEWLINE$more$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: VERGES$NEWLINE$(to the Watch) If you hear a child cry in the night, you must$NEWLINE$(to the Watch)$NEWLINE$call to the nurse and bid her still it.
paragraphs.translated: VERGES$NEWLINE$(to the watchmen) If you hear a child crying in the night, you should call the nurse and tell her to quiet the child.$NEWLINE$(to the watchmen)

paragraphs.original: WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$How if the nurse be asleep and will not hear us?
paragraphs.translated: WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$What if the nurse is asleep and doesn’t hear us?

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Why then, depart in peace and let the child wake her with$NEWLINE$crying, for the ewe that will not hear her lamb when it baas$NEWLINE$will never answer a calf when he bleats.
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Well then, leave quietly, and let the child’s crying wake up the nurse. The ewe that doesn’t go to her lamb when it baas will never tend to another animal’s child.$NEWLINE$baas

paragraphs.original: VERGES$NEWLINE$'Tis very true.
paragraphs.translated: VERGES$NEWLINE$That’s very true.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$This is the end of the charge. You, constable, are to present$NEWLINE$the Prince’s own person. If you meet the Prince in the night,$NEWLINE$you may stay him.
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$And that’s the end of your assignment. You, constable, are representing the Prince himself. If you meet the Prince in the night, you can order him to stop.

paragraphs.original: VERGES$NEWLINE$Nay, by 'r Lady, that I think he cannot.
paragraphs.translated: VERGES$NEWLINE$No, by our Lady, I don’t think he can.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Five shillings to one on ’t, with any man that knows the$NEWLINE$statutes, he may stay him—marry, not without the Prince$NEWLINE$be willing, for indeed the watch ought to offend no man,$NEWLINE$and it is an offense to stay a man against his will.
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$I’ll bet any man who knows the law five shillings to one on it. Truly though, you can’t stop the Prince without the Prince’s consent, for the watch shouldn’t offend anyone, and it’s an offense to keep a man without his consent.

paragraphs.original: VERGES$NEWLINE$By 'r lady, I think it be so.
paragraphs.translated: VERGES$NEWLINE$By our Lady, I think that’s true.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Ha, ha, ha!—Well, masters, good night.$NEWLINE$An there be any matter of weight chances, call up me. Keep your fellows'$NEWLINE$counsels and your own; and good night.—Come, neighbor.
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Ha, ha, ha! Well, gentlemen, good night. And if anything important happens, find me and let me know. Keep each other’s secrets and your own. Good night. Come, friend.

paragraphs.original: WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Well, masters, we hear our charge. Let us go sit here upon$NEWLINE$the church bench till two, and then all to bed.
paragraphs.translated: WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Well gentlemen, we’ve heard our assignment. Let’s sit here on the church bench until two and then go off to bed.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$One word more, honest neighbors. I pray you watch about$NEWLINE$Signior Leonato’s door, for the wedding being there$NEWLINE$tomorrow, there is a great coil tonight. Adieu, be vigitant,$NEWLINE$I beseech you.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$One more thing, good gentlemen. Watch over Signior Leonato’s house; with the wedding being held there tomorrow, there’s a great to-do there tonight. Adieu. Be
vigitant, I beg you.$NEWLINE$vigitant$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exeunt DOGBERRY andVERGES$NEWLINE$DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$VERGES
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY and VERGES exit.$NEWLINE$DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$VERGES

paragraphs.original: Enter BORACHIO andCONRADE$NEWLINE$BORACHIO$NEWLINE$CONRADE
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO and CONRADE enter.$NEWLINE$BORACHIO$NEWLINE$CONRADE

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$What Conrade!
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Conrade!

paragraphs.original: SEACOAL$NEWLINE$(aside) Peace! Stir not.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$(whispering) Quiet! Don’t move!$NEWLINE$(whispering)

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Conrade, I say!
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Conrade, I say!

paragraphs.original: CONRADE$NEWLINE$Here, man. I am at thy elbow.
paragraphs.translated: CONRADE$NEWLINE$I’m here, man, at your elbow.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Mass, and my elbow itched, I thought there would a scab$NEWLINE$follow.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Come to think of it, I thought I felt a scab there.

paragraphs.original: CONRADE$NEWLINE$I will owe thee an answer for that. And now forward with$NEWLINE$thy tale.
paragraphs.translated: CONRADE$NEWLINE$I’ll get you for that. Now get on with your story.

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Stand thee close, then, under this penthouse, for it drizzles$NEWLINE$rain, and I will, like a true drunkard, utter all to thee.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Since it’s drizzling, stand under this overhang with me and, like a true drunk, I’ll tell you everything.

paragraphs.original: WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$(aside) Some treason, masters. Yet stand close.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only the other WATCHMEN can hear) There’s some treason occurring, gentlemen. Stay here.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only the other$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Therefore know I have earned of Don John a thousand$NEWLINE$ducats.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$You should know I’ve earned a thousand gold pieces from Don John.

paragraphs.original: CONRADE$NEWLINE$Is it possible that any villainy should be so dear?
paragraphs.translated: CONRADE$NEWLINE$Is it possible that any crime could be so valuable?

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Thou shouldst rather ask if it were possible any villainy$NEWLINE$should be so rich. For when rich villains have need of poor$NEWLINE$ones, poor ones may make what price they will.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$You should ask instead if it’s possible that any criminal could be so rich. Because when rich villains need poor villains' services, those poor ones can name the price.

paragraphs.original: CONRADE$NEWLINE$I wonder at it.
paragraphs.translated: CONRADE$NEWLINE$I can’t believe it.

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$That shows thou art unconfirmed. Thou knowest that the$NEWLINE$fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloak, is nothing to a man.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$That only proves how inexperienced you are. You know that the style of a man’s jacket or hat or coat means nothing.

paragraphs.original: CONRADE$NEWLINE$Yes, it is apparel.
paragraphs.translated: CONRADE$NEWLINE$Yes, it’s just clothing.

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$I mean the fashion.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$No, I mean, the fashion of a man’s clothing tells us nothing about the man.

paragraphs.original: CONRADE$NEWLINE$Yes, the fashion is the fashion.
paragraphs.translated: CONRADE$NEWLINE$Yes, fashion is fashion.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Tush, I may as well say the fool’s the fool. But seest thou not$NEWLINE$what a deformed thief this fashion is?
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO$NEWLINE$C’mon, I might as well say the fool’s the fool! But don’t you see what a
deformed villain fashion is?$NEWLINE$deformed$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$(aside) I know that Deformed. He has been a vile thief this$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$seven year. He goes up and down like a gentleman. I$NEWLINE$remember his name.
paragraphs.translated:
WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only the other WATCHMEN can hear) I know that man,
Deformed. For the past seven years, he’s been a wicked thief. He walks around as if he were a gentleman. I remember that name.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only the other$NEWLINE$can hear)$NEWLINE$Deformed$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Didst thou not hear somebody?
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Did you hear someone?

paragraphs.original: CONRADE$NEWLINE$No, ’twas the vane on the house.
paragraphs.translated: CONRADE$NEWLINE$Just the weathervane moving.

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Seest thou not, I say, what a deformed thief this fashion is,$NEWLINE$how giddily he turns about all the hot bloods between$NEWLINE$fourteen and five-and-thirty, sometimes fashioning them$NEWLINE$like Pharaoh’s soldiers in the reechy painting, sometime$NEWLINE$like god Bel’s priests in the old church-window, sometime$NEWLINE$like the shaven Hercules in the smirched worm-eaten$NEWLINE$tapestry, where his codpiece seems as massy as his club?
paragraphs.translated:
BORACHIO$NEWLINE$As I was saying, fashion is a deformed villain. It makes hot-blooded young men spin around feverishly, forever changing their appearances, dictating that sometimes they dress like Pharoah’s soldiers in that grimy painting and sometimes like the priests of the god Baal, as seen in old church windows. And sometimes fashion dresses them like the great Hercules in that dirty, worm-eaten tapestry—the one where his
codpiece seems almost as big as his club.$NEWLINE$codpiece$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CONRADE$NEWLINE$All this I see, and I see that the fashion wears out more$NEWLINE$apparel than the man. But art not thou thyself giddy with$NEWLINE$the fashion too, that thou hast shifted out of thy tale into$NEWLINE$telling me of the fashion?
paragraphs.translated: CONRADE$NEWLINE$I get all this. And I also understand how fashion changes so quickly that a man’s clothing never gets a chance to wear itself out. But you’re all wound up about fashion, too. Otherwise, why would you stray from your story to blabber on about it?

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Not so, neither. But know that I have tonight wooed$NEWLINE$Margaret, the Lady Hero’s gentlewoman, by the name of$NEWLINE$Hero. She leans me out at her mistress' chamber window,$NEWLINE$bids me a thousand times good night. I tell this tale vilely.$NEWLINE$I should first tell thee how the Prince, Claudio and my$NEWLINE$master, planted and placed and possessed by my master$NEWLINE$Don John, saw afar off in the orchard this amiable$NEWLINE$encounter.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$No, I’m not wound up. But I will tell you that I seduced Margaret, the Lady Hero’s waiting woman, tonight. I called her “Hero” the whole time. She leaned out of her mistress’s bedroom window and told me good night a thousand times—but I am telling this story poorly. I should backtrack and begin with how my master, Don John, arranged for the Prince, Claudio, and himself to witness this friendly encounter from the orchard.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CONRADE$NEWLINE$And thought they Margaret was Hero?
paragraphs.translated: CONRADE$NEWLINE$And they thought Margaret was Hero?

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Two of them did, the Prince and Claudio, but the devil my$NEWLINE$master knew she was Margaret; and partly by his oaths,$NEWLINE$which first possessed them, partly by the dark night, which$NEWLINE$did deceive them, but chiefly by my villainy, which did$NEWLINE$confirm any slander that Don John had made, away went$NEWLINE$Claudio enraged, swore he would meet her as he was$NEWLINE$appointed next morning at the temple, and there, before the$NEWLINE$whole congregation, shame her with what he saw o'ernight$NEWLINE$and send her home again without a husband.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$The Prince and Claudio did, but the devil, my master, knew that it was Margaret. They believed the charade partially because of my master’s testimony—which first caused them to doubt Hero—and partially because of how dark and deceiving the night was, but mostly because of my villainous actions, which confirmed Don John’s slander. Claudio went away enraged, swearing that he’d meet Hero at the temple as planned and there, before the entire congregation, shame her with what he’d discovered and send her home without a husband.

paragraphs.original: SECOND WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$We charge you, in the Prince’s name, stand!
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$We charge you, in the Prince’s name, to stop!

paragraphs.original: FIRST WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Call up the right Master Constable. We have here$NEWLINE$recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery that ever was$NEWLINE$known in the commonwealth.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Call up the Master Constable Dogberry. We have
recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery that was ever known in the commonwealth.$NEWLINE$recovered$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SECOND WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$And one Deformed is one of them. I know him; he wears a$NEWLINE$lock.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$And one of them is the criminal Deformed. I know him; he wears a lock of hair.

paragraphs.original: CONRADE$NEWLINE$Masters, masters—
paragraphs.translated: CONRADE$NEWLINE$Gentlemen, gentlemen—

paragraphs.original: SECOND WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$(to BORACHIO) You’ll be made bring Deformed forth, I$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$warrant you.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$(to BORACHIO) I bet you’ll be forced to bring Deformed forward.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FIRST WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Masters, never speak, we charge you, let us obey you go$NEWLINE$with us.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Gentlemen, don’t speak. We
obey you to go with us.$NEWLINE$obey$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$We are like to prove a goodly commodity, being taken up of$NEWLINE$these men’s bills.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$We’re probably a very valuable catch for these guys.

paragraphs.original: CONRADE$NEWLINE$A commodity in question, I warrant you.—Come, we’ll$NEWLINE$obey you.
paragraphs.translated: CONRADE$NEWLINE$Well, our value is debatable, I bet. Let’s go, we’ll obey you.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter HERO,MARGARET, and URSULA$NEWLINE$HERO$NEWLINE$MARGARET$NEWLINE$URSULA
paragraphs.translated: HERO, MARGARET, andURSULA enter.$NEWLINE$HERO$NEWLINE$MARGARET$NEWLINE$URSULA

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice and desire her to$NEWLINE$rise.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$Good Ursula, go wake my cousin and ask her to get up.

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$I will, lady.
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$I will, lady.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$And bid her come hither.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$And request that she come here.

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$Well.
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$Very well.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Troth, I think your other rebato were better.
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Really, I think your other ruff is better.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$No, pray thee, good Meg, I’ll wear this.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$No, please good Meg, I’ll wear this one.

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$By my troth, ’s not so good, and I warrant your cousin will$NEWLINE$say so.
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Honestly, it’s not as good as the other one, and I’m sure your cousin will agree with me.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$My cousin’s a fool, and thou art another. I’ll wear none but$NEWLINE$this.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$My cousin’s a fool, and you are too. I’ll wear this one and none other.

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$I like the new tire within excellently, if the hair were a$NEWLINE$thought browner; and your gown’s a most rare fashion, i'$NEWLINE$faith. I saw the Duchess of Milan’s gown that they praise so.
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$I like your new wig and headdress, though I’d like it more if the hair were a shade browner. And your gown is really stylish. You know, I saw the Duchess of Milan’s gown, the one that everyone praises so highly.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$Oh, that exceeds, they say.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$Oh, they say that dress surpasses all others.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$By my troth, ’s but a nightgown in respect of yours—cloth$NEWLINE$o' gold, and cuts, and laced with silver, set with pearls,$NEWLINE$down sleeves, side sleeves, and skirts, round underborne$NEWLINE$with a bluish tinsel. But for a fine, quaint, graceful, and$NEWLINE$excellent fashion, yours is worth ten on ’t.
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Compared to your dress, it’s no better than a nightgown. The cloth is interwoven with gold thread, and slashes in the material show the fabric beneath. It is trimmed with silver lace and embroidered with pearls. It has one set of fitted sleeves and another ornamental pair that hangs open from the shoulders. The skirts are trimmed with a blue, metallic fabric. But for a fine, elegant, graceful, and excellent dress, yours is worth ten of those.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$God give me joy to wear it, for my heart is exceeding heavy.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$I hope I enjoy wearing it, for my heart is very heavy.

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$'Twill be heavier soon by the weight of a man.
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$It will be made even heavier soon—by the weight of a man.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$Fie upon thee! Art not ashamed?
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$Watch your tongue! Have you no shame?

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Of what, lady? Of speaking honorably? Is not marriage$NEWLINE$honorable in a beggar? Is not your lord honorable without$NEWLINE$marriage? I think you would have me say, “Saving your$NEWLINE$reverence, a husband.” An bad thinking do not wrest true$NEWLINE$speaking, I’ll offend nobody. Is there any harm in “the$NEWLINE$heavier for a husband”? None, I think, an it be the right$NEWLINE$husband and the right wife. Otherwise, ’tis light and not$NEWLINE$heavy. Ask my Lady Beatrice else. Here she comes.
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Shame of what, lady? Sex and marriage are honorable things—even for a beggar, right? And isn’t your husband an honorable man? You’re so prudish you’d probably like me to say, “I beg your pardon, your husband”—as if husband were a dirty word! So long as suspicious minds aren’t misinterpreting my honest words, I’ll offend no one. What’s wrong with admitting your husband’s going to lie on you? Nothing, as long as it’s the right husband with the right wife. That’s right and proper—anything else is frivolous and immoral. Ask Beatrice. Here she comes.$NEWLINE$husband

paragraphs.original: Enter BEATRICE$NEWLINE$BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE enters.$NEWLINE$BEATRICE

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$Good morrow, coz.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$Good morning, cousin.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Good morrow, sweet Hero.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Good morning, sweet Hero.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$Why, how now? Do you speak in the sick tune?
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$Why do you sound so odd? Are you ill? You sound out of tune.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I am out of all other tune, methinks.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I must be ill—I don’t think I can speak in any other tune.

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Clap ’s into “Light o' love.” That goes without a burden.$NEWLINE$Do you sing it, and I’ll dance it.
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$If it’s a tune we want, let’s sing “Light on Love!” It’s a light song and doesn’t require a man to sing the baritone. You sing, and I’ll dance.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Ye light o' love, with your heels! Then, if your husband$NEWLINE$have stables enough, you’ll see he shall lack no barns.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$You’re “light on love” sure enough—your frivolous dancing proves you have light heels! When you’re married one of these days, if your husband is rolling in dough, you’ll let him roll in the hay whenever he wants.

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$O illegitimate construction! I scorn that with my heels.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET$NEWLINE$Never! I reject that life; I kick it away with my
heels.$NEWLINE$heels$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$'Tis almost five o'clock, cousin. 'Tis time you were ready.$NEWLINE$By my troth, I am exceeding ill. Heigh-ho!
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$(to HERO) It’s almost five o'clock, cousin. You should be ready by now. Oh, I really don’t feel well. Heigh-ho!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$For a hawk, a horse, or a husband?
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Are you sighing for a hawk, a horse, or a husband?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$For the letter that begins them all, H.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I have an ache; I’m sighing for the letter that begins all those words.

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Well, an you be not turned Turk, there’s no more sailing by$NEWLINE$the star.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET$NEWLINE$Well, if you haven’t
renounced your old faith yet, we can’t trust anything anymore.$NEWLINE$renounced$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$What means the fool, trow?
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$What does the fool mean by that, I wonder?

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Nothing, I; but God send everyone their heart’s desire.
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$I don’t mean anything—but God sends everyone their heart’s desire.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$These gloves the Count sent me, they are an excellent$NEWLINE$perfume.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$The Count sent me an excellent pair of perfumed gloves.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I am stuffed, cousin. I cannot smell.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Sorry, I’m all stuffed. I can’t smell a thing.

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$A maid, and stuffed! There’s goodly catching of cold.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET$NEWLINE$Oh, just a young lady and already
stuffed! That’s a nice way to catch a cold.$NEWLINE$stuffed!$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Oh, God help me, God help me! How long have you$NEWLINE$professed apprehension?
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Oh, God help me! Since when have you claimed to be such a great wit?

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Even since you left it. Doth not my wit become me rarely?
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Ever since you lost yours. Doesn’t my wit suit me well?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$It is not seen enough; you should wear it in your cap. By my$NEWLINE$troth, I am sick.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$It doesn’t get seen enough; you should wear it in your cap, the way fools wear coxcombs. God, I’m really sick.

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Get you some of this distilled carduus benedictus and lay it$NEWLINE$to your heart. It is the only thing for a qualm.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET$NEWLINE$You should get some distilled
carduus benedictus and put it on your chest. It’s the only way to cure a sudden faintness.$NEWLINE$carduus benedictus$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$There thou prick’st her with a thistle.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$With that you’ve managed to prick her with a thistle.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Benedictus! Why benedictus? You have some moral in this$NEWLINE$benedictus?$NEWLINE$benedictus?
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Benedictus! Why do you suggest I use benedictus? Is there some double meaning in that word, “benedictus”?$NEWLINE$Benedictus$NEWLINE$benedictus

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Moral! No, by my troth, I have no moral meaning. I meant$NEWLINE$plain holy thistle. You may think perchance that I think you$NEWLINE$are in love. Nay, by 'r Lady, I am not such a fool to think$NEWLINE$what I list, nor I list not to think what I can, nor indeed I$NEWLINE$cannot think, if I would think my heart out of thinking, that$NEWLINE$you are in love or that you will be in love or that you can be$NEWLINE$in love. Yet Benedick was such another, and now is he$NEWLINE$become a man. He swore he would never marry, and yet$NEWLINE$now, in despite of his heart, he eats his meat without$NEWLINE$grudging. And how you may be converted I know not, but$NEWLINE$methinks you look with your eyes as other women do.
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Double meaning! No, honestly, there’s no other meaning. I just meant that you should use some holy thistle. Maybe you think that I think you’re in love. No, by Our Lady, I’m not such a fool to think what I please, and I don’t please to think what I can, and in fact I cannot think, even if I could think my heart right past thinking, that you are in love or that you will be in love or even that you can be in love. But Benedick was once an enemy of love as well, and now he’s become a real man. He swore that he’d never get married, but now, despite his earlier protestations, he loves ungrudgingly. How we’re going to convert you I’ll never know. And yet I think you look with your eyes just like every other woman does.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$What pace is this that thy tongue keeps?
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Why are you talking at such a crazy clip?

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Not a false gallop.
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$It’s not a false gallop, anyway.

paragraphs.original: Enter URSULA$NEWLINE$URSULA
paragraphs.translated: URSULA enters.$NEWLINE$URSULA

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$Madam, withdraw: the Prince, the Count, Signor$NEWLINE$Benedick, Don John, and all the gallants of the town are$NEWLINE$come to fetch you to church.
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$Madam, we have to go: the Prince, the Count, Signior Benedick, Don John, and all the gentlemen of the town have come to bring you to church.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$Help to dress me, good coz, good Meg, good Ursula.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$Good cousin, good Meg, good Ursula, come help me get dressed.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LEONATO withDOGBERRY and VERGES$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$VERGES
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO enters withDOGBERRY andVERGES.$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$VERGES

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$What would you with me, honest neighbor?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$What do you want from me, my good man?

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Marry, sir, I would have some confidence with you that$NEWLINE$decerns you nearly.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Please, sir, I would like to discuss some news that
decerns you greatly.$NEWLINE$decerns$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Brief, I pray you, for you see it is a busy time with me.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Be brief, please, because, as you can see, this is a busy time for me.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Marry, this it is, sir.
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Indeed, sir, it is.

paragraphs.original: VERGES$NEWLINE$Yes, in truth it is, sir.
paragraphs.translated: VERGES$NEWLINE$Yes, it truly is.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$What is it, my good friends?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$What’s the news, my good friends?

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Goodman Verges, sir, speaks a little off the matter. An old$NEWLINE$man, sir, and his wits are not so blunt as, God help, I would$NEWLINE$desire they were, but, in faith, honest as the skin between$NEWLINE$his brows.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Sorry, sir, Goodman Verges tends to ramble. He’s an old man, sir, and his wits are not as
blunt as I wish they were. But truly, he’s as honest as the skin between his brows.$NEWLINE$blunt$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: VERGES$NEWLINE$Yes, I thank God I am as honest as any man living that is an$NEWLINE$old man and no honester than I.
paragraphs.translated: VERGES$NEWLINE$Yes, I thank God that I am as honest as all the other old men who are not honester than me.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Comparisons are odorous. Palabras, neighbor Verges.$NEWLINE$Palabras
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Making comparisons is
odorous, Verges. Get on with your story.$NEWLINE$odorous$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Neighbors, you are tedious.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Friends, you are becoming tedious.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$It pleases your Worship to say so, but we are the poor duke’s$NEWLINE$officers. But truly, for mine own part, if I were as tedious as$NEWLINE$a king, I could find it in my heart to bestow it all of your$NEWLINE$worship.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Thank you for saying that, your Worship, but we’re just the poor duke’s officers. But truly, if I were as
tedious as a king, I would give everything to you, your Worship.$NEWLINE$tedious$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$All thy tediousness on me, ah?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Oh, so you’d give me all your tediousness?

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Yea, an ’twere a thousand pound more than ’tis, for I hear$NEWLINE$as good exclamation on your Worship as of any man in the$NEWLINE$city, and though I be but a poor man, I am glad to hear it.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Yes, even if I had a thousand more pounds than that, for I hear that you are
exclaimed throughout the city, and though I am only a poor man, it makes me glad to hear it.$NEWLINE$exclaimed$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: VERGES$NEWLINE$And so am I.
paragraphs.translated: VERGES$NEWLINE$Me, too.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I would fain know what you have to say.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Gentlemen, please, I’d like to hear your news.

paragraphs.original: VERGES$NEWLINE$Marry, sir, our watch tonight, excepting your Worship’s$NEWLINE$presence, ha' ta'en a couple of as arrant knaves as any in$NEWLINE$Messina.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES$NEWLINE$Sir, our watch tonight—
expectfully, sir—has captured a couple of the worst criminals in Messina.$NEWLINE$expectfully$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$A good old man, sir. He will be talking. As they say, “When$NEWLINE$the age is in, the wit is out.” God help us, it is a world to see!$NEWLINE$Well said, i' faith, neighbor Verges.—Well, God’s a good$NEWLINE$man. An two men ride of a horse, one must ride behind. An$NEWLINE$honest soul, i' faith, sir, by my troth he is, as ever broke$NEWLINE$bread, but God is to be worshipped, all men are not alike,$NEWLINE$alas, good neighbor!
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$(to LEONATO) Verges is a good old man, sir, but he’s always babbling. Like they say, “When age comes, wit goes.” God help us, what a world! (to VERGES) You did well, Verges, honestly. (to LEONATO) Well, God’s a fair man. If two men are riding on one horse, one must naturally ride behind. Verges is as honest a man as any, but, God bless him, not all men are created equal. Am I right, my friend?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Indeed, neighbor, he comes too short of you.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Truly, my friend, he isn’t nearly as impressive as you are.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Gifts that God gives.
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$God gives those gifts—I had nothing to do with it.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I must leave you.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Now I must return to the wedding.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$One word, sir. Our watch, sir, have indeed comprehended$NEWLINE$two aspicious persons, and we would have them this$NEWLINE$morning examined before your worship.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$One more thing, sir. Our watch, sir, as you know, has
comprehended two auspicious persons. We’d like for you to examine them this morning.$NEWLINE$comprehended$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Take their examination yourself and bring it me. I am now$NEWLINE$in great haste, as it may appear unto you.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Examine them yourselves, then bring me your findings. Now I’m in a great hurry, as I’m sure you can see.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$It shall be suffigance.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$That will be
suffigance.$NEWLINE$suffigance$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Drink some wine ere you go. Fare you well.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Have some wine before you go. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$My lord, they stay for you to give your daughter to her$NEWLINE$husband.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$My lord, they’re waiting for you to give your daughter away to Claudio.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I’ll wait upon them. I am ready.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I’m coming.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt LEONATO andMESSENGER$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO and theMESSENGER exit.$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Go, good partner, go, get you to Francis Seacole. Bid him$NEWLINE$bring his pen and inkhorn to the jail. We are now to$NEWLINE$examination these men.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Go to Francis Seacole, the constable of the watch. Tell him to bring his pen and his inkwell to the jail. We will now go to
examination these men.$NEWLINE$examination$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: VERGES$NEWLINE$And we must do it wisely.
paragraphs.translated: VERGES$NEWLINE$We must do this wisely.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$We will spare for no wit, I warrant you. Here’s that shall$NEWLINE$drive some of them to a noncome. Only get the learned$NEWLINE$writer to set down our excommunication and meet me at$NEWLINE$the jail.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$We won’t hold back any of our wisdom. We’ll drive them to a
noncome. Go get the educated writer to record our excommunication, and I’ll meet you at the jail.$NEWLINE$noncome$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, LEONATO, FRIAR FRANCIS, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK,HERO, BEATRICE, and Attendants$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$DON JOHN$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$HERO$NEWLINE$BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO, DON JOHN,LEONATO, FRIAR FRANCIS,CLAUDIO, BENEDICK,HERO, and BEATRICE enter withATTENDANTS.$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$DON JOHN$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$HERO$NEWLINE$BEATRICE$NEWLINE$ATTENDANTS

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Come, Friar Francis, be brief, only to the plain form of$NEWLINE$marriage, and you shall recount their particular duties$NEWLINE$afterwards.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$All right, Friar Francis, let’s keep this short. Do a simple ceremony, and list all the particular duties of marriage later.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$(to CLAUDIO) You come hither, my lord, to marry this lady?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$(to CLAUDIO) Have you come here, my lord, to marry this lady?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$No.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$No.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$To be married to her.—Friar, you come to marry her.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$No, he comes to be married to her. Friar, you are the one who has come to marry her.$NEWLINE$to

paragraphs.original: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Lady, you come hither to be married to this count?
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Lady, do you come here to be married to this count?

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$I do.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$I do.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$If either of you know any inward impediment why you$NEWLINE$should not be conjoined, charge you on your souls to utter$NEWLINE$it.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$If either of you knows any secret reason why you two should not be joined in marriage, I order you on your souls to say so.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Know you any, Hero?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Do you know any, Hero?

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$None, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$None, my lord.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Know you any, count?
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Do you know any, count?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I dare make his answer, none.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I’m sure I can answer for him—he doesn’t know any, either.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$O, what men dare do! What men may do! What men daily$NEWLINE$do, not knowing what they do!
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Oh, the things men dare to do! The things men are allowed to do! The things men do daily, not knowing what they’re doing!

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$How now, interjections? Why, then, some be of laughing,$NEWLINE$as, ah, ha, he!
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK$NEWLINE$What, are we playing with interjections? Well then, add some interjections that indicate laughter, like
“ah,” “ha,” and “he!”$NEWLINE$“ah,” “ha,” and “he!”$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Stand thee by, Friar.—Father, by your leave,$NEWLINE$Will you with free and unconstrainèd soul$NEWLINE$Give me this maid, your daughter?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Hold on, Friar. (to LEONATO) Father, are you giving me your daughter freely?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$As freely, son, as God did give her me.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$As freely, son, as God gave her to me.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And what have I to give you back whose worth$NEWLINE$May counterpoise this rich and precious gift?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And what should I give you that would be equal in value to this rare and precious gift?

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Nothing, unless you render her again.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Nothing, sir, except grandchildren.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Sweet Prince, you learn me noble thankfulness.—$NEWLINE$There, Leonato, take her back again.$NEWLINE$Give not this rotten orange to your friend.$NEWLINE$She’s but the sign and semblance of her honor.$NEWLINE$Behold how like a maid she blushes here!$NEWLINE$Oh, what authority and show of truth$NEWLINE$Can cunning sin cover itself withal!$NEWLINE$Comes not that blood as modest evidence$NEWLINE$To witness simple virtue? Would you not swear,$NEWLINE$All you that see her, that she were a maid$NEWLINE$By these exterior shows? But she is none.$NEWLINE$She knows the heat of a luxurious bed.$NEWLINE$Her blush is guiltiness, not modesty.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Good Prince, you have taught me how to accept things nobly. There, Leonato, take your daughter back. Don’t insult a friend by giving him a beautiful orange that rots inside. She only appears honorable from the outside. Look, how she blushes like a virgin! Oh, sin can disguise itself so artfully! Doesn’t that rising blush suggest that she is virtuous and innocent? All of you who are looking at her, wouldn’t you swear that she’s a virgin, judging by these outward shows? But she is no virgin. She has been in a man’s bed. She blushes from guilt, not modesty.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$What do you mean, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$What do you mean, my lord?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Not to be married,$NEWLINE$Not to knit my soul to an approvèd wanton.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I won’t be married. I won’t join my soul to such a proven slut.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Dear my lord, if you in your own proof$NEWLINE$Have vanquished the resistance of her youth$NEWLINE$And made defeat of her virginity—
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$My dear lord, if it was you who conquered her and took her virginity—

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I know what you would say: if I have known her,$NEWLINE$You will say she did embrace me as a husband,$NEWLINE$And so extenuate the forehand sin.$NEWLINE$No, Leonato,$NEWLINE$I never tempted her with word too large$NEWLINE$But, as a brother to his sister, showed$NEWLINE$Bashful sincerity and comely love.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I know what you’re about to say. If I had slept with her, you’d say that we did so as husband and wife, merely anticipating our eventual marriage. No, Leonato. I never seduced her, or tempted her with indecent words. I treated her like a brother would treat a sister, with modest sincerity and appropriate affection.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$And seemed I ever otherwise to you?
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$And have I ever seemed less than modest or appropriate to you?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Out on thee, seeming! I will write against it.$NEWLINE$You seem to me as Dian in her orb,$NEWLINE$As chaste as is the bud ere it be blown.$NEWLINE$But you are more intemperate in your blood$NEWLINE$Than Venus, or those pampered animals$NEWLINE$That rage in savage sensuality.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Curse you for your false appearances! To me, you seemed like
Diana in her orbit—as virginal as the flower bud before it blooms. But you’re actually as hot-blooded as Venus, or a pampered animal allowed to run wild.$NEWLINE$Diana$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$Is my lord well, that he doth speak so wide?
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$Are you sick, my lord? Is that why you’re talking so wildly?

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Sweet Prince, why speak not you?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Good Prince, say something!

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$What should I speak?$NEWLINE$I stand dishonored, that have gone about$NEWLINE$To link my dear friend to a common stale.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$What should I say? I’ve been dishonored: I arranged for a friend of mine to marry a common whore.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Are these things spoken, or do I but dream?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Are you really saying these things, or am I dreaming?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Sir, they are spoken, and these things are true.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$They’re really being spoken, sir, and they’re true.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$This looks not like a nuptial.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$This doesn’t look like a wedding.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$True! O God!
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$It’s true! Oh God!

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Leonato, stand I here?$NEWLINE$Is this the Prince? Is this the Prince’s brother?$NEWLINE$Is this face Hero’s? Are our eyes our own?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Leonato, am I standing here? Is this the Prince? Is this the Prince’s brother? Is this face Hero’s? Are these our eyes?

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$All this is so, but what of this, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Yes, that’s all true—but what do you mean by it, my lord?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Let me but move one question to your daughter,$NEWLINE$And by that fatherly and kindly power$NEWLINE$That you have in her, bid her answer truly.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Let me just ask her one question, and by your authority as her father, order her to answer truthfully.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I charge thee do so, as thou art my child.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$As my child, I order you to do so.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$Oh, God defend me! how am I beset!—$NEWLINE$What kind of catechizing call you this?
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$Oh, God help me! How I’m being attacked! What kind of game is this?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$To make you answer truly to your name.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$We just want you to answer to your real name.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$Is it not Hero? Who can blot that name$NEWLINE$With any just reproach?
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$Isn’t my name Hero? Who can stain that name with a just accusation?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Marry, that can Hero!$NEWLINE$Hero itself can blot out Hero’s virtue.$NEWLINE$What man was he talked with you yesternight$NEWLINE$Out at your window betwixt twelve and one?$NEWLINE$Now, if you are a maid, answer to this.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Indeed, Hero herself can! You’ve stained your virtue with your own actions. What man were you talking to at your window last night, between the hours of midnight and one? If you’re a virgin, you’ll answer this question.

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$I talked with no man at that hour, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$I wasn’t talking to any man at that time, my lord.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Why, then are you no maiden.—Leonato,$NEWLINE$I am sorry you must hear. Upon mine honor,$NEWLINE$Myself, my brother, and this grievèd count$NEWLINE$Did see her, hear her, at that hour last night$NEWLINE$Talk with a ruffian at her chamber window$NEWLINE$Who hath indeed, most like a liberal villain,$NEWLINE$Confessed the vile encounters they have had$NEWLINE$A thousand times in secret.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Well then, you are no virgin. Leonato, I’m sorry you have to hear this. I swear on my honor that we saw and heard Hero talking to a brute at her window last night.$NEWLINE$And that man confessed at length how he has secretly come to her bedroom thousands of times.

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Fie, fie, they are not to be named, my lord,$NEWLINE$Not to be spoke of!$NEWLINE$There is not chastity enough in language,$NEWLINE$Without offense, to utter them.—Thus, pretty lady,$NEWLINE$I am sorry for thy much misgovernment.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$No, my lord, don’t name her sinful acts or speak of them! There’s no way to describe them without offending everyone here. Pretty lady, I’m much ashamed of your shocking behavior.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$O Hero, what a Hero hadst thou been$NEWLINE$If half thy outward graces had been placed$NEWLINE$About thy thoughts and counsels of thy heart!$NEWLINE$But fare thee well, most foul, most fair! Farewell,$NEWLINE$Thou pure impiety and impious purity.$NEWLINE$For thee I’ll lock up all the gates of love,$NEWLINE$And on my eyelids shall conjecture hang,$NEWLINE$To turn all beauty into thoughts of harm,$NEWLINE$And never shall it more be gracious.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Oh Hero, you could have equaled the
mythical Hero if only half your outward beauty matched your inner thoughts and desires! Goodbye, beautiful sinner. Goodbye to your pure wickedness and your wicked purity. Because of you, I’ll keep myself away from love. I’ll hang suspicion on my eyelids, so that all the beautiful things I see are transformed into dangers and are never able to trick me again.$NEWLINE$mythical Hero$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Hath no man’s dagger here a point for me?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Does anyone have a dagger for me?

paragraphs.original: HERO swoons$NEWLINE$HERO
paragraphs.translated: HERO faints.$NEWLINE$HERO

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Why, how now, cousin! wherefore sink you down?
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$What’s wrong, cousin? Why have you collapsed?

paragraphs.original: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Come, let us go. These things, come thus to light,$NEWLINE$Smother her spirits up.
paragraphs.translated: DON JOHN$NEWLINE$Come, let’s go. These revelations have overwhelmed her.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, and CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$DON JOHN$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO DON JOHN, and CLAUDIO exit.$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$DON JOHN$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$How doth the lady?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$How is she?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Dead, I think.—Help, uncle!—$NEWLINE$Hero, why, Hero! Uncle! Signor Benedick! Friar!
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$She’s dead, I think.—Help, uncle!—Hero, why Hero! Uncle! Signior Benedick! Friar!

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$O Fate! Take not away thy heavy hand!$NEWLINE$Death is the fairest cover for her shame$NEWLINE$That may be wished for.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Oh Fate, don’t spare Hero from being punished! Death is the best way to cover over her shame.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$How now, cousin Hero!
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$How are you, Hero?

paragraphs.original: HERO stirs$NEWLINE$HERO
paragraphs.translated: HERO stirs.$NEWLINE$HERO

paragraphs.original: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$(to HERO) Have comfort, lady.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$(to HERO) Take comfort, lady.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$(to HERO) Dost thou look up?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$(to HERO) Are you looking up?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Yea, wherefore should she not?
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Yes, why shouldn’t she?

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Wherefore! Why, doth not every earthly thing$NEWLINE$Cry shame upon her? Could she here deny$NEWLINE$The story that is printed in her blood?—$NEWLINE$Do not live, Hero, do not ope thine eyes,$NEWLINE$For, did I think thou wouldst not quickly die,$NEWLINE$Thought I thy spirits were stronger than thy shames,$NEWLINE$Myself would, on the rearward of reproaches,$NEWLINE$Strike at thy life. Grieved I I had but one?$NEWLINE$Chid I for that at frugal Nature’s frame?$NEWLINE$O, one too much by thee! Why had I one?$NEWLINE$Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes?$NEWLINE$Why had I not with charitable hand$NEWLINE$Took up a beggar’s issue at my gates,$NEWLINE$Who, smirchèd thus, and mired with infamy,$NEWLINE$I might have said, “No part of it is mine;$NEWLINE$This shame derives itself from unknown loins”?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Why not! Isn’t every living thing condemning her? Can she deny the accusations that are proven by her guilty blush? Die, Hero, don’t open your eyes. If I didn’t think you were about to die soon—if I thought your spirit could bear this shame—I would risk punishment and kill you myself. Am I sorry that I only had one child? Do I blame Nature for being so thrifty? Oh, one child is one too many! Why did I ever have one? Why did you once seem lovely to me? Why didn’t I just adopt a beggar’s child left at my doorstep, whose shame and dishonor I could have denied, not being its true father?$NEWLINE$But you were mine, and I loved and praised you for being mine, and was proud of you for being mine—I loved you so much that I hardly cared about myself.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: But mine, and mine I loved, and mine I praised,$NEWLINE$And mine that I was proud on, mine so much$NEWLINE$That I myself was to myself not mine,$NEWLINE$Valuing of her—why, she, O she is fall'n$NEWLINE$Into a pit of ink, that the wide sea$NEWLINE$Hath drops too few to wash her clean again$NEWLINE$And salt too little which may season give$NEWLINE$To her foul tainted flesh!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, but now you have fallen into a pit of ink, and there’s not enough water in the whole wide sea to wash you clean again, and not enough salt to cover your stink.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Sir, sir, be patient.$NEWLINE$For my part, I am so attired in wonder$NEWLINE$I know not what to say.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Sir, sir, calm down. I’m so amazed by this, I don’t know what to say.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Oh, on my soul, my cousin is belied!
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Oh, on my soul, my cousin has been slandered falsely!

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Lady, were you her bedfellow last night?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Lady, did you sleep in her room last night?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$No, truly not, although until last night$NEWLINE$I have this twelvemonth been her bedfellow.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$No, I didn’t, but I did every night for the past year.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Confirmed, confirmed! Oh, that is stronger made$NEWLINE$Which was before barred up with ribs of iron!$NEWLINE$Would the two princes lie and Claudio lie,$NEWLINE$Who loved her so that, speaking of her foulness,$NEWLINE$Washed it with tears? Hence from her. Let her die.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Then it’s confirmed! That’s even more proof, and the case against her was airtight already. Would the two princes and Claudio lie? Claudio, who loved her so much that talking about her wickedness made him weep?

paragraphs.original: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Hear me a little,$NEWLINE$For I have only silent been so long,$NEWLINE$And given way unto this course of fortune,$NEWLINE$By noting of the lady. I have marked$NEWLINE$A thousand blushing apparitions$NEWLINE$To start into her face, a thousand innocent shames$NEWLINE$In angel whiteness beat away those blushes,$NEWLINE$And in her eye there hath appeared a fire$NEWLINE$To burn the errors that these princes hold$NEWLINE$Against her maiden truth. Call me a fool,
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Listen to me a moment. I’ve only remained silent this whole time because I’ve been watching Hero. I’ve seen her begin to blush a thousand times, only to watch those blushes disappear a thousand times and an innocent paleness take over her face. And in her eyes I see a fire that would seem to burn away the lies the princes have told about her chastity. Call me a fool,$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$don’t trust my observations—the truth of which is backed up by all my years of experience—don’t trust my age, my reputation, my position, and my holiness.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Trust not my reading nor my observations,$NEWLINE$Which with experimental seal doth warrant$NEWLINE$The tenor of my book; trust not my age,$NEWLINE$My reverence, calling, nor divinity,$NEWLINE$If this sweet lady lie not guiltless here$NEWLINE$Under some biting error.
paragraphs.translated: You can doubt all these things if this sweet lady turns out to be guilty.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Friar, it cannot be.$NEWLINE$Thou seest that all the grace that she hath left$NEWLINE$Is that she will not add to her damnation$NEWLINE$A sin of perjury. She not denies it.$NEWLINE$Why seek’st thou then to cover with excuse$NEWLINE$That which appears in proper nakedness?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$But she must be, Friar. You see that any morals she has left are preventing her from denying the charges: she doesn’t want to add perjury to her list of sins.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Lady, what man is he you are accused of?
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Lady, who do they accuse you of having taken as your lover?

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$They know that do accuse me. I know none.$NEWLINE$If I know more of any man alive$NEWLINE$Than that which maiden modesty doth warrant,$NEWLINE$Let all my sins lack mercy!—O my father,$NEWLINE$Prove you that any man with me conversed$NEWLINE$At hours unmeet, or that I yesternight$NEWLINE$Maintained the change of words with any creature,$NEWLINE$Refuse me, hate me, torture me to death!
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$You should ask them. I don’t know who they’re talking about. If I’ve been with a man in any improper way, let all my sins be punished! Oh, father, if you yourself can prove that I talked with a man at an indecent hour, or indeed that I spoke to any creature last night, you can disown me, hate me, and torture me to death!

paragraphs.original: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$There is some strange misprision in the princes.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$The princes are under some strange misunderstanding.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Two of them have the very bent of honor,$NEWLINE$And if their wisdoms be misled in this,$NEWLINE$The practice of it lives in John the Bastard,$NEWLINE$Whose spirits toil in frame of villainies.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Two of them are completely honorable, and if they have been tricked in this, we must blame John the Bastard, who lives to create conflict.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I know not. If they speak but truth of her,$NEWLINE$These hands shall tear her; if they wrong her honor,$NEWLINE$The proudest of them shall well hear of it.$NEWLINE$Time hath not yet so dried this blood of mine$NEWLINE$Nor age so eat up my invention$NEWLINE$Nor fortune made such havoc of my means$NEWLINE$Nor my bad life reft me so much of friends$NEWLINE$But they shall find, awaked in such a kind,$NEWLINE$Both strength of limb and policy of mind,$NEWLINE$Ability in means and choice of friends,$NEWLINE$To quit me of them throughly.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I don’t know. If they have spoken the truth about Hero, I will tear her apart with my bare hands. But if they have accused her falsely, even the greatest of them will have to deal with me.
