Age hasn’t dried up my body or eroded my intelligence so much, and luck hasn’t robbed me of so much of my fortune, and my bad ways$NEWLINE$haven’t deprived me of so many friends, that they won’t find me ready to seek revenge both physically and mentally, with money and friends at my disposal.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Pause awhile,$NEWLINE$And let my counsel sway you in this case.$NEWLINE$Your daughter here the princes left for dead.$NEWLINE$Let her awhile be secretly kept in$NEWLINE$And publish it that she is dead indeed.$NEWLINE$Maintain a mourning ostentation,$NEWLINE$And on your family’s old monument$NEWLINE$Hang mournful epitaphs and do all rites$NEWLINE$That appertain unto a burial.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Hold on a moment, and listen to my advice. The princes left your daughter here for dead. Hide her for a while in your house, and tell everyone that she has, in fact, died. Make a bug show of mourning for her, hang sad epitaphs up at your family’s tomb, and perform all the appropriate burial ceremonies.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$What shall become of this? What will this do?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Why should we do this? What will this do?

paragraphs.original: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Marry, this, well carried, shall on her behalf$NEWLINE$Change slander to remorse. That is some good.$NEWLINE$But not for that dream I on this strange course,$NEWLINE$But on this travail look for greater birth.$NEWLINE$She, dying, as it must so be maintained,$NEWLINE$Upon the instant that she was accused,$NEWLINE$Shall be lamented, pitied and excused$NEWLINE$Of every hearer. For it so falls out$NEWLINE$That what we have we prize not to the worth$NEWLINE$Whiles we enjoy it, but being lacked and lost,$NEWLINE$Why then we rack the value, then we find
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Listen, if we do this correctly, the men who slandered Hero will feel remorse for her instead. That will be a good thing. But I have an even greater goal in mind. We’ll maintain that she died the instant she was accused, and everyone who hears this will grieve for her, pity her, and excuse her actions. That’s how it goes: we don’t value the things we have until we lose them, when we suddenly rack up their value and see$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$all the virtues we were blind to when they were alive and with us. That’s how Claudio will respond. When he hears that she died from his words, his imagination will be sweetly overtaken by thoughts of her. In death, every aspect of her life will be got up more beautifully, and in his mind she will seem more moving, more delicate, and more lively even than when she was alive. Then, if he ever truly felt love, he’ll mourn and wish he hadn’t accused her—even though he believed his accu-

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: The virtue that possession would not show us$NEWLINE$Whiles it was ours. So will it fare with Claudio.$NEWLINE$When he shall hear she died upon his words,$NEWLINE$The idea of her life shall sweetly creep$NEWLINE$Into his study of imagination,$NEWLINE$And every lovely organ of her life$NEWLINE$Shall come apparelled in more precious habit,$NEWLINE$More moving, delicate and full of life,$NEWLINE$Into the eye and prospect of his soul$NEWLINE$Than when she lived indeed. Then shall he mourn,$NEWLINE$If ever love had interest in his liver,$NEWLINE$And wish he had not so accused her,$NEWLINE$No, though he thought his accusation true.$NEWLINE$Let this be so, and doubt not but success$NEWLINE$Will fashion the event in better shape$NEWLINE$Than I can lay it down in likelihood.$NEWLINE$But if all aim but this be leveled false,$NEWLINE$The supposition of the lady’s death$NEWLINE$Will quench the wonder of her infamy.$NEWLINE$And if it sort not well, you may conceal her,$NEWLINE$As best befits her wounded reputation,$NEWLINE$In some reclusive and religious life,$NEWLINE$Out of all eyes, tongues, minds, and injuries.
paragraphs.translated: sation to be true. Follow my plan, and trust that the actual events will play out even better than I am describing. And even if they don’t, at least Hero’s supposed death will stop the rumors of her infidelity. And if it doesn’t go well, then you can keep her hidden in a nunnery, the best place for someone with her kind of dirtied reputation—away from the public’s eyes, tongues, mind, and insults.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Signior Leonato, let the friar advise you.$NEWLINE$And though you know my inwardness and love$NEWLINE$Is very much unto the Prince and Claudio,$NEWLINE$Yet, by mine honor, I will deal in this$NEWLINE$As secretly and justly as your soul$NEWLINE$Should with your body.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Signior Leonato, listen to the friar’s plan. And even though you know I’m very close to the Prince and Claudio, I swear I’ll keep your counsel and deal with this secretly and justly.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Being that I flow in grief,$NEWLINE$The smallest twine may lead me.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Because I’m drowning in my grief, I’ll grab onto the smallest piece of string dangled in front of me.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$'Tis well consented. Presently away,$NEWLINE$For to strange sores strangely they strain the cure.—$NEWLINE$Come, lady, die to live. This wedding day$NEWLINE$Perhaps is but prolonged. Have patience and endure.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$This is a good agreement. Now, let’s go. A strange disease requires a strange cure. Come, lady; you must die in order to live. Hopefully, your wedding day is only postponed. Have patience and endure.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but BENEDICK andBEATRICE$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated: Everyone but BENEDICK andBEATRICE exits.$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$BEATRICE

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Lady Beatrice, have you wept all this while?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Lady Beatrice, have you been crying this entire time?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Yea, and I will weep a while longer.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Yes, and I’ll keep crying a while longer.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I will not desire that.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I don’t wish that on you.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$You have no reason. I do it freely.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$You don’t have to; I do it of my own free will.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Surely I do believe your fair cousin is wronged.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I really believe your cousin was falsely accused.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Ah, how much might the man deserve of me that would$NEWLINE$right her!
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Oh, the man who avenged her could ask anything of me!

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Is there any way to show such friendship?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Is there any way I could show such friendship to you?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$A very even way, but no such friend.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$A very clear way, but there is no friend who will undertake it.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$May a man do it?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Can a man do it?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$It is a man’s office, but not yours.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$It’s a job meant for a man, but not you.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I do love nothing in the world so well as you. Is not that$NEWLINE$strange?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$There is nothing in the world that I love as much as you. Isn’t that strange?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$As strange as the thing I know not. It were as possible for$NEWLINE$me to say I loved nothing so well as you, but believe me not,$NEWLINE$and yet I lie not, I confess nothing, nor I deny nothing. I am$NEWLINE$sorry for my cousin.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$It’s as strange as this other thing which I don’t understand. I could just as easily say that there is nothing in the world that I love as much as you. But don’t believe me—though I’m not lying. I confess nothing, and I deny nothing. I feel awful for my cousin.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$By my sword, Beatrice, thou lovest me.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$By my sword, Beatrice, you love me.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Do not swear, and eat it.
paragraphs.translated:
BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Don’t swear like that and then go back and
eat it later.$NEWLINE$eat it$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I will swear by it that you love me, and I will make him eat$NEWLINE$it that says I love not you.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I’ll swear by my
sword that you love me, too, and I’ll make any man who says that I don’t love you eat it.$NEWLINE$sword$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Will you not eat your word?
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$But you won’t eat your words?

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$With no sauce that can be devised to it. I protest I love thee.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Not with any sauce they could provide for them. I swear, I love you.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Why then, God forgive me.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Well then, God forgive me!

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$What offense, sweet Beatrice?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Why, what have you done, sweet Beatrice?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$You have stayed me in a happy hour. I was about to protest$NEWLINE$I loved you.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$You got to me first. I was about to swear that I loved you.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$And do it with all thy heart.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Then do so, with all your heart.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I love you with so much of my heart that none is left to$NEWLINE$protest.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I love you with so much of my heart that none of it is left to protest with.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Come, bid me do anything for thee.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Come, ask me to do anything for you.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Kill Claudio.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Kill Claudio.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Ha! Not for the wide world.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Ha! I wouldn’t do that for the whole wide world.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$You kill me to deny it. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Then, rejecting my request, you kill me, instead. Goodbye.$NEWLINE$me,

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE begins to exit$NEWLINE$BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE begins to exit.$NEWLINE$BEATRICE

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Tarry, sweet Beatrice.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Wait, sweet Beatrice.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I am gone, though I am here. There is no love in you. Nay,$NEWLINE$I pray you let me go.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$My body waits here, but the rest of me is gone. You don’t really love me. I beg you to let me go.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Beatrice—
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Beatrice—

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$In faith, I will go.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I swear, I’m going.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$We’ll be friends first.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Not until we part as friends.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$You dare easier be friends with me than fight with mine$NEWLINE$enemy.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$How dare you try to be my friend when you refuse to fight my enemy.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Is Claudio thine enemy?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Is Claudio your enemy?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Is he not approved in the height a villain, that hath$NEWLINE$slandered, scorned, dishonored my kinswoman? Oh, that I$NEWLINE$were a man! What, bear her in hand until they come to take$NEWLINE$hands and then, with public accusation, uncovered$NEWLINE$slander, unmitigated rancor—O God, that I were a man! I$NEWLINE$would eat his heart in the marketplace.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Hasn’t he proven himself to be a great villain—slandering, scorning, and dishonoring my cousin? Oh, I wish I were a man! He pretended that everything was fine until the moment they were exchanging vows, and then—with public accusation, blatant slander, pure hatred—Oh God, if only I were a man! I would rip his heart out in public and eat it.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Hear me, Beatrice—
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Listen to me, Beatrice—

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Talk with a man out at a window! A proper saying!
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Talking with a man outside her bedroom window! A likely story!

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Nay, but Beatrice—
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$No, but Beatrice—

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Sweet Hero, she is wronged, she is slandered, she is$NEWLINE$undone.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Sweet Hero, she’s been wronged, she’s been slandered, she’s been ruined.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Beat—
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Beat—

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Princes and counties! Surely, a princely testimony, a goodly$NEWLINE$count, Count Comfect, a sweet gallant, surely! Oh, that I$NEWLINE$were a man for his sake! Or that I had any friend would be$NEWLINE$a man for my sake! But manhood is melted into curtsies,$NEWLINE$valor into compliment, and men are only turned into$NEWLINE$tongue, and trim ones too. He is now as valiant as Hercules$NEWLINE$that only tells a lie and swears it. I cannot be a man with$NEWLINE$wishing, therefore I will die a woman with grieving.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Princes and counts! Oh, of course, it was all so proper and ceremonious—they gave a truly princely testimony. He’s a proper count, that Count Sugarplum, a sweet gentleman, for sure! Oh, if only I were a man! Or had a friend who would be a man for me! But there are no real men left. Their manliness has melted into pretty curtsies and fancy manners, and their bravery is spent on making clever compliments. All this conversing has turned men into tongues—and fancy ones, at that. The man who tells a lie and swears by it is now considered as brave as Hercules. I can’t make myself a man by wishing I were, so as a woman I’ll die, from grieving.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Tarry, good Beatrice. By this hand, I love thee.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Wait, good Beatrice. I swear by this hand that I love you.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Use it for my love some other way than swearing by it.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Don’t just swear by it; put your hand to some use that will prove you love me.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Think you in your soul the Count Claudio hath wronged$NEWLINE$Hero?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Do you honestly think, in your soul, that Claudio has wrongly accused
Hero?$NEWLINE$Hero?$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Yea, as sure as I have a thought or a soul.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Yes, as sure as I have a thought or a soul.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Enough, I am engaged. I will challenge him. I will kiss your$NEWLINE$hand, and so I leave you. By this hand, Claudio shall render$NEWLINE$me a dear account. As you hear of me, so think of me. Go$NEWLINE$comfort your cousin. I must say she is dead, and so,$NEWLINE$farewell.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$That’s enough for me, then. I’ll challenge him. I’ll kiss your hand, and with that I leave you. I swear that Claudio will pay dearly for this. Keep me in your thoughts and go comfort your cousin. I’ll go tell them that she’s dead. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter DOGBERRY,VERGES, andSEXTON, in gowns; and the Watch, withCONRADE and BORACHIO$NEWLINE$DOGBERRY,VERGES$NEWLINE$SEXTON$NEWLINE$CONRADE$NEWLINE$BORACHIO
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY, VERGES, the SEXTON (in his official gown), and theWATCHMEN enter, bringing CONRADE and BORACHIO.$NEWLINE$DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$VERGES$NEWLINE$SEXTON$NEWLINE$WATCHMEN$NEWLINE$CONRADE$NEWLINE$BORACHIO

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Is our whole dissembly appeared?
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Is our whole
dissembly here?$NEWLINE$dissembly$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: VERGES$NEWLINE$Oh, a stool and a cushion for the Sexton.
paragraphs.translated: VERGES$NEWLINE$Oh, we need a stool and a cushion for the sexton.

paragraphs.original: A stool is brought in. SEXTON sits$NEWLINE$SEXTON
paragraphs.translated: A stool is brought in. The SEXTON sits down.$NEWLINE$SEXTON

paragraphs.original: SEXTON$NEWLINE$Which be the malefactors?
paragraphs.translated: SEXTON$NEWLINE$Which ones are the malefactors?

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Marry, that am I and my partner.
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Sir, that would be me and my partner.

paragraphs.original: VERGES$NEWLINE$Nay, that’s certain; we have the exhibition to examine.
paragraphs.translated:
VERGES$NEWLINE$Yes, yes, we’ve been
exhibitioned to examine this case.$NEWLINE$exhibitioned$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SEXTON$NEWLINE$But which are the offenders that are to be examined? Let$NEWLINE$them come before Master Constable.
paragraphs.translated: SEXTON$NEWLINE$No, you’ve misunderstood me—where are the criminals whom I’m supposed to examine? Have them come in front of the master constable.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Yea, marry, let them come before me.$NEWLINE$What is your name, friend?
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Yes, indeed, bring them before me.

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO andCONRADE come forward$NEWLINE$BORACHIO$NEWLINE$CONRADE
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO and CONRADE come forward.$NEWLINE$BORACHIO$NEWLINE$CONRADE

paragraphs.original: What’s your name, friend?
paragraphs.translated: What’s your name, friend?

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Borachio.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Borachio.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Pray, write down, “Borachio.”—Yours, sirrah?
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Please, write down “Borachio.”—And yours?

paragraphs.original: CONRADE$NEWLINE$I am a gentleman, sir, and my name is Conrade.
paragraphs.translated: CONRADE$NEWLINE$I’m a gentleman, sir, and my name is Conrade.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Write down “Master Gentleman Conrade.”—Masters, do$NEWLINE$you serve God?
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Write down “Master Gentleman Conrade.”—Gentlemen, are you good Christians, and do you serve God?

paragraphs.original: CONRADE, BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Yea, sir, we hope.
paragraphs.translated: CONRADE, BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Yes, sir, we hope so.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Write down that they hope they serve God; and write God$NEWLINE$first, for God defend but God should go before such$NEWLINE$villains!—Masters, it is proved already that you are little$NEWLINE$better than false knaves, and it will go near to be thought so$NEWLINE$shortly. How answer you for yourselves?
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Write down that they hope they serve God. Oh, and write “God” first—for God forbid we put these criminals before God!—Gentlemen, it’s already been proven that you aren’t much better than lying criminals, and soon we’ll know almost for certain. How do you both plead?

paragraphs.original: CONRADE$NEWLINE$Marry, sir, we say we are none.
paragraphs.translated: CONRADE$NEWLINE$Honestly, sir, we say that we are not criminals.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$A marvelous witty fellow, I assure you, but I will go about$NEWLINE$with him.—Come you hither, sirrah, a word in your ear.$NEWLINE$Sir, I say to you it is thought you are false knaves.
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$He’s a marvelously witty fellow, no doubt, but I’ll outmaneuver him.—Come over here; I’ll whisper a word in your ear. Sir, I tell you we believe you’re both lying criminals.

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Sir, I say to you we are none.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Sir, I tell you that we are not.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Well, stand aside.—'Fore God, they are both in a ale. Have$NEWLINE$you writ down that they are none?
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Well, okay.—I swear to God, both their stories match. Have you written that down, that they aren’t criminals?

paragraphs.original: SEXTON$NEWLINE$Master Constable, you go not the way to examine. You$NEWLINE$must call forth the watch that are their accusers.
paragraphs.translated: SEXTON$NEWLINE$Master Constable, you’re going about this all wrong. First, you have to speak to the watchmen who accused them.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Yea, marry, that’s the eftest way.—Let the watch come$NEWLINE$forth. Masters, I charge you in the Prince’s name, accuse$NEWLINE$these men.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Yes, good idea; that’s the
eftest way. Bring the watchmen forward. Gentlemen, I order you in the Prince’s name to accuse these men.$NEWLINE$eftest$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FIRST WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$This man said, sir, that Don John, the Prince’s brother, was$NEWLINE$a villain.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$This man said, sir, that Don John, the Prince’s brother, was a villain.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Write down Prince John a villain. Why, this is flat perjury,$NEWLINE$to call a prince’s brother villain.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Write down that Prince John is a villain. Why, that’s flat-out
perjury—to call a prince’s brother a villain.$NEWLINE$perjury$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Master Constable—
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Master Constable—

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Pray thee, fellow, peace. I do not like thy look, I promise$NEWLINE$thee.
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Be quiet, you. I swear, I don’t like the look of you.

paragraphs.original: SEXTON$NEWLINE$(to Watch) What heard you him say else?$NEWLINE$(to Watch)
paragraphs.translated: SEXTON$NEWLINE$(to the watchmen) What else did you hear him say?$NEWLINE$(to the watchmen)

paragraphs.original: SECOND WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$Marry, that he had received a thousand ducats of Don John$NEWLINE$for accusing the Lady Hero wrongfully.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$That Don John had given him a thousand pieces of gold for wrongfully accusing the Lady Hero.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Flat burglary as ever was committed.
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$That’s burglary, that is.

paragraphs.original: VERGES$NEWLINE$Yea, by Mass, that it is.
paragraphs.translated: VERGES$NEWLINE$Yes, by God, that it is.

paragraphs.original: SEXTON$NEWLINE$What else, fellow?
paragraphs.translated: SEXTON$NEWLINE$What else did you hear?

paragraphs.original: FIRST WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$And that Count Claudio did mean upon his words to$NEWLINE$disgrace Hero before the whole assembly, and not marry$NEWLINE$her.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$I heard that Count Claudio meant to disgrace Hero in front of the whole wedding party and refuse to marry her.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$(to BORACHIO) O villain! Thou wilt be condemned into$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$everlasting redemption for this.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$(to BORACHIO) Oh, you villain! You’ll be condemned to everlasting
redemption for this!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$redemption$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SEXTON$NEWLINE$What else?
paragraphs.translated: SEXTON$NEWLINE$What else?

paragraphs.original: FIRST WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$This is all.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WATCHMAN$NEWLINE$That’s all.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SEXTON$NEWLINE$And this is more, masters, than you can deny. Prince John$NEWLINE$is this morning secretly stolen away. Hero was in this$NEWLINE$manner accused, in this very manner refused, and upon the$NEWLINE$grief of this, suddenly died.—Master Constable, let these$NEWLINE$men be bound and brought to Leonato’s. I will go before$NEWLINE$and show him their examination.
paragraphs.translated: SEXTON$NEWLINE$(to CONRADE and BORACHIO) You can’t deny this, gentlemen. This morning, Prince John secretly snuck out of Messina. Hero was accused exactly as the watchman described, and died on the spot from the grief.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Master Constable, tie up these men and bring them to Leonato’s. I’ll get there first and tell him what we found out.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Come, let them be opinioned.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Come on, let’s get them
opinioned.$NEWLINE$opinioned$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: VERGES$NEWLINE$Let them be in the hands—
paragraphs.translated: VERGES$NEWLINE$Let them be in the hands—

paragraphs.original: CONRADE$NEWLINE$Off, coxcomb!
paragraphs.translated: CONRADE$NEWLINE$Get off me, you fool!

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$God’s my life, where’s the Sexton? Let him write down the$NEWLINE$Prince’s officer “coxcomb.” Come, bind them.—Thou$NEWLINE$naughty varlet!
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Honest to God, where’s the sexton? He should write down that the Prince’s officer was called a fool. Come on, tie them up. (to CONRADE) You’re a nasty little stinker!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CONRADE$NEWLINE$Away! You are an ass, you are an ass!
paragraphs.translated: CONRADE$NEWLINE$Get away from me, you ass! You ass!

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Dost thou not suspect my place? Dost thou not suspect my$NEWLINE$years? Oh, that he were here to write me down an ass! But$NEWLINE$masters, remember that I am an ass, though it be not$NEWLINE$written down, yet forget not that I am an ass.—No, thou$NEWLINE$villain, thou art full of piety, as shall be proved upon thee by$NEWLINE$good witness. I am a wise fellow and, which is more, an$NEWLINE$officer and, which is more, a householder and, which is$NEWLINE$more, as pretty a piece of flesh as any is in Messina, and one$NEWLINE$that knows the law, go to, and a rich fellow enough, go to,$NEWLINE$and a fellow that hath had losses, and one that hath two$NEWLINE$gowns and everything handsome about him.—Bring him$NEWLINE$away.—Oh, that I had been writ down an ass!
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$How can you call me that? Don’t you suspect my office? Don’t you
suspect my age? Oh, if only the sexton were here to write down that I’m an ass! Gentlemen, remember that I am an ass; even though it’s not written down, don’t forget that I’m an ass. Oh, you’re a rotten bastard, you are. I’m a wise man and, what’s more, I’m an officer of the law and, what’s more, I’m a householder and, what’s more, I’m as handsome a hunk of meat as any in Messina. And I know the law, damn you, and I’m rich enough, damn you, and I used to have more, but I still have two robes and lots of lovely things.—Take him away!—Oh, if only the sexton had recorded that I’m an ass!$NEWLINE$suspect$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LEONATO andANTONIO$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO and ANTONIO enter.$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$If you go on thus, you will kill yourself,$NEWLINE$And ’tis not wisdom thus to second grief$NEWLINE$Against yourself.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$If you keep on the way you’ve been going, you’ll kill yourself. There’s no point in adding to your grief.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I pray thee, cease thy counsel,$NEWLINE$Which falls into mine ears as profitless$NEWLINE$As water in a sieve. Give not me counsel,$NEWLINE$Nor let no comforter delight mine ear$NEWLINE$But such a one whose wrongs do suit with mine.$NEWLINE$Bring me a father that so loved his child,$NEWLINE$Whose joy of her is overwhelmed like mine,$NEWLINE$And bid him speak of patience.$NEWLINE$Measure his woe the length and breadth of mine,$NEWLINE$And let it answer every strain for strain,$NEWLINE$As thus for thus and such a grief for such,$NEWLINE$In every lineament, branch, shape, and form.$NEWLINE$If such a one will smile and stroke his beard,$NEWLINE$Bid sorrow wag, cry “hem” when he should groan,$NEWLINE$Patch grief with proverbs, make misfortune drunk$NEWLINE$With candle-wasters, bring him yet to me$NEWLINE$And I of him will gather patience.$NEWLINE$But there is no such man. For, brother, men$NEWLINE$Can counsel and speak comfort to that grief$NEWLINE$Which they themselves not feel, but, tasting it,$NEWLINE$Their counsel turns to passion which before$NEWLINE$Would give preceptial med'cine to rage,$NEWLINE$Fetter strong madness in a silken thread,$NEWLINE$Charm ache with air, and agony with words.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Stop advising me; your words pass through my ears like water through a sieve. Don’t counsel me. Only someone who’s been wronged as I have can comfort me. Find a father who loved his child as overwhelmingly as I loved Hero and askhim to be patient. Compare the length and width of that man’s sadness against my own; match up all the complaints and strong emotions that run through our bodies. If a man who has suffered as I have gave me advice the way you do—smiling and stroking his beard, telling me to toss away my sorrow, giving speeches when he should be wailing with me, trying to heal my grief with little proverbs, spinning my head around with philosophy—then I would take his advice and be patient. But that man doesn’t exist. You can try to comfort a man who feels a pain that you have never felt, but once you feel it too, your sober advice will also turn into passion. You can’t treat madness with rules or bind up insanity with little silken threads or cure heartache with hot air or lighten agony with pat phrases.$NEWLINE$him

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: No, no, ’tis all men’s office to speak patience$NEWLINE$To those that wring under the load of sorrow,$NEWLINE$But no man’s virtue nor sufficiency$NEWLINE$To be so moral when he shall endure$NEWLINE$The like himself. Therefore give me no counsel.$NEWLINE$My griefs cry louder than advertisement.
paragraphs.translated: Every man thinks it’s his duty to advise those who are overwrought with sorrow to be patient. But no man is so moral or so strong that they can endure the same advice when they themselves are grieving. So don’t advise me. My sorrow is crying too loudly to hear what you have to say.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Therein do men from children nothing differ.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Well then you’re no better than a child.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I pray thee, peace. I will be flesh and blood,$NEWLINE$For there was never yet philosopher$NEWLINE$That could endure the toothache patiently,$NEWLINE$However they have writ the style of gods$NEWLINE$And made a push at chance and sufferance.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Please, leave me alone. I intend to be flesh and blood, not airy philosophy, for there has never yet been a philosopher who could endure a toothache patiently, even though they all write as if they had risen above human suffering and misfortune.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Yet bend not all the harm upon yourself.$NEWLINE$Make those that do offend you suffer too.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$But don’t take all that pain on yourself. Make sure the ones who have wronged you suffer too.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$There thou speak’st reason. Nay, I will do so.$NEWLINE$My soul doth tell me Hero is belied,$NEWLINE$And that shall Claudio know; so shall the Prince$NEWLINE$And all of them that thus dishonor her.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Now you’re talking. I definitely will. In my soul, I believe Hero has been falsely accused. And I’ll make sure that Claudio, the Prince, and anyone else who helped dishonor her know about it.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO andCLAUDIO$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO andCLAUDIO enter.$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Here comes the Prince and Claudio hastily.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$The Prince and Claudio are hurrying this way.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Good e'en, good e'en.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Good evening, good evening.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Good day to both of you.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Good day to both of you.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Hear you, my lords—
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Listen, my lords—

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$We have some haste, Leonato.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$We’re in a bit of a hurry, Leonato.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Some haste, my lord! Well, fare you well, my lord.$NEWLINE$Are you so hasty now? Well, all is one.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$A bit of a hurry, my lord! Well then, good bye, my lord. You’re in a hurry, are you? Well then, don’t bother.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Nay, do not quarrel with us, good old man.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Come on, don’t quarrel with us, good old man.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$If he could right himself with quarreling,$NEWLINE$Some of us would lie low.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$If it’s fighting he is after, some of us here should run and hide.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Who wrongs him?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Who has wronged him?

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Marry, thou dost wrong me, thou dissembler, thou.$NEWLINE$Nay, never lay thy hand upon thy sword.$NEWLINE$I fear thee not.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Indeed, you have wronged me, you liar. Don’t bother trying to intimidate me by putting your hand on your sword. I’m not scared of you.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Marry, beshrew my hand$NEWLINE$If it should give your age such cause of fear.$NEWLINE$In faith, my hand meant nothing to my sword.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Curse my hand if it ever threatened an old man like you. Really, I had no intention of going for my sword.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Tush, tush, man, never fleer and jest at me.$NEWLINE$I speak not like a dotard nor a fool,$NEWLINE$As under privilege of age to brag$NEWLINE$What I have done being young, or what would do$NEWLINE$Were I not old. Know, Claudio, to thy head,$NEWLINE$Thou hast so wronged mine innocent child and me$NEWLINE$That I am forced to lay my reverence by,$NEWLINE$And with gray hairs and bruise of many days$NEWLINE$Do challenge thee to trial of a man.$NEWLINE$I say thou hast belied mine innocent child.$NEWLINE$Thy slander hath gone through and through her heart,$NEWLINE$And she lies buried with her ancestors,$NEWLINE$Oh, in a tomb where never scandal slept$NEWLINE$Save this of hers, framed by thy villainy.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Damn you, don’t mock and sneer at me. I’m not a doddering old fool who brags about the things he did when he was young, and what he would do now if he weren’t so old. Claudio, I’m telling you right to your face that you have wronged me and my innocent child. I am forced to lay aside my old man’s respectability, and with my gray hairs and my aching body I challenge you to a duel. You have ruined my innocent child. Your slander has broken her heart, and now she lies buried with her ancestors in a tomb—ancestors who had never been tainted by scandal until you caused one with your wickedness.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$My villainy?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$My wickedness?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Thine, Claudio, thine, I say.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Yours, Claudio, yours, I say.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$You say not right, old man.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$You’ve got it wrong, old man.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$My lord, my lord,$NEWLINE$I’ll prove it on his body if he dare,$NEWLINE$Despite his nice fence and his active practice,$NEWLINE$His May of youth and bloom of lustihood.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$My lord, if he dares to accept my challenge, I’ll beat him and prove he’s guilty. I’ll beat him despite his fancy fencing techniques and all the practicing he does, despite his youth and manliness.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Away! I will not have to do with you.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Not a chance! I’ll have nothing to do with you.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Canst thou so daff me? Thou hast killed my child.$NEWLINE$If thou kill’st me, boy, thou shalt kill a man.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$You think you can get rid of me that easily? You killed my child. Take on someone your own size: if you kill me, boy, you’ll have killed a man.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$He shall kill two of us, and men indeed,$NEWLINE$But that’s no matter. Let him kill one first.$NEWLINE$Win me and wear me! Let him answer me.—$NEWLINE$Come, follow me, boy. Come, sir boy, come, follow me.$NEWLINE$Sir boy, I’ll whip you from your foining fence,$NEWLINE$Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$He’ll have to kill both of us, and indeed we’re both men. But let him start off easy by killing one of us. Come on—kill me and brag about it! Let me at him. Come on, come after me, little boy. Come on and get me. Little man, I’ll be right in your face with my sword. I will, as surely as I am a gentleman.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Brother—
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Brother—

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Content yourself. God knows I loved my niece,$NEWLINE$And she is dead, slandered to death by villains$NEWLINE$That dare as well answer a man indeed$NEWLINE$As I dare take a serpent by the tongue.—$NEWLINE$Boys, apes, braggarts, jacks, milksops!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Quiet. God knows I loved my niece, and now she’s dead—slandered to death by cowards who would just as likely fight a real man as I would grab a poisonous snake by the tongue. Boys, fools, braggers, scoundrels, babies!

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Brother Anthony—
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Brother Anthony—

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Hold you content. What, man! I know them, yea,$NEWLINE$And what they weigh, even to the utmost scruple—$NEWLINE$Scrambling, outfacing, fashion-monging boys,$NEWLINE$That lie and cog and flout, deprave and slander,$NEWLINE$Go anticly and show outward hideousness,$NEWLINE$And speak off half a dozen dang'rous words$NEWLINE$How they might hurt their enemies, if they durst,$NEWLINE$And this is all.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Hold your peace. I know their kind, I know them exactly. They’re petulant, disrespectful, fashion-crazy boys who lie and cheat and mock, defame and slander. They walk around in outlandish outfits, pretending to be brave and wild and saying a few inflammatory things about how they’ll hurt their enemies—and that’s all they do.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$But brother Anthony—
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$But brother Anthony—

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Come, ’tis no matter.$NEWLINE$Do not you meddle. Let me deal in this.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Don’t, it’s no big deal. Don’t bother with it. Let me deal with this.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience.$NEWLINE$My heart is sorry for your daughter’s death,$NEWLINE$But, on my honor, she was charged with nothing$NEWLINE$But what was true and very full of proof.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Gentlemen, we won’t stay here and anger you further. I’m sorry about your daughter’s death, but I swear our accusations were true, and backed up with proof.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$My lord, my lord—
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$My lord, my lord—

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I will not hear you.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I don’t want to hear any more about it.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$No? Come, brother; away! I will be heard.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$No? Come on, brother! I’m determined to be heard by someone.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$And shall, or some of us will smart for it.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$And you will be, or some people here will suffer for it.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt LEONATO andANTONIO$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO and ANTONIO exit.$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO

paragraphs.original: Enter BENEDICK$NEWLINE$BENEDICK
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK enters.$NEWLINE$BENEDICK

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$See, see, here comes the man we went to seek.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Look, here comes just the man we were looking for.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Now, Signior, what news?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$What’s up, mister?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$(to DON PEDRO) Good day, my lord.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$(to DON PEDRO) Hello, my lord.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Welcome, Signior. You are almost come to part almost a$NEWLINE$fray.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Welcome, sir. You just missed a fight that was barely$NEWLINE$avoided.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$We had like to have had our two noses snapped off with two$NEWLINE$old men without teeth.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$We were about to have our noses snapped off by two$NEWLINE$old men with no teeth.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Leonato and his brother. What think’st thou? Had we$NEWLINE$fought, I doubt we should have been too young for them.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Leonato and his brother. What do you think? I think$NEWLINE$if we had fought, we would have proven too young and$NEWLINE$strong for them after all.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$In a false quarrel there is no true valor. I came to seek you$NEWLINE$both.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$There’s no bravery in an unfair fight. I’ve been look-$NEWLINE$ing for you two.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$We have been up and down to seek thee, for we are high-$NEWLINE$proof melancholy and would fain have it beaten away. Wilt$NEWLINE$thou use thy wit?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$We’ve been looking for you, too. We’re really$NEWLINE$depressed. Will you tell us some jokes to beat our sad-$NEWLINE$ness away?

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$It is in my scabbard. Shall I draw it?
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK$NEWLINE$My wit’s in my
scabbard. Should I unsheath it?$NEWLINE$scabbard$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Dost thou wear thy wit by thy side?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$You wear your wit next to you?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Never any did so, though very many have been beside their$NEWLINE$wit. I will bid thee draw, as we do the minstrels: draw to$NEWLINE$pleasure us.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$No one carries their wit next to them, though some$NEWLINE$people are
beside their wit. Come on, draw your wit,$NEWLINE$beside their wit$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$just as musicians draw their bows across the instru-$NEWLINE$ments: draw for our pleasure.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$As I am an honest man, he looks pale.—Art thou sick, or$NEWLINE$angry?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Look: Benedick is so pale—are you sick, or angry?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(to BENEDICK) What, courage, man! What though care$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$killed a cat? Thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(to BENEDICK) Buck up, man!
Care may have killed the$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Care$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$cat, but you are strong enough to kill care. Lighten up.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Sir, I shall meet your wit in the career, an you charge it$NEWLINE$against me. I pray you, choose another subject.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Sir, don’t even try to beat me in a battle of wits. I’ll$NEWLINE$meet all your attacks, even if you come charging at me$NEWLINE$with a lance at full gallop. Choose another tack.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(to DON PEDRO) Nay, then, give him another staff. This last$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$was broke 'cross.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(to DON PEDRO) That was poor, Benedick! Give him$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$another lance—that last one got broken in half.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$By this light, he changes more and more. I think he be angry$NEWLINE$indeed.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Lord, he seems to be getting paler by the minute. I$NEWLINE$think he really is angry.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$If he be, he knows how to turn his girdle.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$If he is, that’s his problem.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Shall I speak a word in your ear?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Can I have a word with you privately?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$God bless me from a challenge!
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$God forbid he wants to challenge me!

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$(aside to CLAUDIO) You are a villain. I jest not. I will make it$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$good how you dare, with what you dare, and when you$NEWLINE$dare. Do me right, or I will protest your cowardice. You$NEWLINE$have killed a sweet lady, and her death shall fall heavy on$NEWLINE$you. Let me hear from you.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only CLAUDIOcan hear) You are a vil-$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)$NEWLINE$lain. I’m not kidding. I challenge you however you$NEWLINE$like—with whatever weapons you choose, and whe-$NEWLINE$never you want. Meet this challenge, or I’ll say that$NEWLINE$you’re a coward. You’ve killed an innocent woman,$NEWLINE$and you’re going to pay dearly for her death. What do you say?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Well, I will meet you, so I may have good cheer.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I’ll be there, and I’ll enjoy myself.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$What, a feast, a feast?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$What, are we having a feast?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I' faith, I thank him. He hath bid me to a calf’s head and a$NEWLINE$capon, the which if I do not carve most curiously, say my$NEWLINE$knife’s naught. Shall I not find a woodcock too?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Yes, we are. He has invited me to have a
calf’s head and a capon. He says if I don’t carve them up and serve them elegantly, he’ll declare I have no skills with a knife. Should I go get us a woodcock, too?$NEWLINE$calf’s head and a capon$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Sir, your wit ambles well; it goes easily.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Sir, you have a very slow, rambling wit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$I’ll tell thee how Beatrice praised thy wit he other day. I$NEWLINE$said thou hadst a fine wit. “True,” said she, “a fine little$NEWLINE$one.” “No,” said I, “a great wit.” “Right,” says she, “a great$NEWLINE$gross one.” “Nay,” said I, “a good wit.” “Just,” said she, “it$NEWLINE$hurts nobody.” “Nay,” said I, “the gentleman is wise.”$NEWLINE$“Certain,” said she, “a wise gentleman.” “Nay,” said I, “he$NEWLINE$hath the tongues.” “That I believe,” said she, “for he swore$NEWLINE$a thing to me on Monday night, which he forswore on$NEWLINE$Tuesday morning; there’s a double tongue, there’s two$NEWLINE$tongues.” Thus did she an hour together transshape thy$NEWLINE$particular virtues. Yet at last she concluded with a sigh,$NEWLINE$thou wast the proper’st man in Italy.
paragraphs.translated:
DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Benedick, Beatrice praised your wit the other day. I said you had a fine wit. “True,” she said, “a fine little one.” “No,” I said, “a huge wit.” “Right,” she said, “a hugely awful one.” “No,” I said, “he has a good wit.” “Exactly,” she said, “it’s good and mild; it doesn’t hurt anyone.” “No,” I said, “Benedick is wise.” “He is certainly,” she said,
“a wise gentleman.”“No,” I said, “he can speak many languages:” “I can believe that,” she said, “because he swore one thing to me on Monday night and took it back on Tuesday morning. He spoke two languages then.” She turned all your virtues into vices just about an hour ago. But in the end she sighed and admitted you were the handsomest man in Italy.$NEWLINE$“a wise gentleman.”$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$For the which she wept heartily and said she cared not.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$She cried a lot at that, and said she didn’t care.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Yea, that she did. But yet for all that, an if she did not hate$NEWLINE$him deadly, she would love him dearly. The old man’s$NEWLINE$daughter told us all.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$That she did. And yet for all that, if she didn’t hate him to death, she’d love him to death. Leonato’s daughter had told us everything.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$All, all. And, moreover, God saw him when he was hid in$NEWLINE$the garden.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Absolutely everything. And, moreover, God saw Benedick when he was hid in the garden.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$But when shall we set the savage bull’s horns on the sensible$NEWLINE$Benedick’s head?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$But when exactly will we see Benedick married?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Yea, and text underneath: “Here dwells Benedick the$NEWLINE$married man”?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Yes, with the sign underneath him that says: “Here lives Benedick the married man”?

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Fare you well, boy. You know my mind. I will leave you now$NEWLINE$to your gossip-like humor. You break jests as braggarts do$NEWLINE$their blades, which, God be thanked, hurt not.—My lord,$NEWLINE$for your many courtesies I thank you. I must discontinue$NEWLINE$your company.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Goodbye, boy. You know what I intend. I’ll leave you now to chatter and gossip like an old woman. The wit you flaunt is like a blunt sword—it can’t hurt anyone, thank God.—My lord, I thank you for your many kindnesses. I’m leaving your court now.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Your brother the Bastard is fled from Messina. You have$NEWLINE$among you killed a sweet and innocent lady. For my Lord$NEWLINE$Lackbeard there, he and I shall meet, and till then peace be$NEWLINE$with him.
paragraphs.translated: Your brother Don John the Bastard has run away from Messina. The three of you have killed a sweet, innocent woman. Lord Babyface over there will meet me in a duel, and good luck to him then.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$He is in earnest.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$He’s serious.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$In most profound earnest, and, I’ll warrant you, for the love$NEWLINE$of Beatrice.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Very serious, and I’m sure it’s because of Beatrice.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$And hath challenged thee?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$And he challenged you to a duel?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Most sincerely.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$He did, very sincerely.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$What a pretty thing man is when he goes in his doublet and$NEWLINE$hose and leaves off his wit!
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$What a strange sight—a man who has put on all his fancy clothes but forgotten his brain at home!

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$He is then a giant to an ape; but then is an ape a doctor to$NEWLINE$such a man.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$A guy like that is bigger than an ape, but the ape could be his doctor, it’s so much smarter.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$But soft you, let me be. Pluck up, my heart, and be sad. Did$NEWLINE$he not say my brother was fled?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$But wait a minute. Let me gather my wits and get serious here. Didn’t he say my brother has run away?

paragraphs.original: Enter DOGBERRY,VERGES, and the Watch, with CONRADE and BORACHIO$NEWLINE$DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$VERGES$NEWLINE$CONRADE$NEWLINE$BORACHIO
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY, VERGES, and the WATCHMEN enter with CONRADE and BORACHIO.$NEWLINE$DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$VERGES$NEWLINE$WATCHMEN$NEWLINE$CONRADE$NEWLINE$BORACHIO

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Come you, sir. If justice cannot tame you, she shall ne'er$NEWLINE$weigh more reasons in her balance. Nay, an you be a cursing$NEWLINE$hypocrite once, you must be looked to.
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Come on, you. If they let you off, then we’ll have to assume that Lady Justice has lost all her power. Since you are a lying hypocrite, we must look after you.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$How now? Two of my brother’s men bound! Borachio one!
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$What’s this? Two of my brother’s men, all tied up! And Borachio is one of them!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Hearken after their offense, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Find out what they’re being held for.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Officers, what offense have these men done?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Officers, what crime have these men committed?

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Marry, sir, they have committed false report; moreover,$NEWLINE$they have spoken untruths; secondarily, they are slanders;$NEWLINE$sixth and lastly, they have belied a lady; thirdly, they have$NEWLINE$verified unjust things; and, to conclude, they are lying$NEWLINE$knaves.
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Well sir, they’ve lied; moreover, they have said things that were not true; secondarily, they are slanderers; sixth and lastly, they have falsely accused a lady; thirdly, they have confirmed things that did not in fact happen; and, in conclusion, they are lying scoundrels.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$First, I ask thee what they have done; thirdly, I ask thee$NEWLINE$what’s their offense; sixth and lastly, why they are$NEWLINE$committed; and, to conclude, what you lay to their charge.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$First, I ask you what they’ve done; thirdly, I ask you what offense they’re charged with; sixth and lastly, I ask you why they’ve been committed here; and, in conclusion, I ask what they’re accused of.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Rightly reasoned, and in his own division; and, by my$NEWLINE$troth, there’s one meaning well suited.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Nicely done, and organized in just the way he’ll understand. My God, he manages to say the same thing six different ways.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$(to BORACHIO and CONRADE) Who have you offended,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$masters, that you are thus bound to your answer? This$NEWLINE$learned constable is too cunning to be understood. What’s$NEWLINE$your offense?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$(to BORACHIO and CONRADE) What have you done, gentlemen? This educated constable is too brilliant for me to understand. What is your crime?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Sweet Prince, let me go no farther to mine answer. Do you$NEWLINE$hear me, and let this count kill me. I have deceived even your$NEWLINE$very eyes. What your wisdoms could not discover, these$NEWLINE$shallow fools have brought to light, who in the night$NEWLINE$overheard me confessing to this man how Don John your$NEWLINE$brother incensed me to slander the Lady Hero, how you$NEWLINE$were brought into the orchard and saw me court Margaret in$NEWLINE$Hero’s garments, how you disgraced her when you should$NEWLINE$marry her. My villainy they have upon record, which I had$NEWLINE$rather seal with my death than repeat over to my shame. The$NEWLINE$lady is dead upon mine and my master’s false accusation.$NEWLINE$And, briefly, I desire nothing but the reward of a villain.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Prince, I won’t wait for my trial: listen to my story, and let the count kill me now. I tricked your own eyes. These stupid fools have uncovered what you in all your wisdom could not. They heard me confess to Conrade how Don John, your brother, prompted me to slander Hero—how you came to the orchard and saw me making sexual advances toward Margaret, who was disguised as Hero; how you disgraced Hero when you should have married her. They’ve recorded my crimes, and I would rather die than have to retell this shameful story. The lady has died because of the false accusations of me and my master. I desire nothing now but a criminal’s punishment.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$(to CLAUDIO) Runs not this speech like iron through your$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$blood?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$(to CLAUDIO) Doesn’t this make your blood run cold?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I have drunk poison whiles he uttered it.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$His words are like poison to me.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$(to BORACHIO) But did my brother set thee on to this?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$(to BORACHIO) But did my brother prompt you to do all this?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Yea, and paid me richly for the practice of it.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Yes, and paid me well for doing it.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$He is composed and framed of treachery,$NEWLINE$And fled he is upon this villainy.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$He is made of treachery, and has run away to avoid his crimes.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Sweet Hero, now thy image doth appear$NEWLINE$In the rare semblance that I loved it first.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Sweet Hero; when I imagine you now, you seem as beautiful as you did when I first loved you.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Come, bring away the plaintiffs. By this time our sexton$NEWLINE$hath reformed Signior Leonato of the matter. And,$NEWLINE$masters, do not forget to specify, when time and place shall$NEWLINE$serve, that I am an ass.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Come, take away the
plaintiffs. By now the sexton will have reformed Signior Leonato of the matter. (to CLAUDIO and DON PEDRO) And, gentlemen, please do not forget to specify, whenever it is convenient, that I am an ass.$NEWLINE$plaintiffs$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: VERGES$NEWLINE$Here, here comes Master Signior Leonato, and the Sexton$NEWLINE$too.
paragraphs.translated: VERGES$NEWLINE$Here comes Master Signior Leonato with the sexton.

paragraphs.original: Enter LEONATO andANTONIO, with the SEXTON$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$SEXTON
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO and ANTONIO enter with the SEXTON.$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$SEXTON

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Which is the villain? Let me see his eyes,$NEWLINE$That, when I note another man like him,$NEWLINE$I may avoid him. Which of these is he?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Which one of them did it? Let me see what he looks like, so when I see another man who resembles him, I’ll know to avoid him. Which one is it?

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$If you would know your wronger, look on me.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$If you want to see your deceiver, then look at me.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Art thou the slave that with thy breath hast killed$NEWLINE$Mine innocent child?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Are you the slave who, with your slanderous words, killed my innocent child?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Yea, even I alone.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$Yes, I am the one.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$No, not so, villain, thou beliest thyself.$NEWLINE$Here stand a pair of honorable men—$NEWLINE$A third is fled—that had a hand in it.—$NEWLINE$I thank you, princes, for my daughter’s death.$NEWLINE$Record it with your high and worthy deeds.$NEWLINE$'Twas bravely done, if you bethink you of it.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$No, villain, but you didn’t work alone. (indicating CLAUDIO and DON PEDRO) For here are two noblemen —the third has run away—who helped you. (to CLAUDIO and DON PEDRO) Thank you, gentlemen, for my daughter’s death. Make a note of it on your long lists of righteous and worthy deeds. It was very brave of you.$NEWLINE$(indicating$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I know not how to pray your patience,$NEWLINE$Yet I must speak. Choose your revenge yourself.$NEWLINE$Impose me to what penance your invention$NEWLINE$Can lay upon my sin. Yet sinned I not$NEWLINE$But in mistaking.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I don’t know how to ask you for forgiveness, but I have to say something. Choose your revenge. Punish me through any means you can devise, though I sinned by mistake.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$By my soul, nor I,$NEWLINE$And yet to satisfy this good old man$NEWLINE$I would bend under any heavy weight$NEWLINE$That he’ll enjoin me to.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Me too—but to satisfy this good old man, I too will bear any punishment he gives me.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I cannot bid you bid my daughter live—$NEWLINE$That were impossible—but, I pray you both,$NEWLINE$Possess the people in Messina here$NEWLINE$How innocent she died. And if your love$NEWLINE$Can labor ought in sad invention,$NEWLINE$Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb$NEWLINE$And sing it to her bones. Sing it tonight.$NEWLINE$Tomorrow morning come you to my house,$NEWLINE$And since you could not be my son-in-law,$NEWLINE$Be yet my nephew. My brother hath a daughter,$NEWLINE$Almost the copy of my child that’s dead,$NEWLINE$And she alone is heir to both of us.$NEWLINE$Give her the right you should have given her cousin,$NEWLINE$And so dies my revenge.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I can’t ask you to make my daughter live—that’s impossible—but I beg you both to tell the people of Messina that she was innocent when she died. And if your love can produce something from its sadness, write a poem for her; hang it on her grave and sing it to her bones. Sing it tonight. Then come to my house tomorrow morning, and since you couldn’t be my son-in-law, be my nephew instead. My brother has a daughter who looks exactly like Hero; this girl is heir to both our estates. Marry her as you should have married her cousin, and I will let my revenge die.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$O noble sir!$NEWLINE$Your overkindness doth wring tears from me.$NEWLINE$I do embrace your offer; and dispose$NEWLINE$For henceforth of poor Claudio.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Oh, noble sir! Your overwhelming kindness makes me weep. I willingly accept your offer and put my future in your hands.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Tomorrow then I will expect your coming.$NEWLINE$Tonight I take my leave. This naughty man$NEWLINE$Shall face to face be brought to Margaret,$NEWLINE$Who I believe was packed in all this wrong,$NEWLINE$Hired to it by your brother.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I will see you tomorrow, then. Now I have to leave. This wicked man will be brought face to face with Margaret, who I believe was hired by Don John to take part in this plot.

paragraphs.original: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$No, by my soul, she was not,$NEWLINE$Nor knew not what she did when she spoke to me,$NEWLINE$But always hath been just and virtuous$NEWLINE$In any thing that I do know by her.
paragraphs.translated: BORACHIO$NEWLINE$No, she wasn’t, and she didn’t know anything about it. She has always been honest and good.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$(to LEONATO) Moreover, sir, which indeed is not under$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$white and black, this plaintiff here, the offender, did call me$NEWLINE$ass. I beseech you, let it be remembered in his punishment.$NEWLINE$And also the watch heard them talk of one Deformed. They$NEWLINE$say he wears a key in his ear and a lock hanging by it and$NEWLINE$borrows money in God’s name, the which he hath used so$NEWLINE$long and never paid that now men grow hard-hearted and$NEWLINE$will lend nothing for God’s sake. Pray you, examine him$NEWLINE$upon that point.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$(to LEONATO) Also, sir, this hasn’t been put down in writing, but I should let you know that this
plaintiff here, the criminal, did in fact call me an ass. Please remember that when you’re punishing him. Plus, the watchmen heard the criminals talking about some man named
Deformed. They say that he has an earring made out of a key, with a lock hanging from it. Apparently, he borrows money from people in the name of God and then never pays it back, which angers everyone so much that they now refuse to fund anything in the name of God. Make sure you ask him about this.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$plaintiff$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$Deformed$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I thank thee for thy care and honest pains.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Thank you for all your efforts.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$Your worship speaks like a most thankful and reverent$NEWLINE$youth, and I praise God for you.
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$You speak like a very thankful and respectful boy, and may God bless you.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$(giving him money) There’s for thy pains.$NEWLINE$(giving him money)
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$(giving DOGBERRY money) This is for your trouble.$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$money)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$God save the foundation!
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$God save the charitable organization!

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Go, I discharge thee of thy prisoner, and I thank thee.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Go, you’re relieved of your duty. Thank you.

paragraphs.original: DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$I leave an arrant knave with your Worship, which I beseech$NEWLINE$your Worship to correct yourself, for the example of others.$NEWLINE$God keep your Worship! I wish your Worship well. God$NEWLINE$restore you to health! I humbly give you leave to depart, and$NEWLINE$if a merry meeting may be wished, God prohibit it!—$NEWLINE$Come, neighbor.
paragraphs.translated:
DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$I leave a slimy bastard with you, your Worship, for you to punish and make an example of. God bless your Worship! I wish you well. I hope that God restores you to health. I will humbly let you go now, God
prohibiting we will meet again in the future.—Come on, man.$NEWLINE$prohibiting$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exeunt DOGBERRY andVERGES$NEWLINE$DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$VERGES
paragraphs.translated: DOGBERRY and VERGES exit.$NEWLINE$DOGBERRY$NEWLINE$VERGES

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Until tomorrow morning, lords, farewell.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$I’ll see you tomorrow morning, gentlemen.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Farewell, my lords. We look for you tomorrow.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Goodbye, gentlemen. We’ll see you tomorrow.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$We will not fail.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$We’ll be there.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Tonight I’ll mourn with Hero.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I will mourn Hero tonight.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$(to the Watch)$NEWLINE$(to the Watch)$NEWLINE$Bring you these fellows on.—We’ll talk with Margaret,$NEWLINE$How her acquaintance grew with this lewd fellow.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$(to the watchmen) Bring these criminals with us. We’ll go talk to Margaret, to see how she got involved with this worthless man.$NEWLINE$(to the watchmen)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter BENEDICK andMARGARET$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$MARGARET
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK andMARGARET enter.$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$MARGARET

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Pray thee, sweet Mistress Margaret, deserve well at my$NEWLINE$hands by helping me to the speech of Beatrice.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Please Margaret, help me write this poem for Beatrice.

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Will you then write me a sonnet in praise of my beauty?
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Afterward, will you write a sonnet for me, praising my beauty?

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$In so high a style, Margaret, that no man living shall come$NEWLINE$over it, for in most comely truth thou deservest it.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I’ll write you such a glorious sonnet, Margaret, that no man will ever be able to come over it. You certainly deserve it.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$To have no man come over me! Why, shall I always keep$NEWLINE$below stairs?
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET$NEWLINE$No man will come
over me! What a life that would be!$NEWLINE$over me$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Thy wit is as quick as the greyhound’s mouth; it catches.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Your wit is as quick as a greyhound’s jaws—it catches whatever it goes after.

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$And yours as blunt as the fencer’s foils, which hit but hurt$NEWLINE$not.
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$And your wit is as blunt as a practice sword, with its dull tip; it hits people but doesn’t hurt them.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$A most manly wit, Margaret, it will not hurt a woman. And$NEWLINE$so, I pray thee, call Beatrice. I give thee the bucklers.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK$NEWLINE$It’s just that my wit is very gentlemanly, Margaret, and refuses to hurt a woman. Now please, tell Beatrice to come out. I admit defeat; I give you the
bucklers.$NEWLINE$bucklers$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Give us the swords; we have bucklers of our own.
paragraphs.translated:
MARGARET$NEWLINE$No, you should give a woman your sword—we have our own
bucklers!$NEWLINE$bucklers$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$If you use them, Margaret, you must put in the pikes with$NEWLINE$a vice, and they are dangerous weapons for maids.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Watch out, though, Margaret—virgins shouldn’t be brandishing their bucklers around.

paragraphs.original: MARGARET$NEWLINE$Well, I will call Beatrice to you, who I think hath legs.
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET$NEWLINE$I’ll go get Beatrice for you, who can walk here by herself—she has legs.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$And therefore will come.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$So that means she’ll come.

paragraphs.original: Exit MARGARET$NEWLINE$MARGARET
paragraphs.translated: MARGARET exits.$NEWLINE$MARGARET

paragraphs.original: (sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$The god of love,$NEWLINE$The god of love$NEWLINE$That sits above,$NEWLINE$That sits above$NEWLINE$And knows me, and knows me,$NEWLINE$And knows me, and knows me$NEWLINE$How pitiful I deserve—$NEWLINE$How pitiful I deserve$NEWLINE$I mean in singing. But in loving, Leander the good swimmer, Troilus the first employer of panders, and a whole bookful of these quondam carpetmongers, whose names yet run smoothly in the even road of a blank verse, why, they were never so truly turned over and over as my poor self in love. Marry, I cannot show it in rhyme. I have tried. I can find out no rhyme to “lady” but “baby”—an innocent rhyme; for “scorn,” “horn”—a hard rhyme; for, “school,” “fool”—a babbling rhyme; very ominous endings. No, I was not born under a rhyming planet, nor I cannot woo in festival terms.
paragraphs.translated:
(singing)$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$The god of love$NEWLINE$The god of love$NEWLINE$He sits in heaven above$NEWLINE$He sits in heaven above$NEWLINE$And he knows me, he knows me$NEWLINE$And he knows me, he knows me$NEWLINE$He knows how much pity I deserve—$NEWLINE$He knows how much pity I deserve—$NEWLINE$I’m really a pitiful singer. But as a lover, well, that’s another story. Take
Leander, Troilus, or an entire book’s worth of those legendary lover–boys, whose names sound so smooth and nice in a line of verse—not one of them has been driven as crazy by love as I have been. But I can’t prove it in a poem. I have tried. I can’t think of any rhyme for “lady” but “baby,” which is a childish rhyme. The only rhyme for “scorn” I can come up with is
“horn”—a bit off for a love poem. Nothing rhymes with “school” but “fool,” and that’s a ridiculous jingle. These are all very unpromising line endings. No, I wasn’t destined to be a poet, and I can’t woo a lady with pretty words.$NEWLINE$Leander, Troilus$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$“horn”$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter BEATRICE$NEWLINE$BEATRICE
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE enters.$NEWLINE$BEATRICE

paragraphs.original: Sweet Beatrice, wouldst thou come when I called thee?
paragraphs.translated: Beatrice, have you come because I called for you?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Yea, Signior, and depart when you bid me.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Yes, sir, and I’ll leave when you ask me to.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Oh , stay but till then!
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Oh, well, stay till then!

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$“Then” is spoken. Fare you well now. And yet, ere I go, let$NEWLINE$me go with that I came, which is, with knowing what hath$NEWLINE$passed between you and Claudio.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$There—you said “then.” So I’ll leave now. But before I go, let me get what I came for. What happened between you and Claudio?

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Only foul words, and thereupon I will kiss thee.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I spoke angry, foul words to him, and with that I will kiss you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Foul words is but foul wind, and foul wind is but foul$NEWLINE$breath, and foul breath is noisome. Therefore I will depart$NEWLINE$unkissed.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$If you had foul words in your mouth, then your breath must be foul, and foul breath is nauseating. Thus, I’ll leave without being kissed.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Thou hast frighted the word out of his right sense, so$NEWLINE$forcible is thy wit. But I must tell thee plainly, Claudio$NEWLINE$undergoes my challenge, and either I must shortly hear$NEWLINE$from him, or I will subscribe him a coward. And I pray thee$NEWLINE$now tell me, for which of my bad parts didst thou first fall$NEWLINE$in love with me?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Your wit is so forceful, it frightens the very meaning out of your words. But I will tell you this very plainly: I have challenged Claudio, and either he’ll accept the challenge or admit he’s a coward. Now, tell me—which of my bad qualities did you fall in love with first?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$For them all together, which maintained so politic a state of$NEWLINE$evil that they will not admit any good part to intermingle$NEWLINE$with them. But for which of my good parts did you first$NEWLINE$suffer love for me?
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$With all of them at once: they work together to create such an entirely evil person that no good ever manages to enter the mix. But tell me—which of my good qualities first made you suffer love for me?

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Suffer love! A good epithet! I do suffer love indeed, for I$NEWLINE$love thee against my will.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Suffer love! That’s a good way of putting it. I do suffer love, because I love you against my will.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$In spite of your heart, I think. Alas, poor heart, if you spite$NEWLINE$it for my sake, I will spite it for yours, for I will never love$NEWLINE$that which my riend hates.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$You love me in spite of your heart, I think. If you spite your heart for my sake, then I will spite it for yours. I will never love the thing my friend hates.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Thou and I are too wise to woo peaceably.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$You and I are too wise to woo each other peacefully.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$It appears not in this confession. There’s not one wise man$NEWLINE$among twenty that will praise himself.
