paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$It’s said that no truly wise man will praise himself. If you say that you are wise, it’s likely you’re not.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$An old, an old instance, Beatrice, that lived in the lime of$NEWLINE$good neighbors. If a man do not erect in this age his own$NEWLINE$tomb ere he dies, he shall live no longer in monument than$NEWLINE$the bell rings and the widow weeps.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$That’s an old proverb, Beatrice, from the time when neighbors praised each other. In this day and age, if a man doesn’t erect his own monument before he dies, he won’t be remembered past the funeral bell’s ringing and his widow’s crying.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$And how long is that, think you?
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Exactly how long is that, do you think?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Question: why, an hour in clamor and a quarter in rheum.$NEWLINE$Therefore is it most expedient for the wise, if Don Worm,$NEWLINE$his conscience, find no impediment to the contrary, to be$NEWLINE$the trumpet of his own virtues, as I am to myself. So much$NEWLINE$for praising myself, who, I myself will bear witness, is$NEWLINE$praiseworthy. An now tell me, how doth your cousin?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$About an hour for the ringing and fifteen minutes for the crying. That’s why it’s better for wise men to trumpet their own virtues, like I do. That’s why I praise myself, who—if I do say so myself—is quite praiseworthy. But tell me, how is your cousin?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Very ill.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$She’s very sick.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$And how do you?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$And how are you?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Very ill, too.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I’m very sick, too.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Serve God, love me, and mend. There will I leave you too,$NEWLINE$for here comes one in haste.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Have faith, love me, and you will get better. And that’s where I’ll end, because someone is hurrying this way.

paragraphs.original: Enter URSULA$NEWLINE$URSULA
paragraphs.translated: URSULA enters.$NEWLINE$URSULA

paragraphs.original: URSULA$NEWLINE$Madam, you must come to your uncle. Yonder’s old coil at$NEWLINE$home. It is proved my Lady Hero hath been falsely$NEWLINE$accused, the Prince and Claudio mightily abused, and Don$NEWLINE$John is the author of all, who is fled and gone. Will you$NEWLINE$come presently?
paragraphs.translated: URSULA$NEWLINE$Madam, you have to go to your uncle’s. There’s a huge racket going on there. It’s been proven that Lady Hero is innocent, that the Prince and Claudio have been utterly deceived, and that Don John—who has run away—is the source of all the trouble. Will you come immediately?

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Will you go hear this news, Signior?
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Will you come with me to hear this news, sir?

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I will live in thy heart, die in thy lap, and be buried in thy$NEWLINE$eyes—and moreover, I will go with thee to thy uncle’s.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I will live in your heart, die in your lap, and be buried in your eyes—and, what’s more, I will go with you to your uncle’s.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, three or four LORDS with tapers, and musicians$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$LORDS
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDROand CLAUDIO enter with three or four LORDS carrying candles, and musicians.$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$LORDS

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Is this the monument of Leonato?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Is this the family tomb of Leonato?

paragraphs.original: FIRST LORD$NEWLINE$It is, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST LORD$NEWLINE$It is, my lord.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(reading an epitaph)$NEWLINE$(reading an epitaph)$NEWLINE$Done to death by slanderous tongues$NEWLINE$Was the Hero that here lies.$NEWLINE$Death, in guerdon of her wrongs,$NEWLINE$Gives her fame which never dies.$NEWLINE$So the life that died with shame$NEWLINE$Lives in death with glorious fame.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(reading an epitaph)$NEWLINE$(reading an epitaph)$NEWLINE$Here lies Hero,$NEWLINE$The heroic maiden killed by slanderous words.$NEWLINE$To repay her for her troubles, Death$NEWLINE$Gives her undying fame.$NEWLINE$So the life that died with shame$NEWLINE$Lives on with fame.

paragraphs.original: Hangs the scroll
paragraphs.translated: (he hangs the scroll)

paragraphs.original: Hang thou there upon the tomb,$NEWLINE$Praising her when I am dumb.$NEWLINE$Now, music, sound, and sing your solemn hymn.$NEWLINE$(Song)$NEWLINE$(Song)$NEWLINE$Pardon, goddess of the night,$NEWLINE$Pardon, goddess of the night$NEWLINE$Those that slew thy virgin knight,$NEWLINE$Those that slew thy virgin knight$NEWLINE$For the which with songs of woe$NEWLINE$For the which with songs of woe$NEWLINE$Round about her tomb they go.$NEWLINE$Round about her tomb they go$NEWLINE$Midnight, assist our moan.$NEWLINE$Midnight, assist our moan$NEWLINE$Help us to sigh and groan$NEWLINE$Help us to sigh and groan$NEWLINE$Heavily, heavily.$NEWLINE$Heavily, heavily$NEWLINE$Graves, yawn and yield your dead,$NEWLINE$Graves, yawn and yield your dead$NEWLINE$Till death be utterèd,$NEWLINE$Till death be utterèd$NEWLINE$Heavily, heavily.$NEWLINE$Heavily, heavily
paragraphs.translated:
This epitaph will hang here forever,$NEWLINE$Continuing to praise Hero after I die.$NEWLINE$Now start the music, and sing the solemn hymn.$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$Please pardon, goddess of the night,$NEWLINE$Please pardon, goddess of the night$NEWLINE$The men who killed your
virgin knight.$NEWLINE$The men who killed your$NEWLINE$virgin knight$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$These men now walk around her tomb,$NEWLINE$These men now walk around her tomb$NEWLINE$Singing songs of woe.$NEWLINE$Singing songs of woe$NEWLINE$Oh, midnight, join our moaning$NEWLINE$Oh, midnight, join our moaning$NEWLINE$Help us with our sighs and groaning$NEWLINE$Help us with our sighs and groaning$NEWLINE$Heavily, heavily.$NEWLINE$Heavily, heavily$NEWLINE$Graves, open up and release your corpses$NEWLINE$Graves, open up and release your corpses$NEWLINE$Until Hero’s death is fully mourned$NEWLINE$Until Hero’s death is fully mourned$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$Heavily, heavily.$NEWLINE$Heavily, heavily

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Now, unto thy bones good night!$NEWLINE$Yearly will I do this rite.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Now I say good night to your bones, Hero. I will perform this ceremony every year.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Good morrow, masters. Put your torches out.$NEWLINE$The wolves have preyed, and look, the gentle day,$NEWLINE$Before the wheels of Phoebus, round about$NEWLINE$Dapples the drowsy east with spots of grey.$NEWLINE$Thanks to you all, and leave us. Fare you well.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Good morning, gentlemen. Put out your torches. The wolves have finished preying for the night, and look—the gentle dawn is rising, dappling the sleepy eastern sky with spots of light.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Good morrow, masters. Each his several way.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Good morning, gentlemen. We go our separate ways.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt LORDS and Musicians$NEWLINE$LORDS
paragraphs.translated: LORDS and musicians exit$NEWLINE$LORDS

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Come, let us hence, and put on other weeds,$NEWLINE$And then to Leonato’s we will go.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Come, let’s go and change our clothes. Then we’ll visit Leonato’s.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And Hymen now with luckier issue speed ’s$NEWLINE$Than this for whom we rendered up this woe.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And I hope
Hymen will give us better luck than Hero got.$NEWLINE$Hymen$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LEONATO,ANTONIO, BENEDICK,BEATRICE, MARGARET,URSULA, FRIAR FRANCIS, andHERO$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$BEATRICE$NEWLINE$MARGARET$NEWLINE$URSULA$NEWLINE$FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$HERO
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO, ANTONIO,BENEDICK, BEATRICE,MARGARET, URSULA, FRIAR FRANCIS, and HERO enter.$NEWLINE$LEONATO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$BENEDICK$NEWLINE$BEATRICE$NEWLINE$MARGARET$NEWLINE$URSULA$NEWLINE$FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$HERO

paragraphs.original: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Did I not tell you she was innocent?
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Didn’t I tell you she was innocent?

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$So are the Prince and Claudio, who accused her$NEWLINE$Upon the error that you heard debated.$NEWLINE$But Margaret was in some fault for this,$NEWLINE$Although against her will, as it appears$NEWLINE$In the true course of all the question.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$And the Prince and Claudio, who accused her, are innocent as well, because they were deceived by Don John. Margaret is partially guilty, although our investigation shows that she acted unintentionally.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Well, I am glad that all things sort so well.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Well, I’m glad that everything has been sorted out.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$And so am I, being else by faith enforced$NEWLINE$To call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Me too—otherwise I would have had to duel with Claudio.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Well, daughter, and you gentlewomen all,$NEWLINE$Withdraw into a chamber by yourselves,$NEWLINE$And when I send for you, come hither masked.$NEWLINE$The Prince and Claudio promised by this hour$NEWLINE$To visit me.—You know your office, brother.$NEWLINE$You must be father to your brother’s daughter,$NEWLINE$And give her to young Claudio.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Hero, you and the other women should all retreat to a room. When I send for you, come out wearing masks. The Prince and Claudio are supposed to be here by now.—You know your job, brother. You have to pretend to be your niece’s father, and give her away to Claudio.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt Ladies
paragraphs.translated: The ladies exit.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Which I will do with confirmed countenance.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I’ll do that, without giving away our secret.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Friar, I must entreat your pains, I think.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Friar, I think I need a favor from you.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$To do what, Signior?
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$What do you need me to do?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$To bind me or undo me, one of them.—$NEWLINE$Signior Leonato, truth it is, good Signior,$NEWLINE$Your niece regards me with an eye of favor.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$To tie me up, or to undo me: one or the other. Signior Leonato, the truth is, your niece likes me.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$That eye my daughter lent her; ’tis most true.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$She sees you with the eyes my daughter lent her, it’s true.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$And I do with an eye of love requite her.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$And I see her also through the eyes of love.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$The sight whereof I think you had from me,$NEWLINE$From Claudio and the Prince. But what’s your will?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$And those eyes were endowed with sight by Claudio, the Prince, and me. But what did you want?

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Your answer, sir, is enigmatical.$NEWLINE$But for my will, my will is your goodwill$NEWLINE$May stand with ours, this day to be conjoined$NEWLINE$In the state of honorable marriage—$NEWLINE$In which, good Friar, I shall desire your help.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Sir, I’m puzzled by what you just said. But as far as what I want—I want you to give Beatrice and me your blessing to be married. That, good Friar, is where you come in.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$My heart is with your liking.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Our wishes are aligned, then: I give you my blessing.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$And my help.$NEWLINE$Here comes the Prince and Claudio.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$And I’ll help you. Here comes the Prince and Claudio.

paragraphs.original: Enter DON PEDRO andCLAUDIO, and two or three others$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO andCLAUDIO enter with two or three others.$NEWLINE$DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Good morrow to this fair assembly.
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Good morning to all these lovely people.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Good morrow, Prince; good morrow, Claudio.$NEWLINE$We here attend you. Are you yet determined$NEWLINE$Today to marry with my brother’s daughter?
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Good morning, Prince; good morning, Claudio. We’re waiting here for you. Are you still set on marrying my brother’s daughter?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I’ll hold my mind were she an Ethiope.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I wouldn’t change my mind even if she were
black-skinned.$NEWLINE$black-skinned$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Call her forth, brother. Here’s the friar ready.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Bring her out, brother. The friar’s ready.

paragraphs.original: Exit ANTONIO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO exits.$NEWLINE$ANTONIO

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Good morrow, Benedick. Why, what’s the matter$NEWLINE$That you have such a February face,$NEWLINE$So full of frost, of storm and cloudiness?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$Good morning, Benedick. What’s the matter? Your face looks like the month of February—full of frost, storms, and cloudiness.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I think he thinks upon the savage bull.$NEWLINE$Tush, fear not, man. We’ll tip thy horns with gold,$NEWLINE$And all Europa shall rejoice at thee$NEWLINE$As once Europa did at lusty Jove$NEWLINE$When he would play the noble beast in love.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I think he’s nervous—he’s about to become the savage bull who got domesticated. Oh, don’t worry about it—we’ll dip your
horns in gold and make you pretty, and you’ll delight all of Europe, just like Jove delighted Europa when he was a bull.$NEWLINE$horns$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$he

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Bull Jove, sir, had an amiable low,$NEWLINE$And some such strange bull leapt your father’s cow$NEWLINE$And got a calf in that same noble feat$NEWLINE$Much like to you, for you have just his bleat.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Jove came to earth lowing for love. A strange bull just like him mated with one of your father’s cows and, voilà, gave birth to a calf like you—you bleat the same as him.$NEWLINE$Jove$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$For this I owe you. Here comes other reck'nings.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I’ll get you for that one. But here are other matters to be dealt with.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONIO,HERO, BEATRICE,MARGARET, URSULA, the ladies masked$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$HERO$NEWLINE$BEATRICE$NEWLINE$MARGARET$NEWLINE$URSULA
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO, HERO,BEATRICE, MARGARET,URSULA enter. The ladies wear masks.$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$HERO$NEWLINE$BEATRICE$NEWLINE$MARGARET$NEWLINE$URSULA

paragraphs.original: Which is the lady I must seize upon?
paragraphs.translated: Which is the lady I’m supposed to marry?

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$This same is she, and I do give you her.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$This one, and I will give her to you.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Why, then she’s mine.—Sweet, let me see your face.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Well, then she’s the one for me. Sweetheart, let me see your face.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$No, that you shall not till you take her hand$NEWLINE$Before this friar and swear to marry her.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$No, you can’t do that until you take her hand and, in front of this friar, swear to marry her.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(to HERO) Give me your hand before this holy friar.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I am your husband, if you like of me.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$(to HERO) Give me your hand. With the friar as my witness, I am your husband, if you want me.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$And when I lived, I was your other wife,$NEWLINE$And when you loved, you were my other husband.$NEWLINE$(She unmasks)$NEWLINE$(She unmasks)
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$And when I lived, I was your other wife. And when you loved me, you were my other husband.(she removes her mask)$NEWLINE$(she removes her mask)

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Another Hero!
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$It’s another Hero!

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$Nothing certainer.$NEWLINE$One Hero died defiled, but I do live,$NEWLINE$And surely as I live, I am a maid.
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$Exactly right. One Hero died when she was slandered, but I am alive. And as surely as I am alive, I am a virgin.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$The former Hero! Hero that is dead!
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$It’s the former Hero! The Hero that died!

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$She died, my lord, but whiles her slander lived.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$She was only dead, my lord, as long as her slander lived.

paragraphs.original: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$All this amazement can I qualify$NEWLINE$When after that the holy rites are ended$NEWLINE$I’ll tell you largely of fair Hero’s death.$NEWLINE$Meantime let wonder seem familiar,$NEWLINE$And to the chapel let us presently.
paragraphs.translated: FRIAR FRANCIS$NEWLINE$I can confirm that all these shocking things are true. After the wedding ceremony, I’ll tell you all about beautiful Hero’s “death.” In the meantime, just accept all these wonderful things, and let’s head to the chapel.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Soft and fair, Friar.—Which is Beatrice?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Wait a moment, Friar. Which one of you is Beatrice?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$(unmasking) I answer to that name. What is your will?$NEWLINE$(unmasking)
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$(taking off her mask) That’s my name. What do you want?$NEWLINE$(taking off her mask)

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Do not you love me?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Do you love me?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Why no, no more than reason.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$No, no more than is reasonable.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Why then, your uncle and the Prince and Claudio$NEWLINE$Have been deceived. They swore you did.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Well then, your uncle and the Prince and Claudio have been deceived. They swore you did.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Do not you love me?
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Do you love me?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Troth, no, no more than reason.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Truly, no—no more than is reasonable.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Why then, my cousin, Margaret, and Ursula$NEWLINE$Are much deceived, for they did swear you did.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$Well then, Margaret, Ursula, and my cousin have been very much deceived, for they swore you did.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$They swore that you were almost sick for me.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$They swore that you were sick with love for me.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$They swore that you were well-nigh dead for me.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$They swore that you were nearly dead with love for me.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$'Tis no such matter. Then you do not love me?
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Oh, well. So you don’t love me?

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$No, truly, but in friendly recompense.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$No, I don’t—except as a friend.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Come, cousin, I am sure you love the gentleman.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$Come on, niece, I’m sure you love him.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And I’ll be sworn upon ’t that he loves her,$NEWLINE$For here’s a paper written in his hand,$NEWLINE$A halting sonnet of his own pure brain,$NEWLINE$Fashioned to Beatrice.$NEWLINE$(Shows a paper)$NEWLINE$(Shows a paper)
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$And I’ll swear that he loves her. Here’s a clumsy sonnet, in Benedick’s handwriting, dedicated to Beatrice. (holding up a piece of paper)$NEWLINE$(holding up a piece of paper)

paragraphs.original: HERO$NEWLINE$And here’s another,$NEWLINE$Writ in my cousin’s hand, stol'n from her pocket,$NEWLINE$Containing her affection unto Benedick.$NEWLINE$(Shows a paper)$NEWLINE$(Shows a paper)
paragraphs.translated: HERO$NEWLINE$And here’s another poem, which I stole from my cousin’s pocket—in her handwriting and all about her adoration for Benedick. (holding up a piece of paper)$NEWLINE$(holding up a piece of paper)

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$A miracle! Here’s our own hands against our hearts. Come,$NEWLINE$I will have thee, but, by this light, I take thee for pity.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$What a miracle! Our handwriting gives away our hearts. Come on, I’ll take you, but honestly I’m only doing it out of pity.

paragraphs.original: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I would not deny you, but, by this good day, I yield upon$NEWLINE$great persuasion, and partly to save your life, for I was told$NEWLINE$you were in a consumption.
paragraphs.translated: BEATRICE$NEWLINE$I won’t say no to you, but let it be known that I’m only doing this after a lot of persuasion and to save your life —I hear you were quickly wasting away without me.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Peace! I will stop your mouth.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Oh, shut up! I’ll stop your mouth with a kiss.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: They kiss
paragraphs.translated: They kiss.

paragraphs.original: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$How dost thou, Benedick, the married man?
paragraphs.translated: DON PEDRO$NEWLINE$How does it feel to be Benedick the Married Man?

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I’ll tell thee what, Prince: a college of wit-crackers cannot$NEWLINE$flout me out of my humor. Dost thou think I care for a satire$NEWLINE$or an epigram? No. If a man will be beaten with brains, he$NEWLINE$shall wear nothing handsome about him. In brief, since I do$NEWLINE$purpose to marry, I will think nothing to any purpose that$NEWLINE$the world can say against it, and therefore never flout at me$NEWLINE$for what I have said against it. For man is a giddy thing, and$NEWLINE$this is my conclusion.—For thy part, Claudio, I did think to$NEWLINE$have beaten thee, but in that thou art like to be my kinsman,$NEWLINE$live unbruised, and love my cousin.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$I’ll tell you what, Prince: a whole university full of wisecrackers couldn’t change my mood today. You think I care what I’m called? Well, I don’t. If a man is always afraid of what others think, he won’t even dare to dress nicely, because he’ll be afraid people will talk about him. In short, since I intend to get married, I won’t hear anyone say a bad thing about it. So don’t go making fun of me for what I said before. Man is a giddy, flighty thing: that’s my conclusion. And Claudio—though I’m sure I would have beaten you in our duel—since you’re likely to become my relative, I’ll let you go, unbruised, and love my cousin Hero.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I had well hoped thou wouldst have denied Beatrice, that I$NEWLINE$might have cudgeled thee out of thy single life, to make thee$NEWLINE$a double-dealer, which out of question, thou wilt be, if my$NEWLINE$cousin do not look exceedingly narrowly to thee.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$I was sort of hoping you would say no to Beatrice, so that I could have smacked you out of your single life and made you a
double dealer. Which you’ll probably turn into anyway, if my cousin Beatrice doesn’t keep you on a short leash.$NEWLINE$double dealer$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Come, come, we are friends. Let’s have a dance ere we are$NEWLINE$married, that we may lighten our own hearts and our wives'$NEWLINE$heels.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$Come on, we’re all friends. Let’s do a dance, and have some fun, before we’re wed.

paragraphs.original: LEONATO$NEWLINE$We’ll have dancing afterward.
paragraphs.translated: LEONATO$NEWLINE$We’ll dance after the wedding.

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$First, of my word! Therefore play, music.—Prince, thou art$NEWLINE$sad. Get thee a wife, get thee a wife. There is no staff more$NEWLINE$reverend than one tipped with horn.
paragraphs.translated:
BENEDICK$NEWLINE$No, before! Musicians, play us a song.—Prince, you look sad. You should get a wife! Your royal staff would be so much more impressive if it were topped off by a
horn.$NEWLINE$horn$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$(to DON PEDRO) My lord, your brother John is ta'en in flight$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$And brought with armed men back to Messina.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$(to DON PEDRO) My lord, your brother John was caught by armed soldiers as he fled. He’s been brought back to Messina.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$(to DON PEDRO) Think not on him till tomorrow. I’ll devise$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$thee brave punishments for him.—Strike up, pipers.
paragraphs.translated: BENEDICK$NEWLINE$(to DON PEDRO) Leave him till tomorrow. I’ll think of some awful punishment for him. Play on, musicians!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Dance
paragraphs.translated: They all dance.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.
